pros: It's a large broker dealer institution, giving you exposure to world capital markets.  There is a large spend on Tech in general, and the size of the department ensures you have access to new technology that would not be seen in smaller IT environments. You will come out of a job with them with new buzzwords on your CV.  Opportunities for moving business product area in some cases.  Large degree of independece in how you complete your work.
cons: Poor morale, poor tech architecture, management not aligned with staff, frequent project change, High project failure rate, high staff turnover, low pay in Investment Banking IT terms. Disparate systems is also a negative in that you tend to be constantly firefighting old/existing systems instead of concentrating on greenfield development.  The pay, even on promotion, is not reflective of the extra hours/weekends put in to the job.  It is not even higher than inflation.

review_title: Citigroup works like a large corporation would be expected to work...
job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
For the most part it seems that Citigroup's pay and benefits are about average to other large corporations however they are definitely less than some of the smaller Wall Street firms and more than some of the other gloabl banks.

As a large corporation Citigroup operates as one would expect a large corporation would however one area they seem to have really focused on and started to provide some significant strides is the Work/Life balance.  Just about every person I know working here works from home at least one day a week with some working at an "Alternate Work Location" full time.
cons:
Citigroup operates very much like a large corporation would.  politics are everywhere and to get something done takes significant man power, stress, and time.  Nothing is simple in a company this big as there are too many layers of management, too many independent "businesses" and "regions".  It gets frustrating operating in a hybrid model where some stuff is centralized while others are de-centralized.  It may be easier if they picked one strategy and stuck with it.

The overall well-being of the employee as a commodity for Citigroup is signigficantly lacking.  There is a general lack of respect for common employees in the upper levels of this company's management.

CEO and executives are completely disconnected from its employees.

review_title: You have to work to get the rewards
pros: LOTS of opportunity if you are willing to work hard and be humble. A company this big always has a place for the right fit person. It also has an endless opportunity to learn how things work in the financial services industry, if you are flexible, willing to move laterally, and in some cases, geographically.
cons: Generally pays middle-of-the-market and due to the economic downturn, doesn't bonus to meet/beat the market, as in past. Also, there are still a number of VERY difficult personalities and politics (as there would be anywhere), and some of them advance up and fast, so you have to be willing to tolerate that. Sometimes, finding the right management fit, which can make a vast amount of difference, can be difficult. You can make more and move higher by leaving and coming back. Lastly, you have to have a level of tolerance for the uncertainty of the market.

Targets are not realistic and since you will receive a base salary higher then most bank sales positions you will be reminded daily/weekly that you are expendable if you are not selling consistently. They hold the base salary over your head like it’s our fault they offered it to us. Max life expectancy of a CRM is 1-2 years. Anything over that the stars must be alined. Expected to make between 25-40 contacts a day with clients, which can be achieved but with everything else on our plate in the branch can be very hard.  Micromanaged more then any company I have ever worked for. Actually using any of your vacation time is a stretch. Annual bonus for most CRMs equals a few thousand dollars if that.  The challenges are that there is simply too many other (much better) options at other banks for the clients with better technology for them to keep their money at Citi. Don’t blame them. Management for the CRM group in the L.A. area is terrible. Unable to give true coaching leadership and seem out of touch with current reality. Citi seems to be the only company that promotes based on tenure rather then competency.

review_title: I'm looking for a new company.
pros: It looks good on a resume.  That is all that I can think of.  I work in operations, a entry job.  The benefits were very good about a year ago, but due to the recession, they have gotten very "average".
cons:
No raises for 2008, even after hard work.  They give you a "promotion" which means more work and no extra pay.  There is very little incentive for attendance, so people call in and use all of their sick days.  

This company is too focused on "cultural diversity".  People of a diverse background are given promotions even though they are grossly unqualified.  Its very sad to see, but it happens in every department.

The cut the educational reimbursement money in half, and raised the health care costs (mine doubled)..

Pay is right in the middle, probably on the low side for the amount of work that you do.

Walk around the halls in Citi, everyone is miserable.  People will stab each other in the back at any cost to advance themselves, or at least they think they are "advancing".

Upper management will never deliver bad news directly to you, they pass it on to middle managers who's hands are tied.  I actually feel bad for the middle management (kind of).

People in upper management make operational policy, yet they have never worked in operations themselves.  Its hilarious some of the rules that they make.  Totally clueless operation.

review_title: It is a really big bank that values policy and procedure more than doing what is right for the client.
job_title: Business Banking Relationship Manager in New York, NY
pros: Everyone is nice and there is opportunity for good training if you are interested in Commercial Credit and the analytical side. Best to get your training and some seasoning at Citibank and then leave to actually be able to put your skills to use.
cons:
Massive bureaucracy that drives the business. I would guess for every revenue producer there are 10 people who provide support.

Business Banking has an unyielding, unwavering , uncreative credit team that lives by it's rote interpretation of credit policy and target market restrictions. Morale in this segment is now worse than the dark days of the single digit stock price.  Highly rated performers are leaving in droves as they are unable to book loans- which is the primary driver of performance ratings. Can't book a loan- you go on performance plan. Nice way to motivate a team

job_title: Loan Associate in Fort Mill, SC
pros: Benefits are relatively decent depending upon one's position. Middle-level jobs commonly offer better benefits than entry-level jobs, but this may be expected across competitors.
cons: Very minimal training for entry-level and mid-level positions. High stress environment and language barrier among peers makes the job tedious. Dealing with frustrated customers is possibly the worst element of working in the student loans customer service field for this particular company. (For example, it is impossible to truthfully promote CitiAssist student loans based upon Citi's poor business practices and policies. (i.e.: unemployed students - and there are plenty of them - receive little to no options for postponing and/or reducing payments immediately after graduation and while searching for employment). Dealing with frustrated consumers on an hourly basis is not for the weak of heart, or for those who understand the client perspective. Citibank expects loan reps to be cordial and remain calm and collected during these heated interactions. Management is not supportive of employees during this process, and simply fails to follow through on notifying the powers that be of consumer complaints. I was instructed to "ignore" angry consumers' complaints on numerous occasions but would go home to the family each night feeling like a snake and scoundrel for not offering consumers options, or at the very least sharing their true perspectives, requests, complaints, and suggestions with upper level management. Very challenging issues with poor, misguided management. Pay rate and annual compensation not worth the headache, in my personal opinion. Thick-skinned individuals seem to manage better, but I could only tolerate (and sleep peacefully at night) after a few months working here. Outsourcing of jobs a common complaint, also.

job_title: Vice President IT Project Manager in Long Island City, NY
pros: There is amply opportunity to move within Citi, but you need to take the initiative.   Each department has its own corporate culture and way they deal with personnel.  If your lucky you will work in a good department that respects your efforts.
cons:
In seven year I saw few experienced people get promoted.  Most who came in through Citi's management associate program were quickly promoted from intern to Sr. VP within five year.  I saw too many people who  I deemed capable passed over for greater opportunity.  
Your annual review is based more on the department's budget than on your contribution.  My outstanding performance review had to be reduced to average because there was no money in the budget (told to me by a Director). 
Senior Management spends to much time on 'CYA'.  I was told to falsify reports to show that a high priority project was not going over budget.

review_title: Experienced Locals DO NOT apply to Citi
pros: They give you money for showing up.
cons:
Positions: They appear to be complex analytical jobs, but in fact they are relatively simplistic. You will have a 50/50 chance of obtaining an engaging job. Low salaries and no negotiations in salary. 0.50-75% annual raises for excellent performance, no bonus or production incentive.
 Engaging/well paid jobs do exist  - but they usually only go to friends/family of mgmt/upper management. No training in alot of positions - see "teamwork" below. That is only a preview of some items.

Management: Exceptionally inexperienced. The staff  was all new 8 years ago. Very minimal transfer in experienced management from the head office. Managers exhibit "teamwork behavior" below. 30% you will get a good manager. Most good ones will quit.

Teamwork: There is none. Teams have learned to take on the behavior of the traders and MO's that they deal with. Hoarding information, no sharing, no training skills, and "bully culture" abounds. It is a toxic work environment* in many ways. This term* goes into more detail on these behaviors.

Facility: Facility is over crowded. Sometimes you have to wait to use stall in the bathroom. Leaving the office at 5PM is a traffic jam for 15-20Min. before you even leave the office complex. Sometimes walk into office to where you park is about 4-5 city blocks.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros:
- AMAZING maternity leave benefits and work from home flexibility.  I would recommend to any woman who wants a full time job during pregnancy and while raising small children.  Women can combine the 13 weeks of paid maternity leave with other paid time off (vacation + sick days) to get up to 4.5 months off paid at 100%.  Citi also allows up to 6 months off total (including paid and unpaid time) for each maternity leave.  That is hard to beat.
- Citi also offers generous flexible work arrangements.  Almost everyone in my office works remotely 1-3 days per week.  Some people even work remotely 100%.
- Our Citi Cards office is very casual and laid back.  Everyone is friendly and the environment is noncompetitive.
- Senior managers are very approachable and open to new ideas.
cons:
- Internal promotions are limited, but some employees seem content to stay in the same position for 30 years.
- Likewise, yearly raises based on merit and even raises for promotions are minimal.  Many employees leave Citi to take a high paying job, then come back a couple years later in order to get a sufficient raise.
- The employee costs of the health care plans have been increasing significantly each year.

review_title: Solid company to work for with opportunities for growth
pros:
In the right role and department, Citi offers great opportunities to grow professionally. I have had the opportunity to reach out to mentors who have helped me to develop the right set of skills within the company to quickly move from temp to permanent to promotion within the course of only 2 years. 

My current role is low stress, I feel overpaid, and at times under-challenged, however there is great potential for more ambitious people to move up the ranks quickly. Culture in my specific department is diverse, laid-back, and fun. I cannot speak for every time or every department at the company, but my experience has been good so far.
cons: The company is unsurprisingly bureaucratic. It can be difficult to pitch an innovative idea or reach out for career guidance without following the proper hierarchy. Procedures can sometimes pit coworkers against each other and there is no shortage of politics among middle management. Communication within a such a large and geographically dispersed workforce can be a challenge.

review_title: Citi never sleeps, or pays, or gives better benefits....
pros: I like the people I work with, we share the same mentality when it comes to work.  I enjoy what I do on a daily basis.
cons: We are a hard working IT group that completes jobs in record times to the benefits of or internal customers yet we get little recognition outside of our group.  Wage hikes have been non-existent for the past 5 years while benefit cost and deductible amounts continue to rise for the employee.  Way too much "I need this yesterday" due to the fact of poor planning on the PMs.  The "I'll blame you!" attitude so get things done in a hurry, sometimes needing to be re-done 2 or 3 times when we could have just waited to get it right in the first place with better information.  A lot of jobs have been outsourced to groups that seem to have no clue as to what they are doing, yet it is our responsibility to make sure that things get installed correctly with little or no information.  Seems to be a lit of wasted effort and poor planning.

pros: Global company with people across many different functions. The very scale of the company would have you believe that there are opportunities about with respect to career development and progression.
cons: The Citi culture is awful.  The people there are very unpleasant and not team players.  When you first start out there if you ask someone for help there are very few people actually willing to help you.  I was even told that one person couldn't help me because that would take him away fro his own work.  There is no consistent onboarding process and you stay in a constant state of ambiguity.  The company is run in silos that are almost impenetrable.

pros: There are many different career paths, and managment for the most part is good about allowing employess to move around to gain experience.  There are opportunities to move geographically as well.  There are some divisions that are definitely more pleasant to work in than others (the more highly regarded areas like Collections, Risk, Customer Service).  If you are mobile, most people should be able to find a job that they enjoy doing for awhile, while adding tremendously to your resume.
cons:
Company still operates in silos (every division has its own finance group, technology group, hr, etc).  Any attempt to consolidate functiions and create synergies is met with resistance.  There is no accountability and senior execs can be unreasonably demanding, expecting instant results on projects that might take weeks or months.  This appears to be the result of Sr VPs moving laterally to gain experience, and then instantly trying to 'make their mark' before understanding the business.
High performers generally bear the burden of handling the difficult or unwanted side projects/issues that crop up during the course of regular business (projects that don't get recognition, but need to be done for the business to operate efficiently).

Then, once you become a permanent Citibank employee (which you constantly are being told "it will happen soon" and ends up taking over a year), they decide to lay you off due to no work. Then a few months later, another temp agency wants to hire you back on, temp of course, so even if you worked at Citi for 2 years prior, you still have to start at "0". You go through all the same hoops as if you never were employed there. Because you work in a division that deals with Latin America, you are not given Thanksgiving off (even though you work in the US, for a US-owned company). You are required to work Thanksgiving, with no double-time or even time and a half. They are the biggest illegal raquet going on today, and will not stop abusing of their employees, even when they get sued. They take advantage of folks looking for real work (you MUST have a college degree), and treat you as if you were a kid out of high school.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Reputable company-looks good on your resume. A few years before the company started to decline, they had a good work life balance system (6 1/2 day Fridays or 3 whole day Fridays in the summer, birthday off, shopping day in winter). Depending on your department, managers encouraged professional development.
cons: Extremely political. At the top, promotions based on who is in the clique. Citi has a "throw you under the bus type of culture."  Depending on the department you are in, it could be a dead end area where there is no room for advancement or growth. Senior managers at times take all of the credit for the work being done without acknowledging the ones who are processing the work, ie, "the work horses." Senior managers have no real sense of acknowledging true talent in the company.

review_title: Positive experience, excellent job training and benefits with wonderful flexibility.
pros: Flexibility!  A range of part-time schedules were available in my department and it was easy to change my schedule if I had an appointment or something going on with my kids. Excellent benefits, including hands-down best tuition reimbursment program I've ever seen.  Truly a company that wants to see it's employees succeed!  While I worked there, you could even take college courses on our worksite campus.  Wonderful place to work for college students or mom's looking for part-time work.  Also, Citi actively seeks out and hires those with no experience and the job training is amazing.  The skills I learned have helped me get many great paying jobs.
cons: Pay was terrible!  They always tried to mitigate that by feeding us lines about all the other benefits.  Let's face it, the job I did was stressful and i did it at a salary that was way less than what competing banks pay.  It was hard to tell the impact my performance had on overall department goals...Tended to feel like "just a number."  Goals constantly changed making it difficult to get "incentive pay".   Also, incentive pay was rarely paid out on time.

pros: Citibank has some of the best benefits I've ever had while working with a company! The best part about working at the location that I was at is the on-site childcare center! I was able to see my children on lunch and take part in activities they had there. Citibank itself has tons of ways to become involved within the company and within the community. There was great team morale and the opportunity for advancement was fantastic.
cons: Other than having the on-site childcare during the day, there were many times that it was hard to have a good work-life balance. Our pipelines were pretty big from the start, which wouldn't have been so bad...however if you are a single parent and have children to take care of after work but others on the team don't, you are still held as much accountable with pretty much the same production goals even though you can't come in as early or stay as late to work your files. However, there were plenty of times that management was empathetic with others' situations and really helped out.

review_title: Poor leadership, no direction-risk management organization
pros: BASE Salary in the DE market is on the higher side,(read con), freedom mostly to work from home as needed, 4 summer Fridays off additional for the past fewer years in us cards
cons:
Senior leadership can be split into 2 groups those who want to get promoted at all costs, and those who just wants to keep everything the way they are. Theres not a sense of direction for where the group is going, and strong disconnect from citi as a whole. Teams generally don't work together, communication  between teams is nonexistent, push back by senior management is usually on their own team, and very little support given to employees to grow and develop. 
Bonus for most people is 0, don't buy the lie that HR tell you, insurance is expensive and has a high deductible. Overall, I'd say if you get a good base salary and don't care much about your work, this is a good place to work, otherwise you will be frustrated, angered, and have nothing to show for after all that. 
Theres not a culture of promoting from within, most people are on h1b from India, so doing the work is more important than the why.

pros: Citibank International PLC is a good place to work at in general, but it all depends on the Managers.
cons: Along the years I had really good managers who cared about the employees and unfortunately I came across one who cared only about his own career and his own salary raise, and the 3-4 people who were his right hand,  and that pretty much destroyed a whole team of 32 members.  While when I got hired people were professional and you had seniors who you could turn to with your questions and had the opportunity to learn from then, this all disappeared when we got this new manager. He hired unprofessional new graduates so the wages  can go down and thus his and his little team members' ,on who he was relying onto due to his own lack of knowledge,  can go up at least twice a year altogether with at least once a year promotion.

Most of the AML departments at the Tampa campus are volatile, and there were some structural layoffs during my time there.   This was a major turn off to me because it didn't seem like there was a difference in job security between a full-time employee and a contractor.

review_title: Downsize and Get Back to Basics
pros: Diversity and globality.  It is a business that is far reaching that allows one to explore a number of different businesses under one roof.  Citi does value International expereince and a braod range of skills.  With offices in over 100 countries the ability to gain valuable insight from a world perspective is easily attainable.
cons: It is way too large.  As much as diversity and globality is a strength it is also a weakness.  The busines is just too big for one person to manage and the Company has gotten away from its core value, which is banking.  what made Citi successful in teh past has been passed over for sheer size and for making way for a giant financial supermarket.  The market has proven that this cannot work, but the reason that this has not worked is that Citi has concentrated more on building and acquiring rather than melding.  The busineses are all silos with no money spent on integrating business so that they work as one.  Through all of this what has been lost is the innovative spirit that Citi possessed.

review_title: Great to start, Hard to stay
pros: Good place to learn alot about the industry, and there is "ok" ability to move across different business groups depending on availability, luck, who you know, or better yet all three. Able to work with some really smart and dedicated colleagues. Global brand recognition, footprint, and training is good in certain business groups while others just throw you to the wolves.
cons: Regulatory aspect is getting worse as the years go by, big government impedes the ability to do business well and it is affecting the whole industry. Micro-management is prevalent in some businesses. Some colleagues are amazing, others just don't care, and still others used to care but don't anymore. Massive layoffs the past few years have been terrible for morale. There's an underlying feeling that some of the goals in certain businesses are purposefully inflated so few can meet goal, let alone exceed goal, so then bonuses won't have to be paid. I've heard this from veteran sales people who were very successful for many years, but are suddenly "not making goal" anymore and placed on final notice. Very discouraging, and even for the sales people who are doing well in this environment their morale is low too. Strangely, there are also some people who do very little and get away with high compensation and outright laziness. Absolutely confounding.

pros: You are allowed to wear jeans and polo shirt on Friday.  And Saturday and Sunday if they make you work over time.
cons: Citi AML is like Vietnam.  Don't bother making friends there, because either you or them will be gone very soon.  Citi starts a new class of temps about once every two months.  My class was May 2014.  We started out with 83 people.  Exactly one year later only 32 remained.  The rest either quit, or were fired for petty reasons.  If you accept a job here, 60% of the people in your class will not reach one year.  If you are desperate for a job, ok work here for a while.  But DO NOT quit your current job to come here.  Although we do not work directly with customers, I have never seen a more unprofessional atmosphere.  Several people in my class had visible tattoos.  One girl even had pink hair!  Can you believe that?  A pink hair employee working for a Fortune 500 company?

cons: Management was not much more competent than subordinates. This resulted in a lot of animosity between these levels.  Work is often tedious and does not change much from day to day.  It often has the feel of working on an assembly line- just from a desk rather than a factory floor.  The biggest downside is with the lack of talent development.  There are a good number of well educated and experience employees in low level jobs who would like to advance.  With such a large company this should be possible.  However, there is no formal process in place to identify talent and groom it for future leadership roles with more responsibility.  This contributes to the generally low morale and high turnover.
