pros: Most of the people I worked with were professional and very friendly.  The time-off policies were very generous and you were encouraged to use them.  There were more than adequate opportunities for promotions if you were willing to work very long hours.  There were a lot of training opportunities, as well, and allowed me to develop very marketable skills.  The pay was great, imo.
cons: I worked at Citi for 8 years during the turbulent times that included the most recent recession.  It was embarrassing to be part of a company that was so publicly criticized for the  handouts it took, and then the fines it paid when it was discovered that its actions contributed in a big way to the recession.  During recovery, there were a lot of layoffs, then reorganizations, then layoffs, and more reorgs, then hiring a lot of people at lower wages.  It became very stressful.

job_title: Sec Processing Representative II in Mississauga, ON
pros: It's a globally recognized company, but it's definitely not a positive organization to work for.
cons: Management at Citi is the epitome of inept. The job here is bad enough, but the use of antiquated, inefficient systems and procedures makes your day-to-day that much harder. Management dreams big, but is incapable and unqualified to implement any sort of change that adds benefit or value to the company. Many functions of the job are being moved to India where the workers they hire are incompetent causing you to have to always correct their work or send it back for rework, which delays deliverables. SVPs and VPs are spineless when it comes to defending staff from demanding and unreasonable fund managers. Accepting unrealistic demands means frequent nights working until midnight, especially at month end. Advancement opportunities are few and far between. Management tends to hire employees from the former companies that they've worked for.  These workers tend to be very unqualified for the job. They would rather hire workers externally with little experience than a more experienced internal candidate. Management also tends to hire many temporary staff from temp agencies. Management likes to promote people with little education. Many supervisors and AVPs have only obtained a community college diploma or are from mediocre universities like the University of Windsor.

review_title: Working at citibank call center as a Personal Bnaker
job_title: Personal Banker in San Antonio, TX
pros: good steady work, steady pay but doing on phone sales is a must!  Your required to take incomming customer service calls on rare occassions but most of your sales will come from your excellent cross selling skills and ability to seize opportunities with the customers your dealing with, so its best to learn the products during training as good as you can along with all their benefits so you can upsell them when the opportunity arises.
cons: on a computer all day, which can cause headaches and the job itself althogh rewarding can become very boring one you master it.  Some bosses are jerks at Citibank and want you to sell home equitys to every customer and this takes a very special skilled person to do all the time but they expect it and can make life there hard because of their greed for them. Also commissions are hard to get if you mess up and say something you wernt suppose to say they monitor all calls and can take away commisions for all the home equitys you closed that month, and this sucks.

pros: Excellent manuals and resources available to assist you with doing your job. Excellent benefits and vacation time. Company is very involved with community and several charities. Company is great in recognizing its employees. The building is very nice.
cons: I believe the pay is not competitive. Rarely do you receive an annual increase and if so, it is very small, usually under 1%. Loyalty does not pay- since there are very small annual increases, if any at all, the only way to increase your salary is to constantly move from one position to the next. You are limited to advancing from one position into another until you have been with the current position at least one full year. Very few exceptions.

review_title: Run.. You don't want want be a Personal Banker here, Citibank Retail Branches are going down the Drain.
job_title: Prsoanl Banker in New York, NY
pros: In comparison to other banks, Citibank offers great salaries.
cons: Work-life in  the  retail branch is horrible.  I feel like it is just as bad as Chase Bank use to be back in 2010. The culture is so aggressive with the goals that it can force you to be unethical, oh and management even bullies you to do it.  They push customer service with a TOOL called KDS which is completely off scale.  Also resource are completely malfunctioning. Most of the employees that are working in the branch are miserable and looking for a way out.

review_title: Uninspiring leadership, lack of female leadership - glass ceiling, nice benefits, easy to make a mid level career there.
pros: Some line's of business allow the ability to work from home (salaried employees C12 and above), but warning that now many require being on IM all the time and on video/camera make you feel micro managed when working from home.  Nice benefits on vacation, sick and holiday time off for salaried employees.
cons: Get as much money as you can upon initial hire.  Big promotions come with small bumps in pay for twice the responsibility, stress, and hours.  Raises and annual bonuses went from great to pathetic in the last 7 years.  The office environment lacks passion and inspiration.  The culture is dead, especially the Regent campus.  Too many contractors.

review_title: Low pay with no room for career growth
pros: Benefits with flexibility when you need time off. Most of the people are nice and helpful to new workers... probably because its almost part of their job description since the place is a revolving door.
cons: Management doesn't help mostly because they are over worked themselves. Low pay with no room for growth in your career. General management is disorganized and tend to dump work on you even when you have too much without any consideration.

job_title: AVP- Culture Overhaul in New Castle, DE
pros: Good Pay, Benefits, Some really good co-workers
cons: Doing the job of 2 to 3 people. Never fully staffed. No work home life balance.Typical fear based management approaches that are outdated. Unprofessional feedback standard given and management does not practice what is preached.

pros: salary, pay and benefits only pros
cons: highly political & stressful environment

pros: Work with very bright individuals who know what it takes to get the job done!  Co-workers and peers help each other to do their jobs!
cons: Upper management - most above manager level do not have a clue about the mortgage industry.  Some upper management have been promoted based on who they know and not what they know.  One director came from another department, and did not even know that REO and Real Estate Owned were one in the same!  Terrible promotions being made, which makes entire department look bad.  If going to lay off employees, need to begin with some at the top, who have no clue what they are doing.  They are definitely ruining a once good company to work for.

review_title: Great company but seems lost itself
job_title: Infrastructure Senior Technical Analyst in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros:
Great global and huge financial conglomerate
Great people to work with, coworkers are like a "family"
cons:
Too much processes; poor project execution (everything run too slow, even simples things). 
 Headquarters  treat LAC employees just as "headcount",  a lot of layoffs mainly in technology area  (being outsourced), LAC manager are completely "yes man" to the Headquarters.
You don't have much opportunities to show your real talent, you are confined to a box and need to do everything "by the book" as a production line, what limits you a lot in terms of career development.
Company seems completely lost in their objectives, they are changing their goals all the time, they don't have a consistent path to follow (they've invested millions in a branch refresh and some months later closed most of them).
They waste millions in unuseful projects and think that that will cut costs is just "getting rid of the people".

review_title:
Citi Pune. The work culture here is very simple; you do not have to work hard at all, just butter and patronise your bosses very well and you will reach new heights. 
The HR in Citi is synonymous to a turtle. They lack IQ and are very slow. They will delay everything they could before you join. In fact, they will communicate hours before for any update.
pros:
Money- if you dont mind being a slave; u will get a good price for yourself.
Work from home- depends on your managers approval.
Senior management is very transparent.
cons:
HR Lacks IQ and is very slow in responding, sometimes they wont bother to reply to your email unless you escalate them.
Not enough 4 wheeler parking, its reserved only for seniors.
Bays, desks and even chairs are of pathetic quality. Expect back pain within a month.
Transport is pathetic.

review_title: Great technical work but ride could be rough [ CITI Equities Technology ]
pros:
Cutting edge work, most of the teams have great work with them .
CITI touches almost all technical niche skill available, something even a lot of mainstream IT companies don't and can't.
Mobility options to change job roles/locations. 
Great exposure to various real life business and activities. One can see and feel how his/her work is making money ( OR losing money ! ) for CITI.
cons:
Work life balance is not a common thing here. Though they are ON it to improve it.
Culture is informal so you need to be vocal and aggressive to be recognized and awarded, not a heaven for humble folks unless they are satisfied with whatever comes to them.
Mobility is easier below VP level, above that it matters if you have some Godfather .
A lot of not-best-kind-of-talent in non technical (aka HR/IT/Infrastructure ) streams
Bureaucracy which is affecting efficiency.
Not too many leaders who can inspire you.

job_title: Teller II in New York, NY
pros:
Starting pay
Paid sick days starting immediately 
Bank hours
cons: Management played the favorites game, in many occasions I was left out because I wasn't in a clique this includes by management & co workers. I was mislead believing I would have the opportunity to be a full time employee and they had no intention of ever giving me those hours. I accepted the position because I needed a job but ultimately ended up leaving because I couldn't afford to live off of part time hours. Management will blame you for things you had no part in if they are friends with the co workers who are stirring up the drama. Management called me out and made fun of me at an out of work event along w/ another co worker egging that manager on. Very unprofessional environment.

pros: Incentives are okay(given you pass all thr requirements). Once endorsed to the floor, toxicity decreases slightly so.
cons:
As the title states, the unprofessionalism from a majority of HR staff to Trianers to Managers is masked by their professional attire and "tone". 

I've never felt as isolated as I've ever been in all my experience when going through their training process. Trainers should be properly taught how to get full class participation by asking all trainees individually whether they follow the topic or not instead of rewarding *forgive the lack for a better term* Jollibee trainees. Grouping trainees into separate groups and applying a point system for participation does well for individuals who are competitive and *again forgive the terminology* Jollibee by nature. This completely backfires for other personality types(especially if they're part of a group thats losing in points). Obvious favoritism from managers present during such process.

HR had a very threatening tone prior to my employment and during.

Compensantion ceiling is very lackluster considering inflation in The Philippines.

Company culture can be put into 2 simple words, Overinflated Ego. Yes I understand that you're supposed to have pride when you work for your company. But trust me when I say, they're over the top.

TLDR; there are better options out there considering the call volume and toxicity of the environment. It isn't worth it.

review_title: Too slow in making some key decisions. Seems like  he is not suited for the crisis....
pros:
Size and global reach
Not too many senior management roles available elsewhere
cons:
No meritocracy
No stability in management, vision and depth
New management planted in IT/Ops from Lehman are bringing their own favorites. Not a bad idea if people are talented. Some are. But others have walked in with intellectual material from Barclays. This is plain illegal and problem waiting to bring the company down. No integrity. Sad part is the new management is aware of this
Some of the old managers have managed to survive on BS. With flux and management change, the BS is getting them further in career. While real rain makers are slogging and getting pushed down.
Example, FICC technnology has spent close to 1 billion in solutions for rates, fx and credit etrading, trading and risk platforms in the past 9 years. No real solutions have been delivered and the people involved have continued to grow without any consequence. With business management and technology management changes there is no real oversight or no one held accountable. Same story still continues.

job_title: All Stage Collections in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Typically the management staff tries to work with it's employees in regards to work/life balances, medical leave, and other personal issues that may arise. They also have a 401k contribution program and a healthy amount of time off as your longevity continues.
cons: The collection department has become a nightmare when it comes to job stability. Some associates have now transistioned through 4-6 managers. Some are due to managers being reassigned to different work while others have been let go due to lack of staff to manage. Staffing is bloated so there will be some downtime between timezones but this year they aren't making adjustments which is causing some people not to get approved for vacation days and even a chance of getting off early. Also the company has telecommuters who used to get reimbursed for their internet but the company has slashed that benefit to half the amount they used to give and then down to nothing in July.

review_title: Citi is no place to go if you want to progress in your career, that is unless you know someone important, be warned!
pros: Decent compensation but it could be better, the rest of benefits are great but are you willing to sell your soul to work there? If so, go ahead but be warned! I know this company is so popular with job seekers due to its "big name" but don’t fool yourself because of that fact alone please.
cons: Too much brown nosing, managers get compensated if they have knowledge no matter if they have no ethics whatsoever; I worked almost ten years at this bank so I know from experience what I am talking about. There was one manager who was known for shaming her subordinates verbally and openly (as per conversation with my then co-workers, this happened before I got into the team and it never happened to me but by her demeanor and treatment of colleagues I could see this was true), still not only she got a raise but a promotion as well.  There is a more serious issue with this bank and I am not going to get into details but one of the managers involved on it was "forced" to retire. Last but not least for career opportunities it is all about who you know otherwise forget about it, you are not getting anywhere better with your job.

review_title: Excellent growth and great Tampa, FL campus
pros: There are many tools and trainings available to you for professional growth. They are continuously making improvements to their technology groups and keeping up to date with the latest trends. They encourage movement within the company so its really hard to look else where since there is so much opportunity available within Citi and Tampa.
cons: You have to network here and it's a must. You will run into a few people and it raises your curiosity on how they got their position but their not horrible. They are in the process of hiring a lot and renovating so you may find yourself moving around too much. I've had 3 different cubicles and on two different sites that are 15 minutes apart. the renovations are said to be so people are more collaborative but really its so they can fit 3 people where two people sat before. Managers have shared offices of 2 to 3 people.

pros:
This company has good benefits. 

You'll get plenty of paid time off, and depending on your department, you can work remotely a lot of the time, which can helpful for work-life balance.

The local site really likes doing events, like for outdoor tailgating and Halloween, which can be fun and are a nice excuse to get away from your desk.
cons:
If you have management on site, you'll be lucky. Most managers are located in New Jersey or NYC, and you'll never see them. This results in a disconnect. They may forget about you, see you as numbers, see you as an inconvenience, or all three. Teams may be scattered too, which makes this issue worse.

There is a severe lack of training. Management often expects you to understand complex internal systems the first time you look at them. They don't offer any training or documentation to help with this. They overload the senior employees with work since they won't trust their newer employees, so seniors can't help train either.

Work-Life balance can be strained, especially if you have a highly international team. Management may also expect weekend work and refuse to give any comp for it.

Mobility and raises are minimal. Don't expect it.

pros:
The place is dynamic and always on the Move, there is so  much packed in a day you are waiting to breath .
It has good set of qualified professionals and  has a very huge and vast setup. Compensation is fair .
cons: The major challenge is the workload which can kill you and also leave no time for work life balance . HR is a mouthpiece of the management and has no independent say or decision making powers. Top Management work the way they want and cascade huge pressure on Junior staff. Work Culture has  eroded over the years and most want to push over the work or put it under the carpet. There is no career growth unless you are very qualified or a MBA from a good institute and put in like 14 hours daily.Too much emphasis on compliance has left the bank with little customer service oriented.

pros: none none none none none
cons: management is not good enough

review_title: Citi Operations/technology is an awful place to work for the motivated.  Heaven for the incompetant.
job_title: Technical Analyst in New York, NY
pros: I used to work in Compliance IT in GWM; the work is not difficult or time-consuming.  Generally, everyone gets in around 10, leaves at 5; definitely great if you want an extremely laid-back occupation.
cons: Awful place for any sort of intellectual stimulation, and there are no real exit opportunities.  You will work with (and probably under) low-caliber people, which is the nature of back-office, and find yourself working at their pace.  I was essentially a glorified email server; taking emails from one party and forwarding it to another.

job_title: Senior Vice President in Dallas, TX
pros: Amazing it has taken a big bank this long to get it right in the commercial lending space.  I have been with the company for quite some time, seen several previous attempts for the company to make a meaningful effort to build out the space between its great consumer/credit card franchise and its investment bank.  Well, that time has finally arrived under Mr. Corbat who is a real banker and who's influence and leadership is being felt throughout the company.
cons: Expense control is crushing and often nonsensical.  The company will save a buck even if it means cutting off it's left arm. Problem is, few in the company understand or can defend useful limbs that need to be saved or investment continued.   In the U.S. its systems are a terrible amalgamation of acquired technology, without investments made to update them.  There are some initiatives to fix them, but expense control remains the priority as the company tries to save its way into profitability.

pros: Being a big organization, Citi is able to sponsor you for a lot of things. To name a few, (internal/external)training, work visa, cfa/cqf exams, etc. Also, Citi tends to have small-medium sized teams(usually under 15). Lots of work/projects going on so you don't have to worry about having no work to do.
cons: Pay sucks, especially the bonus. I could barely buy an iphone with my post-tax bonus last year. You might think it was just me - I'm afraid it was not. Lots of colleagues/teammates had the same issue; I personally graduated as a MSc from a top 10 university in the world and joined Citi as a grad. After working for Citi for 3 years, this was what I got. Oh, I forgot to let you know that my salary rose by a bloody 16% for the first year(they give you 7 for base and 3 for bonus on joining, then 9 for base and 1 for bonus in the following year - look! you salary just rose by 28%! Don't be greedy ... )

job_title: Operations Analyst in New Castle, DE
pros: Citigroup was a great place to get started.  There were some great people to work with in Delaware Ops and while comp was low, I'm glad to have had the experience.
cons: Compensation was low and there are a few people that probably should have been filtered out by better interviewing.  Company needs to figure out  better compensation be it via salary or at the very least a decent 401K match. They are good a promising/selling things to employees that in all likliehood probably don't turn out they way they are described (if they even happen at all).

job_title: Commercial Business Developer- Manager in Ahmedabad
pros:
Salary 
Perks and Benefits 
Paid Holidays 
Supportive line Manager
Club Mahindra Resort Stay
Training and Development
cons:
Insurance oriented company
Rigid approach 
Growth 
Inter functional movement

job_title: Fixed Assets Accountant in Makati City
pros: I joined the company in July 2014 as a Financial Reporting Analyst/EMEA. The leads and colleagues are very professional. I learned a lot of things from them on how to deal with foreign counterparts. Being a financial reporting analyst (integrated close) is very challenging. You have to be keen to details and creative enough to cope up with their manual FDL reduction initiatives. You are encouraged to think outside the box and suggest ways on how to improve the current processes. I enjoyed my stay in that team until the top management decided to migrate the financial reporting tasks to Citi Mumbai. We were then transferred to various departments within the company, and unfortunately I was transferred to the Fixed Asset Team. The leads at that time were rushing the lateral transfers, and we were not given enough time to carefully study our options. As a CPA, joining in the fixed assets team would intake very limited opportunities to grow.
cons: Company policy regarding the meal and transportation allowance is not properly communicated within the teams. Some teams are not strict in approving the meal receipts, so if you're unlucky enough to be under a strict supervisor, then you have no choice but to follow.

pros: Higher than average salary (probably because of all the cons), flexible work schedule... i honestly can not think of any other positives.
cons:
There is a one hundred step process to anything that you do. Citi is using some very current tools when it comes to automation, configuration management, software development, etc, but all the features that make these tools so great are disabled or implemented incorrectly. 

The amount of "red tape" at this place is an enormous hindrance on creativity. The simplest of things are made difficult for no reason other than to check a box that was designed by some business person that somehow obtained their CISSP.

The hypocriticalness of this is massively amusing.. you don't have administrative rights on a Citi provided laptop, but business units supporting the trading markets are allowed to run 30 year old operating systems with huge vulnerabilities.

The culture is nothing short of depressing. Some reviews on Glassdoor will suggest being remote makes for difficult collaboration, but I can assure you that you're better off being remote, as being in the office is very demotivating.

There are people in roles that they definitely shouldn't be in.. my advice to anyone looking for a career in technology is to stay away from big banks.

pros:
Exposure to people and cultures around the world
In many orgs, if you work hard, and show commitment, you can grow your responsibilities and get promoted. 
If you have a strong, supportive manager, things can be great. 
388 Greenwich building renovation, nice new facilities.
cons:
-Ego-driven, political, and very competitive. Many people think more about what a project can do for their career, rather than how it can help the company or team. 
-Teams and individuals compete against each other, rather than market competition. 
-Not enough movement or diversity in senior leadership ranks. People stay put for many years, leading to stagnation in culture and ideas. 
-Extremely limited resources and a lack of prioritization across businesses. As a result, many poor quality work products are delivered, and business goals are not achieved. 
-Many employees are overworked and stressed due to lack of resources and prioritization. 
-Corporate title structure and related power dynamics are a massive culture driver. There isn’t adequate validation of business initiatives. If an MD thought of an idea, it’s taken as gospel.

pros: Good salaries and very nice facilities
cons: Excesive volume of work , unhuman dutyes

review_title: If you are a good employee that works hard make sure to promote yourself.
pros: 5 years ago I could list many good reasons to work for Citi, can think of any at the moment. Job security and knowing if you work hard you will be taken care of is not the case any more.
cons: Citi used to be a firm where you knew your future was safe. Now if management changes in New York, all that you worked for could go down the drain. Not good when you are trying to retain talent.

review_title: Great start, decent pay, no room for growth
pros: Citibank can be a great stepping stone. Their training program and bank platform are spectacular (albeit very slow majority of the time). The compensation for personal banker positions is one of the highest if you're coming on board from another financial institution. Great financial products and modern bank solutions for clients.
cons: I will be with the company for 4 years come this March and have submitted many job applications to help further develop my career. Majority of my applications have gone unanswered and the ones I do receive a response to say that "they have found a better qualified candidate". The positions I have applied to are nothing out of the ordinary for a personal banker to want to develop into. There just seems to be a lack of opportunity and growth potential. I've brought much business and deposits into my branch, my monthly compensation from surpassing "hurdles" will reflect that and the only reason I can imagine for not promoting me is because I'm an asset to them while holding the position I'm currently in.

pros: Good work/life balance and an even better, highly flexible work schedule/alternate workplace policy. Generally speaking, as long as you deliver, you can work from home with a reasonable schedule either when needed or on a regular schedule. Your mileage may vary depending on the specific group you're in but across the TTS Technology landscape, just about everyone works remotely some portion of time.
cons: Bureaucracy, plain and simple. You will spend 80% of your work like of purely administrative tasks, responding to exception reports, doing things to stay off exception reports, etc. Then there are all the organizational "asks" - fill this out, collect metrics on this, etc. All of this is on top of the 100-200 emails per day that a typical mid-level or higher technology person gets. Forget about doing anything meaningful or value-added - this is the type of place that you just put your time in and collect a paycheck.

review_title: Great experience - barring the fact that they don't recognize and promote talent as well as they should.
pros:
Great work life balance - at least in the business units I have been exposed to.
Great to have on the resume.
Management has been striving to make changes after the financial meltdown debacle and they have been successful in implementing key regulatory and other changes,
cons:
Lack of job - skill fit. Managers does not show an active interest in developing team member's and helping them grow.
Complete lack of appreciation for a job well done.
The company expects you to utilize all your skillsets (not just what you have been hired for) and then would not appreciate or compensate for providing services and going the extra mile.
I literally have contributed to 3-4 jobs while getting paid for one. The company realized huge cost savings from the the automation and ideas I had a stake in developing but I did not get as much as a "good job".
Some managers do try and steal the credit for a job well done - when it was all your effort that led to the well done.

pros: International- so plenty of departments you could transfer in when there are openings. Things constantly change, so there are always new things to learn. Good benefits-insurance.
cons: You can go years without getting a raise. During offer call, catch line is that there is bonus potential. A year after employment, you find out you have  to get a certain rating. When you do get that, no bonus and not even a inflation rate increase. Company profits, but few employees overwork (are abused)  thinking their efforts and performance will be paid for b/c rating is so good...until you see no bonus though you met all the standards. Surely management got bonuses when company reported good earnings. But if you ask, response will be "be lucky you got a job".

review_title: Very ambitious for everyone else but not yourself? Ethical?
pros: Diversity is good, company vaccation, holidays and off time is good. Many well educated young professionals. Location and gym is good. Company outings are good, many, and generous. Fiancial managennt is excellent - best see ever.
cons: Pack mentality in hunting down and picking on easy pray from the employees toward any employee. Most employees feel like they deserve better, but most need a lesson in humility. Sweep it under the carpet meentality or same: "manage you superiors expectations" attitude is rampant, obstruction, harrasment and lying is rampant. Group manager gave bad reference despite official policy is: no references. GAAP compliance is disreguarded for accruals. Free for all managerial tendicies because of much remote and young management. IT department is behind everyone else in capability.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in Sioux Falls, SD
pros:
-	The health benefits are actually good for the area I was in.
-	401K match to 6%
-	Work from home was available on an as needed basis
-	Most of the people were dedicated and care about their job.
-	They place a heavy emphasis on volunteering and helping other people.
-	Mandatory paid time off
-	Health rewards cards and benefits
-	Employee break room is well stocked.  I was impressed.
cons:
-	The 15% bonus “given to the highest performer” annually is subjective.  This is a real deterrent to doing high quality work.
-	A lot of the good talent has already left the company.
-	Women leaders are not empowered to make decisions.  The company talks about tolerance yet none of the women in our area, who were promoted to higher management, made the decisions.  This is very backward.
-	You’re lucky if you get more than 3% per year in pay raises.
-	Exit interviews are not given to all employees.
-	Lots of micro-managing.  Heaven forbid if you have your own mind. 
-	Little training is provided on the system.
-	Vague and often unattainable annual goals that must be completed usually before October.

job_title: Assistant Head Teller in Torrance, CA
pros: I had an awesome branch manager.
cons:
Where do I begin?!!! Citi bank will hire you with a 20 hour contract, but make you work full time. So you’re working full time hours with part time
Benefits, not cool! I had to constantly keep asking to get a full time contract since I www only working full time hours. I got it after two years. Also, the area directors will tell those branches who don’t open Saturdays that they HAVE to work one or two Saturdays at another branch. This is actually not required by HR at all, but no one speaks up because they are afraid of the area directors. Citi bank makes it hard for employees to perform they’re job fully because the branches are short staffed, or something is broken, AND the system pretty much has issues every day. On top of that, they don’t give you a raise. I worked three years there, even got a higher title, but no raise. Just got told to refer more and that I would make more money like that. Citi does NOT care about its employees at all. They spend money on stupid stuff, I.e., hats and ugly shirts for employees, instead of giving a raise or even a small bonus. PS: when a branch is short on tellers, no one helps you. They don’t care if you don’t take your breaks or lunches.

pros: My experience is that Citigroup appears not to be a serious employer. You can apply for a position with this company for which you are extraordinarily well-qualified, and you will NEVER hear back from the company. You will, however, continue to see the same position advertised by them, week after week, month after month, for a year or more after you have applied.
cons: I work in Baltimore and I applied online for a long time before I actually started getting called. I think Citigroup is one of those companies where they have to post jobs even if they've already decided someone else is going to get it. I used to think that the applications led to a black hole too. It can sure seem that way and for other sections of Citigroup that might be the case

pros: Not much to say as a pros
cons: No work life balance especially if you are travelling quiet far. High Politics. No bonus

job_title: Commercial Card Representative in Bradenton, FL
pros: Its a job. there's some nice people there.
cons: there is absolutely no work life balance. They are only about the clients. if you are looking for a company that shows value in employees citi is not for you. Their is no morale its very dreading even walking into the building. its very old and there arent and not to much mention they dont even supply cups. you have to bring your own cup daily if you want tea or coffee. and not to mention they dont even offer vending machines or a cafeteria. You would think a company that offers 30 min lunches only would have some type of food or snacks in the building ? wrong. the pto is terrible you barely get any. So if you have plan trips often you will not be able to take many with this job. There is nothing but favoritism and jealousy in my site. the only person i enjoy seeing is the security at the front.

pros: A stable, slightly less than market income. A gym. "A good payout to your spouse and kids if you die at work".  (An actual quote from a worker there).
cons: If you love making great software - don't work at Citi. They are a technology company who will figure out they are a technology company right when their market is taken away by competitors who offer a better user experience, higher-quality software and a caring and inclusive culture for their staff.  The software development model is Waterfall in drag as Agile, design principles are driven by daddy-knows-best and successful output is measured by adherence to outdated requirements and principles. It may be the case that user lock-in is enough to keep the behemoth alive..but if you want to work in a place where people swallow pills to keep going, have cardiac arrests at work and in which gratitude for a job is supposed to be enough to overlook the glaring organisational flaws - then it may be the place for you.

review_title: Good place to start if you can afford to work for low pay
pros: Great benefits - especially the vision insurance; customer centered focus; realistic performance measurements covering whole job duties instead of tunnel vision on stats only; career mentoring programs; tuition reimbursement; lots of locations for transfer opportunities.
cons: Hard to work up from entry level positions without education and/or experience (exception: see career mentoring program); low pay but good benefits; oversea outsourcing results in a lot of cultural/language misinterpretations; patchwork of aquired businesses divisions & departments makes it very hard to figure out where to redirect mis-routed calls.  Good Luck trying to figure out where a "CBNA" inquiry on your credit report originated.  Hard to get a scheduled day off but "Voluntary Time Off" without pay constantly offered to offset overscheduling.

pros:
There are a lot of opportunities to move around laterally. 
Training in Buffalo is decent and the people are nice.
cons:
Senior management continues to move jobs from NYC to Buffalo to save money. This is a good thing if you live in Buffalo. This is bad if you live in NYC. 
The pay is low. Generally people don't receive raises and if they do it's usually only $300 to $700 more a year. Which is fine but starting pay is normally between 28,000 and 32,000 for entry level jobs. 
There is a running joke that anyone can be an AVP at Citi. They'll give you the title but no money. 
Managers are mixed bag. Some are really good but many are terrible. There are times where a manager will mess up and just throw one of their employees under the bus. 
Benefits are terrible. Health insurance is basically a high deductible or a high deductible. 
You never get to take all of your vacation. There is always a reason for why you can't take off.
Groups are run bare bones. Some departments have a 2 for 1 policy. Your team has to lose 2 people to hire 1 person. Which in itself is awful but then office politics come into play and your 1 might be given to someone else.

pros: Pros- Benefits are good for Tucson. Work environment is good for Tucson. Fellow employees are great to work with, good people.
cons: Cons- this site location has limited upside mobility for employees.

review_title: Ok place to start, nothing more
job_title: Product Control Analyst in Tucson, AZ
pros: Generous PTO, decent benefits, good place to gain experience in the industry, ability to work from home
cons: The training is laughable at best and non existent in most cases. The Buffalo office is used for cheap labor from the local universities and nothing more. Do not accept a position here if you're looking for a long term career or have previous experience as it doesn't matter. You will not get rewarded for your hard work with practically no opportunity to move up (within your first 3 years) and no salary increases as well. Don't let the big name or the recruiter talk you into it unless you need to get your foot in the door and have no other options.

review_title: Like the titanic it is taking a long time but eventually it will sink
pros: If you work in Cybersecurity then this is the place to be.
cons: Where to start. All top management worries about is the bottom line, cost cutting and squeezing you as hard as they can. Clueless as it relates to building top line growth. When asked about monetizing their IT prowess the answer is "we want to remain a bank. I wonder if the buggy whip executives said we want to remain the pre-eminent buggy whip provider. Bonuses non existent unless you work on the revenue side or are an MD. Once you get hired be happy with the salary you negotiated as that is what you will have for a LONG time. Raises are sparse and sadly pathetic- in the 1% range. They used to have a great program where you could earn a masters in IT from Stevens in Newark but cost savings made it go away. If you are contemplating joining this place, consider this -the most talented Citi people are alumni like I - the talent drain is unrelenting so you will not have anyone of any value to mentor you nor make you grow - do yourself a favor -  look elsewhere -there are better places to work than Citi.

review_title: Full of learning resources and opportunities for everyone
job_title: Senior Data Quality Analyst in Tampa, FL
pros:
Citi is a great company to work for if you play your cards right, they support work-life balance and provide excellent benefits. The internal website is full of useful information about the company and other educational topics that you should take advantage of.

It's size makes it easy to get 'lost' in the shuffle, if you don't find a way to stay relevant then you will get eaten. They make sure they get their money's worth with the salaries they give their employees, even though it might look like a relaxing environment, people are always expected to deliver. Performance reviews are always thorough.
cons: Performance measurement can be subjective in relationship driven roles, a bad review from one manager early in your career can be almost impossible to recover from.

pros: The benefits are amazing, and if you work hard and receive favorable employee ratings, they will move heaven and earth to work with you on a work life balance.
cons: The leadership is spotty.  Unit managers have considerable autonomy over their employees and work group which has many pros and cons.  My biggest complaint was in advancement.  In 16 years, I never was clear on what goes into advancement decisions.  Honestly my direct supervisors were equally clueless.  They would mentor me and other employees for weeks on their own time only to watch as we weren't granted interviews.  It is not unusual to see a 20 year old on his or her first job obtain a supervisory position while people who had degrees and years of experience in similar roles at other companies never be considered.  And the corporate culture is obsessed with change.  If something works, it will be replaced by a new process with limited testing.

pros: Great experience and great training.
cons: It is hard to use Vacation days and will scorned by your VP if you take them because they feel you do not yet deserve them. Hours are tough and it is hard to have a life outside of the office but that's the nature of investment banking.  Working from home is also frowned on by the senior bankers so expect to be in the office at least 12 hours a day, 6 days a week.

job_title: Inbound Customer Service Representative in Florence, KY
pros: Offers some pretty good benefits (Medical, dental, etc) and pay I believe is fair. Has some extra groups you can get involved in. Pretty good people around you co worker wise, not manager wise. I did make a lot of friends there. Security on site, pretty relaxed dress code.
cons: Managers can be unfair and can do a lot of things against policy. Very harsh when beginning. Not the best food in cafeteria. Training will tell you one thing when it's really another. Force you to go to "town hall meetings" on your break, or you don't go at all. Horrible shifts for starters (mine was 11:30-10 my entire time) When you bring up ideas for the groups you can join, I did a red friday for military idea, it was never brought up. But when I left they basically stole my idea and went on with it.

review_title: It can be OK for some but be prepared...
pros:
Pay is alright, bonuses can be good sometimes.
Training is good in theory
Benefits are great
cons:
They have a bonus structure right along with a structure to make you lose it.
It got really hard to admit I worked there due to some of the policy changes in regards to client accounts, fees, and finance charges.
Expect to have a revolving door for management, along with their expectations of you.
They didn't even have enough cubicles with working computers for you to find one with your assigned team and they still kept on hiring more people. It became impossible to find a computer that worked on some days. Having to explain to my manager why I clocked in late got old, he had no idea how to even do the job he was managing either.

pros:
Great benefits.  Helped in getting a nice rate with mortgage.  Nice 401k Match.  
The possibilities are there to learn and get training.  Some areas even make it easy to get Certifications.
cons:
Easy to get lost in the crowd.
Tech side seems to have a lot of disconnects.  Silos still exist with little communication between them unless forced.
Although the training possibility is there, some areas are squeezed so much that there isn't time to take advantage of them.
After hours support becomes "expected" of Salaried employees with no comp time to balance out.

review_title: Company run into the ground *life of a teller
pros: Great coworkers and enjoyed getting to know customers on a frequent basis. Great benefit package with perks.
cons: Too many to even list... Key driver score drove the honest hard working employees out the door- if you get a 0-8 you fail, what kind of crap is that. And it determines your bonus (could definitely tell when the bank started to sink when they implemented that.) Unrealistic sales goals, they were not based out of your branch but out of the entire area so one branch in a highly populated area could sell 7 credit cards a day, while another branch would only see half the amount of customers and struggle to get 1 but were expected to reach the same numbers. Management got lots of pressure from overhead which fell down on everyone else. And its next to impossible to get promoted, you have to stay well above the goals area directors set, plus perfect key driver for 3 months plus..Overall I would never recommend working here.

review_title: CPB Global Technology - full of "lifers" and "yellers" at the senior levels making it a tense environment
pros:
Face-paced, high pressure org with a lot of solid people working here.
CTO is bright, driven and steers a very tight ship.
Most members of the Senior Mgt team are quality people with the best of intentions.
cons:
Org is extremely hierarchical (although, you'll be told its a flat).
Senior Management expectations are generally not with reality.
Many at mgt level are Citi "lifers" with a narrow view of the outside working world.
Many at SVP & Director level manage through intimidation & bullying and CTO is either clueless or supports it.  Little in the way of stewardship or respect for the individual.
Org is often powerless to the will and diction of umbrella tech org, ICG Technology.
As a result of all this, culture is terrible and morale often very low.  Several attempts to improve have failed over the past few years.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Boise, ID
pros: Very clean work environment. Contests for employees on a daily basis with decent prizes like Ipads, etc. Generous in giving out reward points as kudos for "jobs well done" that could be redeemed at the Citibank website for almost anything you please.
cons: Very stressful environment. Offer rate and sales are of utmost importance, the quoted numbers must be met everyday, without averaging monthly. Transfers and upset clients who cannot be offered a product to, counts against your performance. Offers & successful sales also get a lot of scrutiny through compliance guidelines. You are expected to "produce" by being pushy and extremely aggressive. I'm a little puzzled by how they don't require a TSR (Telemarketing Sales Rule - permission to bring up a fee based product in a call) before offering a product to a client. Extremely high turnover rate and very demanding when it comes to sales production accompanied by demotivating incentives.

review_title: World Leading Company, great place to work, but.....
pros: Good strong company, known worldwide for its leadership in the financial industry.   Great technical opportunities, as long as you are willing to work extremely hard.  Citi is on it’s way to being a global leader with all aspects of IT and I am proud to be a part of that.
cons: IF you are not working harder than everyone else, your job is in jeopardy!  Citi is always cutting costs and laying people off, while executives are getting huge bonuses and salaries!  Every single year, they are cutting benefits for the worse, to save more money.

review_title: Citi is a wonderful brand that is being completely mismanaged
pros: If you are interested in global companies, Citi is very global and there are many jobs where you will have the opportunity to interact with colleagues overseas.  And the people are by and large quite smart.
cons: Senior management (as of 2009, at any rate) were a bunch of chickens.  When there were headcount reductions, it was never the most senior executives, it was always a few levels below.  That way they didn't have to face the pain of firing someone they know, they just made their underlings do it.  And they didn't have much rhyme or reason to the cut backs.  They would also fund departments without requiring other groups to work with them. If the other groups decided not to, then the newly funded group was out in the cold - but management didn't care if their investment was wasted.  Again, they lacked the courage, foresight and vision to be forceful about driving change.  No wonder Citi is mired in craziness!

pros: Flexible hours. Frequent breaks. Awesome managers who really care. Great benefits. Company cares for its employees. Cross-training is encouraged. 3 shifts
cons: Not a lot of mobility within the embossing department due to being a small department. When one wants to move around.

review_title: Great Company Overall but Useless HR policies and procedure
pros: Fun and Friendly coworkers who are willing to help you and treat you as family. Open opportunities for advancement provided your willing to work hard and show the numbers. Exceptional  Customer service is a huge priority. Banking hours wasn’t too bad at all, had weekends off which was great.
cons: Micromanagement, you have your mangers constantly monitoring you which can be very distracting and annoying. The company will make you pay back any unearned PTO you use after you separate from the company. Just to sound this warning to others cos I learned the hard way, your health and other benefits terminate immediately upon separating from the company. Matter of fact my medical insurance was canceled retroactively so I ended up having to pay a bill the insurance had already paid after I left

pros:
• Good emphasis on gender and ethnic diversity in tech 
• Very good benefits
• People are mostly nice and pretty relaxed
• Work is easy 
• Work-life balance can be great
• Compensation is okay
cons:
• Mind-numbing, uninteresting work
• Work-life balance can be awful, with long hours and meetings at odd times of night
• TONS of internal propaganda 
• Outdated tech stacks (super old RHEL, Python, Java, etc)
• Very difficult to incorporate tech stack updates
• Very bad developer environment, typically in resource-starved Windows VDIs or Linux VMs with low-level permissions (have to submit a formal request and wait several days just to get a five year old release of Eclipse)
• Never-ending management changes, middle management layoffs, strategy and vision changes, and unclear or extremely superficial goals such as "be the best"
• Job is largely integrating and configuring purchased products 
• Agonizingly slow CI/CD pipeline
• Enormous process overhead; tons of engineering/development time lost to process requirements
• Engineering is not a priority 
• You work for a soul-sucking, unethical, exploitative, and bloated financial institution

review_title: It's a bureaucracy, like working for the government.
job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Ability to work from home.  They hire very experienced people who are smart.
cons:
You actually don't do work at Citi.  All you do is write powerpoint presentations for management that no one does anything productive with.  Its painful.  The processes and systems make being productive very difficult.  New employees threaten the legacy people with different ideas.
The company is so cheap with the employees its embarrassing, but management wastes so much money its scary.  Its amazing that a bank could be so mismanaged.  Senior Management is all about politics & optics.  Too many people have never worked anywhere else so they dont know that there are different ways that work can be done more effectively and efficiently.

review_title: guided, well-paid, honest If i ever need any guidance, i can talk to anyone
job_title: Account Care Specialist in Tucson, AZ
pros: 11/hr base pay with high school diploma, paid vacation and sick time, minimum of 40/hrs a week with as much overtime as i want. thanksgiving and Christmas off with 6 paid floating holidays and 20% weekend differential and double and a half on holidays. Constant potlucks and events to show employee appreciation like holiday celebrations and contests and ordering pizza and snacks for everyone on black Friday. i never get yelled at and i get a paid volunteer day per year. they have wonderful benefits and work with my school schedule. Plenty of opportunities to move up and absolutely no discrimination of any kind. If you get laid off they will pay for your education and give you a nice fat severance package. they will cover up to 3000 a year for education. Wonderful clean and secure facility. My own large desk i can decorate with a big comfy chair and a lock and key for my personal huge cabinet. No, i wasn't paid to write this, i just love my job
cons: training should be more thorough

review_title: Great experience, little incentive to stay
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Work is challenging and there are plenty of opportunities to grow and build experience, Especially in ICG. People are generally good to work with and the company has an excellent work-life balance.
cons:
Citi Is constantly in financial crisis, especially in operations and technology. Citi has an unfortunate culture to pay to lure good talent but once a person has joined the firm offer little to no raises or bonuses. Even with a good rating one can expect to be flat every year unless you make a big stink about it, which in that case they will offer a raise but for undisclosed amount at a undisclosed time. 

Citi is also highly political. Reviews don't really matter. Senior leadership only care about what you did for them to get a good review not the performance of the individual. 

Opportunities for advancement are political as well. Most moves will not result in better pay, promotions have been made much more rigorous but generally are bypassed by people who simple show management a competing job offer.

pros: Company with global brand recognition. Strict compliance requirements that enable you to know they take ethical selling very seriously. If surpass goals there is good room for commission.
cons: Customer service surveys taken very seriously. Bad surveys will affect monthly commission pay outs as well as branch quarterly. External candidates will be paid more than internal most of the time.  Entered company right out of graduating with a Bachelors degree with hopes of developing career with company. Unfortunately if corporate route is what you are seeking don't start out as a branch employee. Very rarely do branch employees transition to corporate roles or other areas outside branch.

pros: Operations is the functional core of our business, clearing, settling and executing more than 525,000 trades and moving billions of dollars every day. Operations people are primary drivers of competitive edge in our markets. If we can do business faster and more efficiently than anyone else, we will get more of it.
cons: Compliance proactively identifies, assesses, reports and mitigates compliance and reputational risks across business lines, products, entities and jurisdictions to the benefit of our franchise, customers and employees.  We use an enterprise-wide compliance risk management approach in partnership with the business and other control functions to drive a strong culture of compliance and control, and promote the principles of responsible finance.  We are committed to providing sound, independent advice and excellence in execution

pros: Work life balance was better than others, although my manager tried to give me hard time using it. Remote access is quite good. "Citibank" name looks good when seen from outsiders. Convenient mass transit (subways) and minutes from NYC.
cons: Managers (SVPs) are mostly clueless yet very aggressive and overly ambitious. They think of their direct reports as second class citizens. No corporation between departments. No information sharing between groups. Managers are mostly enemies each other and sometimes yell at each other in the meetings. People with louder voices and thick faces usually get promotion, so it's a war zone here. It's common practice to steal others' work and senior managers do not care as long as their people look like working hard. Everybody thinks everyone else is idiots. Very stressful work environment. Good work leads to lot more work and no vacation. While on vacation abroad, my manager kept calling me for trivial issues multiple times. If candidates seem smart and ambitious, they usually don't get hired. Managers are mostly not intelligent so some smart people do get hired but they usually leave in a year. Worst place ever to work.

pros:
Global presence with great synergies
Brand reputation
Being a reputable technology bank
Good in innovations 
Employees engagement in place
Having belief in internal mobility 
Plenty of career opportunities worldwide
Fast-paced culture 
Remuneration set based on market standard 
Promotion of work-life balance
Having exposure to dealing with other internal stakeholders within Citi
Prompt and great customer service 
Client-focused
cons: There might be things that are very automated, hence you may not have good insights about them.

pros: Good reputation, Good salary for fresh graduate, night shift allowance, staff loan, extra allowance on Weekend/Gazetted Holiday. That's all!!
cons:
- Work like a slave here, long working hour (up to 12-14 hour/day) even for night shift.
- Salary, Bonus & Increment (even though asking for estimation) are myth due to confidential. So you wont know how far you can go in your career development.  
- 17 days annual leaves, but after deduction of 10 days consecutive mandatory leaves (which you are forced to take), then you will only left 7 days of actual annual leave. 
- Bad management, they tend to focus on productivity rather than employees' welfare.
- I understand that compliance job nature are repetitive but  sometimes I think their SOP are somehow TOO RIGID!!
- The workload is already very high but we are still forced to do online training and evaluation which are not very useful (will be penalized if we are not do so). 
- Slow career progress (repetitive).

review_title: Good experience but some things are very slow, too much politics and people are not always rewarded for their effort
pros: You can get some good experience working for this big, global company depending on the business/group your work with. There are some very smart people so you can learn a lot if you care. You need to be open and flexible, you can move around within the company looking for your right place to be.
cons: Too much politics, too much red tape, certain things are very, very slow. Career advancement is limited if you do not have good connections with the right people, being excellent at what you do is not enough, you have to play the politics game all the time. There is too much politics, too many managers, PMOs, management reporting, boring meetings. It all takes too much time and this time is wasted. Sometimes they play it too safe here. And still I often do not see good people being rewarded as they should.

job_title: Financial Center Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Freedom to provide client service as needs arose in  difficult situations.  I was always supported on a customer level. 
Total compensation was excellent.
Exceptional financial center location and environment.
cons:
Long hours as a financial center manager.
Large disconnect between what is expected in the role of a Financial Center Manager in managing
branch staff vs. what actually takes place. 
Although always polite on the surface, there is constantly an underlying fear of making the slightest error. 
   There is no relief from the fear.  
As a manager, one can feel extremely alone.

pros: Very large and complex organization with vast areas of work oppertunities; Excellent organization to learn & get hands-on experience in different areas of banking business; Open atmosphere - employees can work freely and express opinions.
cons: Too large to manage efficiently; Less than 20% of work force delivers more than 80% of  deliverable; Too big to manage quality performance management and correct normalization of compensations;  High bureaucratic process.

pros:
1. one gets to learn new things which may help him/her in the future
2. re-location opportunities: if u want to re-locate due to some personal reasons, Citi considers that
3.Job movement (internal Transfer): after 2 years at one position u can freely move to any other (considering your eligibility).
4. Teams: we have an amazing fun loving team in Hyderabad, who loves to giggle and laugh all day which tends to minimize the day to day pressure
5. If erroneously you have made any mistake and if the bank needs to bear the charges, don't work they won't cut your pockets
cons:
1. Slow Growth: you may stuck in the same profile for min. 2 years. Don't think of promotion before that no matter how much you've done the work.
2. Timing issues: there is no work life balance. there were times that girls use to go home by 11 in the night
3. pathetic appraisals: don't think of high appraisals. you cannot expect more than 10 % even if you have 1 rating.

job_title: Call Center Customer Service Representative in Caldwell, ID
pros: They tried to make a good place to work,  nice clean building, some nice people that works there, they like to show their people that been there a long time
cons: Low pay, call center environment, where everything is on a timer, calls, bathroom breaks, lunch and breaks are on a schedule, metics for measuring your performance is base on feedback from upset customers, even if it not your fault, like customers is upset because they can not pay their bill, if they leave a bad review, then it counts on you, they try to say it even out, but it does not. Most of problems is cause by the company that issue the card, rep does get the correct information, and they give out false and misleading info to the customer in order to issue a credit card

review_title: Great People, Not so great comp.
job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY

Citi is a nice place for people to work at. People are friendly and share ideas and inforamtion readily. The calibre of people is not the greatest but folks make up for it by being helpful. 
Bosses are smart
People are firendly
Hours are long but not insane
Ability to move between businesses and globally
Stable company in these uncertain markets
Growth opportunities are available and so is the ability to learn other businesses
Very diverse - is truly a color and gender blind organization
Overall great place with nice people

Low compensation
Really mediocre benfits
Infrastructure is fragmented and this leads to a lot of difficulty in identifying root causes of issues and problems. THere is a lot of rework in the capital markets side and this leads to breaks and costs.

review_title: Citimortgage can grow through acquisition but does not know how to run a business!!!
job_title: Finance Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Citimortgage is a great place to work if you are only interested in collecting a paycheck and not learning any new skill sets. It is particulary nice if you are only interested in a 9 to 5 so that you can rush home to family. They are very flexible with time off.
cons: The downsides are significant for a person really career oriented. Senior management is very light in experience and skill sets that they can pass down to employees who want to build a career. I had to go out of my department to learn the business and only learned new skills with the help of peers on the same level and our third party vendors I interacted with. There is no mentorship mentallity due to the fact that most middle managers do not want to be outperformed or tip the hat on how little they truly know.

review_title: Stable work for old people only
job_title: Unix Systems Administrator in Warsaw, Masovia
pros: good salary, stable work, training, some additional bonuses
cons: no new technologies in use, lots of processes, slow changes, long hours, no work-life balance - additional work over the weekends and during the nights, unclear progression ("wait for your turn")

job_title: Citigold Relationship Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Great compensation pkg & benefits. Citigold is a great program & they fund it very well. You're given a quarterly budget to host client dinners/events. Highly entrepreneurial in that you own your book of business. How u choose to cultivate relationships w/your clients is entirely up to you. Love that about the company.
cons: Don't expect much help from management here. They only tell u what to do & offer no coaching/mentorship. Sales culture is expected. But lack of a more fluid comp plan that encourages partnership btwn branch staff & CRMs makes for unnecessary competition w/the very folks that u need to be referring to u. Also technology SUCKS. As big of a company they are you'd expect a lot better. They still run on Windows 7 & still file paper signature cards in the branches like its 1985...RIDICULOUS.

review_title: Good advancement potential, poor compensation policies
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Buffalo, NY
pros: There is unlimited advancement potential in a company this large. With offices all over the world, once you have gained a little experience within the company, you can apply to transfer pretty much anywhere you might want to live. Citigroup also pays a portion of education expenses and promotes internal education courses.
cons: Compensation and benefits are low compared with smaller companies I have worked for. Human resources is very unhelpful, and promotions often come with little or no pay increase. A good portion of pay for exempt employees is variable (bonus based), so if the company has had a bad year, you may end up making less than the prior year in any given year. Base salaries are relatively low, and you will often see only a 1 to 3 percent pay increase each year, regardless of a change in job title or addition of new responsibilities.

review_title: I love being an employee, but it's a popularity contest to get promoted.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Hagerstown, MD
pros:
Pay. 
Commission is good as long as you stay compliant. 
Direct management is very understanding of situations and issues at work.
Positive impact on the community. 
Happy attitudes throughout bank.
cons:
You have to be "loved" by upper management in order to be chosen for promotions or new advancement opportunities. 
Seen many people with high skill sets who were disregarded completely because they were not extroverted. 
High turnover rate due to rigorously strict schedule and adherence to phones. Offline is often cancelled, resulting in weeks on end of non-stop call taking. Many reps get burned out quickly.
Due to high turnover, they pay new reps fairly better than existing reps just to keep them, raises are not as common as you'd think in a multi-billion dollar bank.
No schedule flexibility.

job_title: Senior Banking Officer in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: Cream crowd to work with
cons:
Poorly paid
customer service representatives should get more salary as well, they handle all the heat for the seniors.

review_title: Good place to learn and move on.
pros: Great learning opportunity of business. People are hard workers, faithfull to the company, pride of their work and devoted. Technology is good but lagging. Great for getting experience and pain. Career opportunities only for selected willing to relocate. Else you are stock on raises. Good health plan.
cons: Senior management is disconnected from rest of teams. You can't say the truth for will be labeled as negative or not trustworthy. Very low valuation of person, just a resource which can be spared without mercy. Even if yo are correct need to be extremely polite to speak and most likely management won't listen. Upcoming workspace standards are like 1930's factories spaces. High noise levels prevent concentration in complex request. Follow latest fads instead of leading. Too much fear and lack of knowledge of laws and. Ompliance which impacts the product. Innovation is slowly getting behind due to compliance fears. Lack of knowledge of senior management of countries environment. Turning to an elitist customer based but efficiencies are not reals. Would not recommend to son or friend to work here for long.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great people, global organization, various avenues for career paths. I was in a great group with a terrific team and highly intelligent Global Head, this can vary from department to department and location to location from my understanding.
cons: Scaling back on benefits that matter (expensive Medical high co pays/deductibles only covers 80%), aggressive cost cutting in the businesses, hiring freezes, preach meritocracy but not fully executing, lots of chiefs make for heavy workload on the indians. Too much preference is given to the analyst program hires without an equal emphasis to define proper talented non program existing employees for career growth within.

review_title: Big company, work your way around
pros:
Lots of mobility opportunities. Citi really encourages people to cross train and learn other functions as a way of dipping your toes into other waters, so to speak. Of course each department is run differently and each manager has different leadership styles, but with such a huge site and many networking opportunities, you are not doing something right if you aren’t involved in one of the many networking and social groups. This is key to moving ahead in an especially big organization.

Up to a 6% 401K company match, other healthcare discounts through Red Brick

Generally speaking and depending on your area, working remote is not a huge issue.
cons: You can become a number if you don’t speak out and drive your own path. (However, even if your manager is bad there are so many other people to speak to to get direction in your career). The healthcare options are OK. Parking is becoming increasingly a bigger issue due to town of Amherst zoning laws not permitting parking garages.

pros: Pretty good starting salary. Citi has a good brand name and has a great reputation for their employee training program.   Citibank has an international presence and has branches in over 120 countries so it makes it easy and interesting to work with international customers.
cons: Horrible work life balance.  Will work you into the ground between the short staffing in the branches and the "call nights" until 8pm.  After you've been worked until you're completely burnt out, they continuously change goals so it makes it impossible to get a payout.  The bank is doing very poorly in the Boston market which is why they have closed 9 branches, downsized to 1 banker per branch, and wiped out all business development officers. With absolutely no involvement in a saturated banking community such as Boston, how can one ever succeed?  It's really a shame because as a bank Citi does have a lot to offer, but the employees working in the branches are paralyzed by red tape and useless mandatory conference calls 3 times a day that do nothing but waste time when real work could be done.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
I worked for Citi for over 13 years and although there were times where I wasn't happy with certain decisions there are areas which need improvement I do feel that Citi is a good employer.
There is a good work life balance and  I feel that there is a company wide attitude that you should only work core hours if possible!
The people are what make the company and there is a real sense of working together.
Holidays and benefits are very good.
cons:
There is a lack of any structured training. For some people pay is not in line with industry levels.
The HR department is not very good - always felt that rather than wanting to do their job they had the attitude that they were doing you a favour!!!

pros: Plenty of opportunities for overtime, and an on-site cafeteria. If you are patient, you can move to a different department if you do not like the one you are currently in.
cons: If you are a recent grad, beware! Citi loves two kinds of people to employ: New grads to take advantage of and underpay, and professionals who have already had years of experience under their belt and have a Master's to compensate nicely. Unfortunately, I fell into the first category. If you apply to an "Operational Analyst role," you may be thrown into a bad department, and overworked there to fix mistakes from previous employees who have long left the company. Incentives and promotions as an associate (entry level) are minimum to non-existent. The older Co-workers who have seniority in the company do minimal work, while you may be given their work if they are deemed to "not" be able to do it.

review_title: This is a heaven for people who want to learn financial markets.
job_title: Vice President in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
Work/life balance
Good benefits (onsite amenities could be better)
Relatively fast moving
Diverse
Great locations/buildings (388 Greenwich in NYC looks awesome inside/out)
cons: The technology is behind. The CTO/CIO needs to embrace new technology fast. They should provide super fast development machines, access to cutting edge technology trainings and drive the business to adopt new technology. The user interface of most applications are outdated. They really need to spend money on how customers are using their applications and change the UI design of every single application.

review_title: Good, stable place to work with good benefits, large company with too many chefs.
job_title: Director, Product Management in New York, NY
pros: Diverse role and location opportunities, competitive compensation. You can be very successful if you are politically savvy and can devote time to running unofficial PR campaigns for your initiatives.
cons: A very large organization with too many decision makers.  Brilliant ideas are often dulled by incorporating too many decision makers or influencers.  Mid level managers are very competitive, and often politically motivated. People who do great work but keep their heads down are not rewarded organizationally.  The organization does not do a good job of shedding sub-par performers or people who are not a good fit for their role.

review_title: Good place for BFSI Analytics professionals, Growth is team dependent
pros:
1. Open culture
2. WFH
3. More leaves as compared to other firms, 20 public holidays+ 30 PL + Unlimited Sick leave
cons:
1. Bureaucracy- your rating is dependent on your relationship with manager and US stakeholders
2. No onsite opportunities unless you want to move to US based on management's recommendations. Every year 2 of 80 people get such chance
3. Some people managers go against HR policy and put cap leaves and WFH. Quite unprofessional and unethical practices based on need
4. LAST BUT NOT THE LEAST: Every team does not get modeling work. Digital teams get best modeling work as compared to teams like phone channel has manual excel works. In case of manual works, one has to follow US stakeholder as well as manager's instructions on unproductive works and make them happy by doing hard work

review_title: Citibank Human Resources Group needs urgent reform
job_title: AML Compliance Analyst in Tampa, FL
pros: Great work life balance and great pay and benefits much better than competition
cons: Citibank Human Resources unit needs reform especially in Tampa Florida.   Most hirees for the higher roles are given to  friends who do not have the experience required for the jobs or who lie on their Resume to be hired.   HR reps are of Spanish decent and they hire only Spanish decent.   Working on the job I have seen this personally.  Additionally I saw one employee who was hired for a job but was hardly ever there or available.   Again because of the hiring of friends individuals do what they want on the job while real hardworking individuals abide  by the rules..

review_title: Only good for experience, nothing else
job_title: S&D Settlement Analyst in Kuala Lumpur
pros:
1. employee engagement activities
2. employee's benefits
cons:
1. favoritism. doesn't matter how hard you work, you won't be able to get a career growth. if so, min would be 3 to 5 years until your next promotion. but as for certain people, 3 months or less than a year is enough to get them promoted. 
2. there's no work-life balance. doesnt matter if you have done your work for the day but if you go back on time, you would be considered as a slacker. and even if you does work till late at night, that doesnt guarantee you that you'll get a better career growth in the dept.
3. they doesn't care about the high turnover that is happening and would continue to hire contract basis worker to help fill in the gap.
4. top management would conduct a team analysis on the worker in the dept, but nothing would change if the top management itself is the reason for the work stress itself

pros: Pretty diverse culture, opportunities to learn and develop new skills, or move into a different role. Great internal training - they hire great trainers and have really useful curriculum. Enjoyed the people I worked with. From a branch level perspective, the company seemed very organized and communicated with a lot of clarity.
cons: Work week is typically 50-60 hours for branch management. Probably depends on the market/area you're in. We were eternally understaffed, with management having to cover for staff at their home branch as well as other branches in town, but it always accounted for extra hours you had to work, rather than a rearranging of schedules. Would have appreciated better support. Led to burnout. Pay scale did not align with cost of living in my area. Marketing support in our area was also very low, but they ended up pulling out of our area altogether, so in the end, it was clear that our area wasn't a priority and it makes sense that they didn't allocate funds there.
