We definitely tried to make a success of our market! Every area is different.

job_title: Personal Banker in New York, NY
pros: Paid Holidays, great staff and coworkers, good benefits.  Competitive salary
cons: Commission is very difficult to make.  Very Bad training, while the teachers were great.  Not enough time went to training when it came to operations.  Upper management seems to care only about numbers and not its people.  I work in Manhattan, and while my manager is great and the area director is great, management above that only care for numbers.  The job description can "change".  Now we have to telemarketer all the time calling clients and trying to get them to come to the branch.  If there is no sale opportunity with a client and its just a servicing the expectation is to get them out as soon as possible.

review_title: Great experience, challenging on career path / opportunities
pros: I did have the opportunity to contribute to a number of key initiatives that had great exposure and helped drive important things for the team. There were several wonderful opportunities that only came about by working with a Fortune 100 company. The pace of work is fast and invigorating, which provides the opportunity to be exposed to a great deal very quickly.
cons: Inconsistencies in culture and team direction. Team structure and reporting relationships were regularly changed, making it impossible for the annual review process to accurately and justly reward employees. Many leaders reward their prior teams when teams are reorganized, putting people in power who know nothing about the subject over people who are experts in the field.

review_title: OK place to start with little financial incentive to stay
job_title: Senior Applications Development Analyst/Programmer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Started via a graduate programme. This is good as it gives a base group of connections in the company helping you to integrate.
cons:
Progression is based on merit is a myth pedalled. Having started in an academy I had a base group to compare people's progression on. There seemed to be a 25% link to what work they did and 75% to how friendly they were with their manager. This is true of most work places but annoying when it is so glaringly obvious. There was a 50% attrition rate in my department in 2017 as people grew tired of being underpaid and undervalued in comparison to less effective employees who had personal relationships with managers.

There are other employers who pay better locally. Best way to get a pay rise is to leave.

review_title: Great Benefits, Nice Place to Work, but No Advancement
pros:
Great Benefits - Health Insurance is outstanding, 401K still matches at 4%
Interesting Work - You are working on some of the biggest problems in business today
Good Work/Life Balance - At least in my part of the organization anyway (front-end consumer)
Genuinely nice people - Again, can't speak for all the organization (its huge) but I found most people to genuinely nice and helpful
cons:
No Advancement Opportunities - The place has officially died for any sort of advancement opportunity
Schizophrenic Personality - The organization may decide to react one way then completely change its mind in six months
Large Bureaucracy - Lots of COE (Centers of Excellence, more commonly known as functions outside Citi, ie silos) that do not work well together or at all.
Slow to Move - Getting anything done in the organizations takes a Herculean effort most times

review_title: Policies biased towards Mumbai head office. Scarce annual increment
pros: You get to move across profiles but after 3 years (although policy requires minimum 18 months in current role before moving).  HR hardly speaks to you while they draw huge salaries and do just nothing.
cons:
1. Best rating of 1 is mostly retained for Mumbai location.
2. Location allowance is unusually high for Mumbai vs. Real estate rentals for other expensive locations like Bangalore/Pune. In other words, Location allowance is extremely low for Non Mumbai locations.
3. People with average rating get promotion vs people with best rating of 1/2 do not. The former mostly happens to be with Mumbai candidates. The decision makers and the HR sit in Mumbai
4. Hike of 6.5% to best rated employee vs inflation of 9-10%.
5. Inconsistent salary range. People at same level have a variance of 30-50%. Management gives you false promises of salary correction. This however happens only when you show them an offer from competition
6. Old retarded systems kills employee efficiency.

job_title: Informtion Security Administrator in Saint Charles, MO
pros: Office is close to home and located in one location instead of scattered around the community.  Upper management communicates with the staff through town halls.
cons: Currently management is a little one sided.  Shows a lot of favoritism, does not take suggestions well.  Uncertainty of job stability.  Recognition awards are not standard across lines of business.  Benefits used to be high on the list but the retirement policies keep changing and become increasingly more complicated.  Insurance benefits change every year and are getting more difficult to understand.  Starts programs but does not follow through for very long.  Upper management is constantly changing and middle management continues to increase while the working staff is being eliminated causing additional stress on the staff. Departmental projects started but not completed.

pros: Flex place, flex time - I've been working remote now 2 years and management allows me to revise my work hours so I am able to get my kids to their after school activities.  Ability to advance.
cons: Procedures are constantly changing (sometimes on a weekly basis) and busy season is spring thru fall which makes it difficult to take time for family vacations while kids are off in the summer.

pros:
- Given its size, it is great for internal mobility, especially across geographies. There are always opportunities, and there is flexibility in movement, though it may take time.
- Because of the large footprint that Citi has across the globe and across different segments of finance, there will always be ample opportunity to leverage this for the benefit of your business.
- One of the more stable banks. They may pay less, but the job is more secure, culture is not aggressive and competition is not cut-throat.
cons:
- Workforce is very top-heavy; not a lot of young talent around, though they are now trying to change it.
- Very bureaucratic; there is generally a lot of politics involved, and your work alone does not guarantee success. Also, any work takes a long time to get to completion.
- Compared to its competitors, not really at the forefront of innovation and technology.
- Compensation generally lower than competition.

pros: This was a good place to start my career.  I was able to move up several times during my tenure.  The benefits were good and the people were easy to get along with.  When the economy is doing well or the rates are low, this is a great place to work.
cons: Some in management were allowed to "run wild" as long as they produced results and if you got in their way, you were gone.  As mentioned above in the Pros as long as the economy was good or the rates were low, times were great, however once the rates go up and the housing market becomes stagnant, which it tends to do on a regular cycle about every 5-10 years, things go south fast.  There were constant layoffs and this stressed everyone out and productivity tanked.  The systems were ancient as were the processes surrounding them.  Compensation was low when promoted from within and bonuses were low or non-existent.

review_title: Always there if you need to get by
job_title: Credit Operations Specialist in O'Fallon, MO
pros: If you don't burn your bridges, you can always go back if you go through hard times.
cons: Pay is not competitve and they do not take your education and experience into considering.  Most jobs are just that "jobs" and all you need is a high school diploma.  Someone with no experience or education can come in and make the same money.  Management clearly does not know what they are doing.  Change is to be expected in any workplace but pure incompetence is a different story.  You will most likely make lateral moves in this company. Growth is not optimal.  They expect you to engage and pick up more work like train employees and take on team lead duties but they won't pay you more.

review_title: Wish I could work for Citi again!
pros: Lots of autonomy given to employees who prove they are able to handle it, flexible hours, the opportunity to grow with the company and the mobility to move to any of their offices in your region, great work-life balance where you are forced to take 2 weeks off in a row to ensure that you have a good rest throughout the year and are able to come back fresh, great value for thinking outside the box and going above and beyond your assigned tasks, office culture excellent and very young - made lots of friends at Citi, game/rest room to take breaks in, access internet, play games and get a chair massage!
cons: Bonuses given are not the best but that also might be because of the recession, since I worked for a remote manager, it was sometimes difficult to get paperwork or other approvals done locally, salaries are not that great but are considered based on your tasks at work.

review_title: Addicted to reorgs and no appreciation
job_title: Vice President Marketing in New York, NY
pros: Flexible work schedule, generous vacation, benefits & 401k.
cons: I am fine with change and keeping things fresh but this company is constantly reorganizing and as a result it really does little to improve the business & the quality of life for employees.  There have been long periods when there has been lack of leadership in some departments. Depending on your manager, there can be long hours & little appreciation. There was a time when it felt like a family, now it feels like you're just a number.

job_title: Client Service Associate in New York, NY
pros:
-Citi has a lot of people who make this place special
-The large array of products and segments allow Citi to help many people inside and out with their financial needs
cons:
-There are some very manual parts of the business that could be automated
-Compliance does not usually grant any exceptions even if it means clients are caught in the middle of red tape

review_title: Lots of good things to say about Citi
pros:
Many opportunities for training and development - self-paced online, webinars and in-person - plus you can learn a lot from the people around you, depending on your role and team
Also many opportunities to get involved with various employee networks and other activities, particularly if you are located on a Citi campus
Good compensation, PTO and other benefits
cons:
These aren't exactly "cons" but more so "comments": 
As with any big company, there's a lot of variability among businesses/departments and some are definitely better to work for than others
And as with any big company (and many smaller ones), it can be easy to get "lost" if you don't have good management support - again, some managers are much better than others
That said, if you are looking to work for Citi, try to get to know the hiring manager and the department as well as you can before you commit. New staff who figure they'll get a foot in the door anywhere and then make a move are likely to be disappointed or frustrated.

job_title: Personal Banker in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: online banking international exposure, company's culture used to care about employees well being, good incentive plan for bankers
cons: the retail banking side of the company is briging top executives from Wachovia and they are changing the company's culture for worse, cutting benefits, micromanaging every single process in the branches, putting manager to work over 60 hrs a week taking advantage they are salary and not to pay overtime, setting up unrealistic goals and causing a lot of employees turn over. A lot of preassure to sell provide good service without giving enough tools. Upper management is not in liason with staff to better service the customers, is like military type of management, if you don't do what they say the punish you with long calls and intimidation. You get promoted based on who you know and not in what you are bringing to the table.

pros: Good work/life balance, vacation time, benefits in general. Certainly could be better, but could also be a lot worse.
cons:
Do more with less. Then, do more with less. Then, do more with less. All that really happens is less gets done and less quality gets produced. The culture of Citi management is to be vague with goals and professional expectations, so that mid-year or at end of year the managers can arbitrarily decide if you did a good job or not.

I was also a manager for a short time. One of my direct reports did a phenomenal job for their level, but my manager told me that person could not get the rating I believed they deserved. Reason: their rating was too low the year before and it wouldn't look right.

pros: Work from home 4 days a week, sometimes more.   Too bad it's only certain groups.   Always looking at ways to enhance processes and deploy new tech.   22 vacation days.
cons:
Unless you work for one of the businesses don't expect to receive regular bonuses and raises.   For the past few years my IRS refund, 4k or so, has exceeded my raise and bonus combined!

Lots of former coworkers lost their jobs due to cost cutting measures.   Jobs were moved to Budapest or Texas.  People were told they could move to new location at their own expense and take a nice pay cut in the process. 

Employee share of benefits cost continues to rise. 

No pension plan.  Company 401k match capped at 6% but you don't get the match until March of the following year.

review_title: Great benefits, but little opportunity for women or POC in management positions
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, 401k, health, dental, vision etc.  Four weeks of vacation if you are an officer and comp days for any weekend work.  Really great nice people, very little cattiness or cut-throat attitude in the finance area.
cons: Very hard to move up in the ranks if you are a woman.  They have a lot of women working , there, but the management ranks have very few women.  For example, when I left, in my reporting line, there were only 3 women out of 45 persons, and the women were only in the lower ranks.  Also, they do not promote from within and allow tons of external hires for management positions.  Finance is continually being outsourced to lower cost areas so NYC jobs will be scarce in a few years.

review_title: The left hand doesn't speak to right hand.
job_title: Financial Advisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: As a Financial Advisor at CPWM, you truly can help individuals achieve their financial dreams. You impact your clients lives in a big way through providing sound investment advice. Your schedule is flexible. You are the master of your domain. You have the ability to run your own practice according to how you see fit. The bank staff, your business partners serve as the primary source for new client referrals. This stream of incoming referrals is a huge advantage for a new FA to establish or grow a new book of business.
cons: Citigroup is a former Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) company- meaning the company was bailed out during the financial crisis of 2008. Therefore Citi & all of its subsidaries (particularly the investment division, CPWM) is a hollow company with aninefficient infrastructure. The intranet platforms are clunky. The business is not sreamlined & burdened with out of date technology & poor business practices. It takes way too long to do get anything done. No reliable back office support and no company morale.  Middle management is unreliable because they are spread too thin and over worked.

pros: Extremely flexible with hours and they provide SO MUCH vacation and sick time for a position with such little experience required. The benefits are truly amazing.  There is a lot of opportunities for growth in the company, specifically the Florence KY site, but you do have to put the work in to get your name out there. Networking is probably your biggest hurdle when it comes to getting promoted- not just your performance.
cons: It's a very typical corporate structure, so there are a lot of managers and red-tape. It can be frustrating to get anything changed to make your job better. Typically, each layer of management has an open door policy, though. So if something isn't getting done that needs to be, you aren't punished for just going up to the next level to escalate the issue. You just need to use a lot of discretion when doing so.

review_title: CET Pune : Great techie work but lots of politics too
pros:
Cutting edge work
Great ownership/responsibility
Some of the best minds to work with in NJ/NY
Above average salary 
Mobility options
cons:
Too much politics, sometimes higher management is confused what not-to-drive e.g. they can't drive day to day technical affairs and decisions. It better left to techies.
Politics, highly unstable management hierarchy, 
Hasty decisions specially for Pune office by people sitting in NJ e.g. creating local managers without empowering them enough to take decision.
Manager has too much power
Mobility is tough for senior people and above if you don't have the best relation with your current manager.
Salary / Bonus are not too great.
Overall if you are tough material and not bothered too much by management noise it's good place to own and execute some great projects.

pros:
Benefits are great
Benefits start at day 1
cons: Mind numbing job.  Most management has no direction and no lead over their own staff/team.  You rarely see anyone that you directly report to.  Once you're out of training you are pretty much on your own and the only communication you receive is what you're doing wrong.  Not that that is a horrible thing, because you do need to know what you need to correct but it's just not worth the mind numbing job of sitting on a phone for over 7 hours each day talking to people that love to spit venom at you and tell you that they make more money than you do.  Older credit card customers literally HATE Citibank so you'll get used to that speech.  You'll seriously hear the hold music in your nightmares when you sleep.  Training is great but there are a lot of times that you will get misinformed about serious information.  There are also times that you'll annoy trainers by asking questions.

pros:
If you love a politically correct culture, this place is for you!
401k matching up to 6%
Lots of banking/corporate holidays
cons:
There is no room for professional growth unless you have been here for 20 years, and even then - it is sparse. 

Citi does not value young talent or new ideas being brought to the table. Senior managers are at top positions and do no implement change because of enlarged ego's.

Manager literally lied to my face about not being allowed to take a sick day - even though I gave more than a day notice. If you love lying, you will get to the top. Citi does not value hard work or 'change'.

Their CSR is all smoke and mirrors and for the company to look good in the public's eye - but behind close doors, I have met racist, misogynist, and disrespectful individuals.

review_title: OK if you do not want to make a difference
pros: Interesting challenging work, facitilies were very good.  There are some great people to work with in New York City.  Good opportunites to learn, most people are cooperative and respectful.  Most employees and managers are open to answering questions.
cons: Too many systems, access difficult to gain.   Politics, advancement and reviews are not based on performance even though the company claims it is.  Some very unfriendly, uncooperative coworkers who seem more interested in sabataging coworkers rather than focusing on their own work.    Inexperienced line management who hindered work activity and work relationships rather than helping.  Employees with little ambition, experience, interest or proven results are given opportunity due to seniority and politics.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good benefits, including health care, on site medical, gym. The daycare is great and is much cheaper than independent day cares and even other locations in town (same day care company, different employer). There are a lot of positions in my department which are work-from-home, which is a huge plus, and the flexibility is great. Not all departments are like this, of course.
cons: I have been working in the same position since 2006 (when things started going south for Citi). I have lost count of the number of rounds of layoffs I have survived. Lots of restructuring, constant management changes. You never know when the axe is going to fall on your head, as there is no warning or reason for most of these layoffs.

job_title: Operations Associate in New York, NY
pros: If you like working in a very structured environment in the finance field, then Citi is for you. Until the outsourcing of my position, I worked for this company for more than half a century. They have positions in everything from money management, administrative, compliance, charity and community work. They provide flex time and telecommuting in certain departments which works well for those that qualify.
cons: As with many companies this large, you can get lost in the shuffle if you don't fight for what you've earned. Depending on the department, there may be a lot of office politics and you are stuck with who you know and not what you know or give value to. Flex time or telecommuting is offered in the company but mainly for higher up positions instead of all levels.

review_title: Improve your skills and social life but not your career
pros: Opportunity to meet a lot of new people. Good social life and lots of events going on. Central location. Canteen, shop, coffee shop and gym in the building. Well-known global company which is good to have on your resume. Can move around to different teams/departments quite easily.
cons: Too much overtime and not enough staff on certain teams while other teams in same department are fully-staffed and go home on time every day. Favouritism is very evident. Career progression only seems happens for the staff who are outspoken and friends with the managers. Management/supervision and team structure changes too much to see any benefits. Some outdated systems. Social club events seem to get worse every year. I got my first payrise after 5 years and I still left a few months later as I'd had enough of the place.

review_title: They pay you well to keep you there...
pros: They pay well. Nice campus. Very clean. Very corporate. Good benefits.
cons: People in suits with little understanding of the technology they hire out for. Too many urgent fire drills keeping you working longer hours than necessary. Then you find that the fire drill was either brushed aside or defunded. Then on to the next one. You can work here for years under bad management and come out with little to nothing to show for your efforts but your paychecks. Much competition on the SVP level due to .org restructuring so cross your fingers that your bosses are in good with the higher ups.

review_title: A great training ground, but internal complications and extended timelines force out many.
job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Having business in over 100 markets presents legitimate global career opportunities.  There are also pportunities to move across business lines and build a career in whatever manner of one's choosing.  Bright people really strive to make the best of their work, and one is surrounded by earnest, smart thinking.
cons: Citi is heavily matrixed which requires too many stakeholders.  The company stll hasn't effectively capitalized on synergies across product lines to benefit our customers - and it make take years to really accomplish that.  There are not enough O&T resources to get any projects done.

pros: Nice Bank offices, good benefits,semi flexible schedule
cons: The single most disorganized, dysfunctional, poorly managed, archaic software.  They pay no real salary yet expect to mandate that the mortgage consultant man a desk 6 hours a day waiting for a mortgage to come in.  The u/w software approves the loans based on fannie guidelines and Citi manually kicks them out in Underwriting.  The state they have lending programs that they don't have.  The upper management blatantly lie to the mortgage consultant, the bankers, and the borrowers. In 10 years in the mortgage industry Citi mortgage is the single most incomptent lender I have ever encountered.

job_title: KYC Analyst in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Chance for progression at times
cons:
Forced to work long hours (with no overtime pay)
Asked to provide reasons why you cant work overtime if you couldn't work late any nights (after contracted hours)
Stressful environment 
Lack of help from HR 
Bullying 
Treated like a number, rather than a person

After I had raised an internal issue in regards to a Manager providing personal information to others (that the Manager should not have been sharing), including making it public who the Manager wanted to fire and salaries of staff members, I was given a guarantee by HR that they would investigate and get back to me. That Manager is still at Citi and has actually been given more responsibility. HR never responded to me, despite my many attempts to reach out to them in regards to the update I was promised.  Certain Managers are rude to the point of bullying and many people are off on stress leave including Managers. 
My personal opinion is that this is the worst company to work for and I would avoid at all costs.

review_title: Top Tier Banking business environment with talented motivated employees
pros: Cutting Edge Technology, i.e. ATM, Credit Card, 24 hour Client Access by Citiphone, Paperless technology in branch environment, has embraced the digital an will lead the charge to easy access by it's clients, no matter where in the world they may be seeking access from.  This is an aggressive sales environment where top performers are recognized and rewarded.  For clients that  have business contacts, family in India, this is absolutely THE PLACE TO BANK!  This company pays attention to the social network discussions and has plans on moving up in it's JD Power rankings.
cons: The environment is evolving and this has been good for the shareholders, and not so good for some of the employee benefits, staffing levels and some of the fringes that were previously available.

pros: For a call center environment there is a little more freedom than most. Lateral moves are common. Benefits and vacation offerings are excellent. Even layoffs give you considerable post employee pay. Good food at the cafe.
cons: Manager hired from BOA several years ago to lower expenses. Therefore layoffs are constant. Those in my position and others that have managed to keep their position have had their pay go down significantly as the incentive pay was eliminated. Many positions moving to India and Philippines. This causes the moral to be very low. The software programs and systems are atrocious. Sitting and watching blow-ups, site not found or simply watching your cursor/mouse spin is a constant part of your day. Promotions are non-existent. Positions are often posted, then the position is suddenly eliminated. Like other companies you take computer ethics training, but are then verbally encouraged to take the shortest route even if the ethics are questionable.

pros: Learning a lot because Senior Management does not lead by example and just know how to give orders
cons: Everything is politics.  Career advancement depends on who you know and how can that person vouch for you.  All the initiatives (Voice of the Employee, Voice of the Client, Multi-Perspective Feedback, KYC count) are designed to justify Senior Management in giving you (i) a poor bonus, (ii) no promotions (despite the "promote when ready" copycat from JPM), and (iii) tell you that work needs to be done....  So, if people rate management poorly on the Voice of the Employee, they are basically shooting themselves in the foot...  Survey has to be perfect....  A survey!!  Your voice!!  Otherwise, it is used as an excuse to punish the whole team....  Go figure....

review_title: Good Leadership Team, Challenging environment in terms of Size of Company
job_title: Director of Technology in New York, NY
pros: Overall the senior leadership team cares about keeping the firm competitive and cares about the employees and their respective careers. For folks who are good with proactively reaching out and outspoken (Type A personalities) , firm is a great place to learn and expand career.
cons: Challenge is that Citi is so big that the message dilutes and changes by the time it gets down to the organization (game of telephone). Turf wars, personal egos and personal agendas always trump doing the right thing. The sheer size makes it hard for anyone to execute a strategy

review_title: constant changes in policies and procedures
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Jacksonville, FL
pros:
Training, great for a first job,
Just above average pay. Great connections. Sawgrass system easy to learn. Great for an complacent person that doesn't seek advancement
cons:
Management constantly changing, PTO available does not mean you should take it or it could negatively effect your scorecard and regardless of the circumstances if your not meeting metrics (even if because of death in family or Short term disability) your reprimanded for not meeting goal. Micro manage environment. C in Citi stands for change this is true and also Confusion there is no solid structure. Management does not receive the necessary training. Do not care for employees or the time they've worked for
The company to advance. Skill does not matter it's all about who you know. Job duties increase and pay remains the same
Which makes the job not worth the hassle. They say assume positive intent with customers but they don't with the employees.

job_title: Vice President Global Digital Strategy in Long Island City, NY
pros: Excellent pay as a contractor (but horrible pay as a FTE).
cons: Huge, massive company that doesn't care about its employees. If an employee has a positive experience, it's only a result of having a great manager -- but beware, reorganizations happen about every 3 months. There's a lot of cross-hiring as well as attrition, so your team could look radically different from year to year, and even month to month. There are also a lot of processes that are done "just because we've always done it this way" - so be prepared for ridiculous, anti-business wastefulness. Last but not least, nasty politics and backstabbing - and an Ethics team that is busy, but lacks fangs depending upon which executive is involved in whatever ethics violation (e.g., sexual harassment).  Lots and lots of busy work and re-dos, just so much waste.

review_title: Worst employer I have ever worked with ( Citi Toronot Service Centre, in Mississauga, Ontario, Canada)
job_title: I T Applications Dev/Support in Mississauga, ON
pros:
1. On-Site gym/fitness, trainers are very nice and knowledgeable
2. In place food court, taste is good and price is much lower than the market
3. Pay deposited on time, that's the reason I give one star
Nothing else
cons:
1. 0 appreciation, don't expect any appreciation, even recognition is absolutely 0,  2. Just a labor center of New York office;
3.  A lot of over time works and weekend works, even had to work till 2:00AM  
 then came to the office before 9:00AM next day, but the manager just didn't care, and still kept blaming you here and there
4. No document at all, but the manager just expected you know everything over night
5. Your achievements were totally ignored, but your minor mistake would be exaggerated infinitely and would be marked in your manager's mind forever
6. very frequent turn-over, the whole team  totally turned-over in a year except the manager
7. too much more.....

review_title: I love my line of work, just not the people who manage it.  Very disappointed with Citi
job_title: Client Support Associate in New York, NY
pros: Company name recognition. Great place to learn how things are done.  Citi is well known throughout the financial industry
cons: No employee appreciation, slow to get compensation program finalized.  Unclear procedures for servicing clients.  Heavy favortism.  Uneven salary ranges amongst colleague.  NO comission even when fully licensed (it is a process ... 7 months and still waiting).  Inadequate staffing.

review_title: Associate with the Corporate & Investment  Bank based primarily in New York City at 388 Greenwich
job_title: Investment Banking Associate in New York, NY
pros: When I started in 1998 the pay was very competitive for investment banking associates.  The caliber of professionals working around you are top shelf. Substantial resources at your disposal to perform your job.  Highest caliber clients.  Truly global universal bank provides geographic flexibility.     Substantial institutional knowledge.   Outstanding training program for those joining at the entry level.  Extremely interesting work.
cons: During my tenure managers were not good at managing subordinates.  Extremely long hours.  Working as a banker with Citi as an I banker was a life style decision.  Break down of compensation causes employees to assume substantial risk for the year.  Its up or out and very competitive.  Can be a political mine field to stay at firm.

review_title: A good job, but not without flaws.
pros: Good 401k,  Dental, and Vision plans, decent incentive structures, professional atmosphere. Volunteer work and community giving is encouraged by business. Paid volunteer day.  CEO seems intelligent and driven. Will train even with no mortgage experience. Pays well for the area. Quarterly town halls and other VOE events.
cons: Health insurance benefit is very expensive for such a high deductible. Different centers and Business units handle process differently, lack of unity and direction. Unnecessary layoff/site closings makes job difficult for those left. Very little room for advancement, unless you 'know somebody'. Not a teamwork driven atmosphere, feels more like a competition between other teams and agents. upper management very rarely visits, causing an overall feel of being disconnected. Not very innovative and very bureaucratic in helping customers.

review_title: Don't work in TTS (Treasury and Trade Solutions)
pros: Decent work hours, people are reasonable and the job is not as life-sucking as others in the ICG (Markets, Banking). If you are really really good, you may be able to move internationally. If you work in a good product like Trade, you will learn a lot, otherwise prepare to be bored and get treated like a second class citizen (compared to the rest of ICG).
cons: Very low pay scale compared to other ICG businesses, especially when you compare our margins to those businesses. No space for personal development...the work is very boring...almost Admin work. The tech systems are a complete mess...you will spend a lot of time fixing things rather than building new systems/innovating.

pros: The Benefits are great.
cons: The pay is pathetic, they don't care to keep the employees they have because they know they can find someone to warm the set and they will pay them less.  You are not encouraged to be creative and when you are you will not get any credit, it goes to your manager and your manager will not acknowledge you.  The job description changes monthly if not daily.  You will never be kept in the loop of the recent change and you will be reprimanded for not doing it correctly.  You will never be respected or thought of in any positive manor and that goes for entry level all the way up to upper management.  Be prepared to always be wrong, finger pointing occurs often.  The list of Cons can go on and on.  I would not tell my friends of job openings unless they are desperate for work.

review_title: Good, if you can handle politics
job_title: Management Associate in O Fallon, MO
pros: Just the pay, the people were good to each other, teams functioned well and deals got closed on time so bonus was made every month
cons: Once you take away a bonus you Take away morale, competition and drive. They ripped bonus away from hard working team players and I'm sure they are loosing a lot of top producing employees to ever bank.

review_title: Very sales oriented and very corporate. That said, great job for a college student
pros:
-They really worked around my hours and have some pretty excellent perks like college tuition reimbursement.
-Lots of holidays are off (with pay)
-Decent money for a pretty straightforward job
-Quarterly commission bonuses depending on sales (2010-2011, not sure now)
cons:
-Very sales oriented with monthly sales charts (checking, savings, credit cards, mortgage referrals, etc.,.) I did not expect this when I was hired. My branch was fairly slow so I wasn't too pressured, however, I heard it was much more competitive at others
-When I worked there, the products weren't very competitive with other banks, so you had to do some sweet talking
-Knowledge that you're working for a bad bank

The only kind of people who really rise up in retail banking are somewhat delusional about the goodness they're bringing to the world. These were the senior managers, and thus, the kind of insufferable people you'll have to deal with. That said, the money was good, the customers were friendly, and the job was straightforward.

review_title: Bad place to work in IT
pros: Allowed to work from home, a few good people still remain.
cons: Almost everything else.  The bureaucracy is incredible, it takes forever for anyone to make decisions and get anything implemented. Everything in IT comes down to cost - they are only interested in doing it as cheap as possible, no interest in retaining high quality staff.  If you in India and cheap you will keep your job, everyone else expects to get made redundant in time. Although the very senior managers seem to have a reasonable idea what they are doing, there are many layers of managers who are incompetent.  Doing well here has little to do with what you deliver, much more about who is your manager and how they choose to look after their staff.

job_title: Financial Service Associate in San Antonio, TX
pros: Casual and predominately professional management and fellow associates. Financially strong company that treats it's Chloe's as well as one could expect a call center to treat them.   Promotion potential was satisfactory and based on a meritocracy which was a nice change from previous work environments I'd been in.
cons: General call center environments usher in a host of stresses, micro management, and often unattainable performance goals. Call volume was average but would occasionally spikes and remain high for weeks and  sometimes lead to attrition.  Company brand was well known but lacked a stellar reputation and needed customer service refinement, but the company was working to center on a benchmark performance standard.

review_title: Undergoing Seismic Shifts in Business Model. Beware!
job_title: Trading Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Though Citigroup is going through some very significant changes in their business model, the company is still a good place to get your feet wet. Long term we do not know what will happen to the business as the rules are being changed everyday by the government. However, from day one you will be alongside very talented people (in investment banking / securities side at least) and will be dealing with some of the largest money managers, funds etc . Benefits are excellent with 17 vacation days for new employees,paid sick days, personal days, free meals after 6pm, generous 401k matching, tuition reimbursement, and health care.
cons: You spend half your day emailing back and forth regardless of where you work.  This has to do with the immense scope of the company and immense bureaucracy which introduces multitudes of redundant workers, many of whom think they are very important .

pros: Great benefits. They encourage career mobility through lateral movement and seem to have a good work life balance.
cons: Call center environment where training classes are consistent because of high turnover in the first 6 month. Customer service reps don't get paid well and any incentive amounts earned are highly scrutinized by compliance which seems to justify their position by being overly critical of misreading block information such as adding or subtracting an "s" or saying "the" when it wasn't included in the script. The consensus is that you have to work for about two years in a role before being considered for promotional opportunities regardless of your credentials. That generally doesn't matter to the typical 20 something rep in their first professional position but its not great incentive for employee retention of higher skilled employees.

review_title: Send a picture to your friends and family because they will not see you for a while....
pros: Large organization with many different career paths.  Decent benefits.  Flexible work schedules (but only to accommodate all of the nights/weekends/holidays you'll be working).   Depending on your management, they may recognize you for going above and beyond...
cons: Long hours.  Poor middle and senior management.  Very few leaders in the right positions.  Hiring under qualified individuals for critical positions, which leads to additional responsibilities for those with ability.  No understanding of project scoping...  If you loose resources and/or new initiative come on line, managers must convey those circumstances to the customers and reset expectations...  Otherwise, people leave in droves....  Management gets too wrapped up in politics, which causes delays and issues with projects...

review_title: Was a good place to work for, iffy now.
pros: Citi Global Markets Is/was a leading player in all fixed income products. The variety of products and the complexity of theproducts provide opportunities for intellectual and career growth. If you are in a front-line area such as trading, sales or analytical support there is abundant talent and opportunity. The departmental management of the key areas is good.
cons: Citi Global Markets is facing dire business conditions and has a hangover of bad decisions leading up to the creidt crisis. Their pay structure is likely to be revamped down severely due to the government involvement. IF you have a short time horizon and find an opportunity for learning a new product then this might be a good place. If you are looking for long-term career opportunity it looks like a risky proposition.

review_title: I worked for the Las Vegas, NV. office in their mortgage department.
job_title: Mortgage Processor in Las Vegas, NV
pros: The ability to work overtime to meet quotas for bonuses.  The benefits were great, as was the opportunity to transfer to another site.
cons: Promotions were based on sucking up to your manager, not on merit.  Lots of nepotism.  Too many layers of management, where the knowledge and work ethic diminished the further down the management chain the position was.  Extremely political, which often happens in such a large environment (about 1000 employees at this site). This was the third time the company opened this site and closed it down again.  They just can't seem to get it right.

pros:
Huge international reach
Great for career networking
Still a great name on your resume despite being laid low in the financial crisis
On-site medical clinic (at least at 388 Greenwich)
cons:
Size/breadth can be a liability - steady drip of scandals requiring huge settlements/fines, always created some excuse why we couldn't get good bonuses even though the scandals had nothing to do with my business area
Some people pull for the team at Citi, others are only out for themselves
Politics can be tricky, you need to find multiple strong senior backers or you're at risk

review_title: Top heavy salaries and an HR team that is oblivious to employee issues
pros: A far better work culture than what is found at Indian banks. You can progress rapidly if you can manage your supervisors well. The bank is trying to address gender related issues in the workplace positively.
cons: Shameless self promotion is the only yardstick of success. Pay is better than Indian banks but far below other MNC's. Promotion is slow for work horses. Clear hierarchy in the ICG, GCG and O&T businesses. Few opportunities for leadership programs. Crazy cost cutting has resulted in zero perks.  HR, Compliance and Risk functions fiddle around with rules that only apply in Utopian scenarios.

review_title: A great start to your financial services career
pros:
-Work/life balance was great
-Enjoyed the people I worked with
-Easy job
-Clear metrics for how you're evaluated
-Ton of resources working for a global bank
-Looks good on a resume
-Very good benefits
cons:
-Interacting with NYC or departments globally is not always smooth. Lots of conflict and Buffalo is looked down upon
-Extremely hard to move up
-Raises were a joke
-Lack of effective leadership
-Poor culture due to upper management's attitude and overall negativity
-Communication within your own line of business from the top down is not so great
-Ambition is not necessarily rewarded, in fact I found it quite the opposite
-Pay is decent for the area but it's not the best in the area for the industry
-Your manager will determine your experience

pros:
-Great benefits (4 weeks vacation, paid holidays, short term dissability paid at 100%)
-Normal work hours (typically 50 hours a week or so. Generally 8:30 to 6:00)
cons: If you are interested in a highly motivated environment this is not the place for you. There is little room for advancement once you reach the branch manager level. There is no official mentor program. The company attracts employees by saying that there are lots of opportunities due to the globality of the company. However, management will block any possibility of loosing a good employee to another business within the company. As a manger you are not given much opportunity to make decisions. Everything is very cookie cutter. It is my understanding that other areas of the business are not this way but this is what I can say about my experience at Citibank.

review_title: Citigroup Fraud ok for someone just starting out in the work force.
pros:
Citigroup is a very family oriented company, they always have some kind of family activities going on, on the campus site.  And even have a complete daycare that funcions during the day and also a summer program for the kids during the summer.  
They also offer many different work shifts if you are looking for something other than a 8-5 fulltime job.
cons: Some of the downsides where that there was not much room for growth within the fraud department.  And the daycare that they did have was only really available to people that work during the day.  Raises where almost impossible to achieve based on their rating system for the fraud department.

review_title: Okay job if you can't get anything else for the moment.
job_title: QA Tester- Contractor in Cincinnati, OH
pros: The only reason I stayed for few months was because I needed a big company's name on my resume.
cons: I had to sit in a lab with about 40 other people. The manager never came to the lab to ask how we were doing. An another contractor (who was our team lead) only came down at lunch time or 5pm to ask us how many scripts were done. QA is about testing quality of the software, instead they only cared about how many test cases (scripts) were done in a day. The team lead never showed any respect. He used to give us work at lunch time or at 5pm and told us to complete it at the end of the day without paying for overtime. Some of us used to just leave because we never got paid for overtime. It felt like I was working in a call center in India.

review_title: Great Company Culture, Decent Benefits, Positive Atmosphere, Opportunities for Lateral and Vertical Growth
job_title: Transaction Services Representative I in Buffalo, NY
pros:
-The company culture is awesome, they hold a lot of different charity events, competitions, and pot lucks for holidays.
-Very professional atmosphere, everyone is always smiling, bureaucracy exists but not to an extent where it starts to affect your general view of the company (just to maintain order).
-Ability to pretty much get hired on to any of the other departments so long as you have the qualifications and you do well in the interview. They love hiring internally.
cons:
-Sometimes, we had to work overtime during the very busy 3-4 months out of the year in Winter, but I was mostly grateful for those OT opportunities, even though it did cause me to lose some sleep.
-There really wasn't any cons about my experience

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Bright offices, global team, generally friendly people. Social committee is very active locally. Starting pay probably higher than elsewhere. Work life balance very good, opportunity for remote working on a regular basis. Tech is just OKAY for supporting this.
cons: Expensive parking. Performance reviews not transparent and left as an after thought. Pay rise and bonus in first year are laughable. No support for development from management. Management are over worked and very poorly trained leading to high turnover and team morale at an all time low

review_title: Decent benefits and pay, be ready for moody management
pros: The benefits are very good, including a great amount of paid time off and sick days.
cons:
Management on the branch level does not recognize hard work and sacrifice.  They are hypocritical expecting the highest of standards from those under them, while they themselves do not provide the same level of service.  

In addition, there is bias towards those who have made friends with management.  While this is expected to be what is needed to move up the corporate latter, it discourages furthering one's career based on merit, and encourages looking busy and becoming friends with management.

Just to be clear, this behavior is not seen at all levels of management.  The branch manager exudes strong management skills and as a leader raises morale.  I question those that are under him though.

pros: Smith Barney is a place where not only the person you work for, but others around you will help you succeed. Everyone is more than willing to mentor you; take you aside and give you their 'words of wisdom'. I truly enjoyed this experience and am glad I had the chance to work there.
cons: I did not have much work to do, nor was I given many responsibilities. The downside of an internship on the financial side was that I did not have my series 7 license and therefore was not allowed to get into much detail about our clients.

review_title: Not the best place to work
pros:
Ablity in some groups to work from home.
Nice amount of time off--However, you can't use sick time if you know in advance you're going to the hospital or are sick the night before you call off. And, you'll be lucky to take this time as it is a sweatshop mentality. 

Issues may change with the new CEO! But the layers of management under him need to be swept clear!
cons:
Lack of competent management and no real management direction.
Reviews are based on popularity with managers not by productivity or preformance. 
Mangement refuses to listen and has no issue throwing people under the bus if it makes them look like they're on top of things.
There's no training or onboarding, you're toss into the mix and they wait to see if you can swim.
HR is of no help if there are issues.
Health insurance is a bit sub-par for a company this size.

pros: Nice people. Everyone can relate to the same problems. Work environment is nice.
cons:
Constant restructuring and offshoring of roles.  Citi fires people because  the jobs are being offshored. They fire before the resources are hired leaving huge gaps making it impossible to do your job.

Also insurance costs are terrible. Obama care is looking more affordable.  Shame on you.

job_title: One Main Collector in Irving, TX
pros: Great pay. Hi tech systems. Month end team lunches delicious. Cafeteria food was varied and priced well. Shadowing helped build team unity.
cons:
1. Team leads and superiors knew their job but not leading people.
2. Solutions to borrowers favored the company not so much for paying off loan easier.
3. No bidding on schedules. Each team has varied rotating hours.
4. High goals set for late stage loans in collections not realistic. High risk loans with low rate of return. Payments made were low.
5. Verrolli  transfer source of frustration by many. Waste of capital investment. Added more stress to already stressed job.
6. Was told by recruiters and management that the position was soft collections but was opposite. 
7. Extremely high turnover due to workforce quitting or getting fired.

review_title: This is the best company I ever worked at in my 30 years as an administrative professional!
job_title: Bankruptcy Clerk in Foster City, CA
pros: The bonuses, the celebrations. The management had many promotions to encourage us to perform better at our jobs and we were rewarded handsomely with being taken out to lunch and the Christmas parties were unforgettable. I worked there as a temporary employee in the mailroom for the Bankruptcy department in the summer of 1987 and was hired permanently as a bankruptcy clerk in August of 1988. If the department didn't move to Kansas City MO, I would still be working there.
cons: The pay was not that great and the department moved out of state.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Tampa, FL
pros: Good starting salary, but no bonuses after your initial year. Their is little training so you need to come in with experience or not survive.
cons: SDLC has been micro managed for the last 20 years to a point that job that was performed by one person now teams of people driving the cost to multi-millions of dollars. This is not the only company that has build the cost of IT up as this seam to be normal to justify the position of ITIL, PMP and Agile practice. This has threaten the employment of people and using the cost per seat around the globe. I heard 2.75 person in China as apposed to 1 in the US.

pros: spacious environment, good training tools, enjoyed team meetings,
cons: I would be more receptive to coworkers then focusing on the bad, always explain to what you like best about that person and can we make it better, always seek transparency in communication.

pros: Good hours, nice schedule, off weekends, ok benefits, decent pay, nice management and decent coworkers plus the every other friday pay
cons:
Very rude customers, stressful job over all, chances to be short on money and get a write up, always too many changes and is hard to keep up and on top of the stress of making sure your register and paper work is all good at the end if the shift dealing with so many many rude customers make the job worse stressful when you are starting and on top of that the too many things to remember and managers always pressuring to refer loans and credit cards. Just a very stressful job. Takes a lot of strength and will in order to keep the job. Is not for everyone. Everyday before i even walk in makes me feel
Paranoid and nervous about whats new or who the the next extremely rude customer as well as what could impossible be missing today.

review_title: Great place to work, but could be better with a few fixes
pros: large company with a lot of growth potential. I am on the bottem rung right now but i totally believe I can work my way up to a well paying job here. Management seems to respect us. I do get to see actual benefits from my position on the rest of the company. A lot of career mobility once you reach some of the higher levels within the company.
cons: so large of a company that you can get lost amid the people here. A lot of process to get things done.  It is frustrating to see the unneccesary expenses that this company has.

pros: Citi has done very well at providing recognition for hard work.  The abiltiy to work from home on a regular basis is very nice.  Given the size of the organization, there is a large pool of resources to draw upon.  The opportunity to come up with creative solutions to challenges is encouraged.
cons: With any organization, you will always have a certain set of drawbacks.  Citi is no exception.  There will always be some individuals who do not want to do their fair share, and the politics of a group this large is somewhat complex.  However, if you are willing to work hard and know how to stand out from your peers, you will be recognized.

review_title: Re-engineering and re-sizing still underway to become THE Global Bank
job_title: Managing Director in New York, NY
pros:
Global orientation is a managerial priority, and is appropriate for reaching new growth regions and sectors. 

Emerging market focus is appropriate and will become even more important in the future. Inevitable re-prioritizing shifts resources and talent away from North America and Western Europe (including bonuses)

Employees have access to very good benefits package, including possibilities for global mobility.
cons:
Execution lags owing to bureaucratic legacies. 

Upper management retains an investment banker culture (mentality) and has not adequately adapted to commercial banking realities and necessities. Optimizing balance sheets and revenue flows are necessary complex relationship-oriented activities, and do not conform to an "eat what you kill" management culture.

Balkanized fiefdoms continue to hinder achieving management objectives. 

Antiquated technology coupled with myopic mid-management jealousies are major obstacles to Citi's needed transformation.

review_title: A company, as a member, you can't be proud of it
pros:
The company name sound
Employees here are nice
cons:
Lack of respect to employees and company's policy from management team
Managers really act like manager, you will definitely have  the impression that you are “Managed" Pushing, Micro Management ...

review_title: Say what you mean and get it done.
pros: International growth. Citi has the tools to do business internationaly and is not taking advantage of all the resources it has. fewer chiefs and more peope executing and getting things done. Focus on our advantages and use them to grow our busienss. Citi has international clients in US and is not taping into this vast resource. Could grow the company exponencialy
cons: Lack of execution. Management needs to focus on getting things done fixing systems so that they all talk to each other. (Technology speaking) fewer chiefs and more peope executing and getting things done. Focus on our advantages and use them to grow our busienss. Citi has international clients in US and is not taping into this vast resource. Could grow the company exponencialy

pros: Opportunity to acquire knowledge and work on a varied environment. Excellent local teamwork.
cons: Too centralized and very unflexible place. Does not supports feedback from employees. Medium management has very little decision making. Top management is focused on short time resources and learns very little from previous experiences. Promotes the "yes-man" culture. Very little thorough analysis is done on many decisions when is idea that is pushed downward. Extremelly use of politics. When a specific regiona makes money the triumphs arfe not shared but when a critical situatiion is encountered lower level employees pay for the incorrect management decision. "Greed is good" is the silent culture of management. "The Citi never sleeps neither does the medium management employees!". No consideration for customer service levels as long as no complany CEO complaints. Employee reviews are manipulated from seniors byspassing the direct managers ratings.

review_title: One thing you won't lack as a manager at Citibank is a challenge.
pros: Worked with some good, devoted people who were trying to make things better, but they were in the minority and it's very tough to retain the best with the salary resrictions from HR.
cons: Outdated systems and outmoded ways of thinking. A lack of trust from senior management down to the individual employee in many cases. A culture that pushes resources and growth to the Citi components where the greatest profits are thought to be, while neglecting many of the more mundane, steady but unspectacular business lines. Predominantly centralized decision making takes empowerment away from all but senior managers.

review_title: What have you done for me lately
pros: Great benefits,great people, great culture
cons: Management changing into micromanaging mode. Employees are definitely only a number, more so than in previous years. Criteria used to measure performanced is flawed, as it does not take into consideration that the tools used have mistakes within them that cause one to manipulate the system to provide compliance to the levels expected.

review_title: A really friendly environment to work in, but not for someone who is looking for a dynamic and fast-paced role
job_title: Cards Analyst in Long Island City, NY
pros: Work/life balance is amazing - hovers around 50 hour work weeks at most, and everyone is very understanding if you need time off. Really nice group of people to work with and everyone is really open to help and mentor new hires.
cons: The pace of work is slow at times, there doesn't seem to be a lot of drive to results as I've seen in other companies. A symptom of the emphasis on work/life balance is that people are not as motivated - you can see if in everything from the dress code of people wearing jeans and sneakers to the pretty low salaries they offer to new hires.

job_title: Research Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Citi is a breathtakingly diverse company in terms of its employees, its businesses, the countries where it operates, and the kinds of products and services it offers.
cons: Citi's HR, which used to be among the strongest in the industry, has been gutted in recent years, which makes it difficult to advance or even to get information about advancement or lateral moves.  Its training has become generic, and successive waves of mergers and layoffs have diluted the culture to such an extent that morale is generally very low and few if anyone there can define what the culture is.  The shareholder-driven orientation means that employees are seen as having little value.  Working here is like walking perpetually on quicksand, as you know your job is likely to end any minute.

review_title: Mixed wet mess of hair wrapped in a broken compass
pros: a way station to a better company
cons:
Some at director level change their minds at a whim without considering all outcomes or long term, make short term goals to fit self serving goals, career or political.  And the senior manager above them are too high up to even see the changing wind impact.  Getting access is a still a pain, years later after senior management promised change.   One could still trying to resolve access issues years in the company.  People who frequently mess up are never punished and allow to  repeat

Not only refusing to pay overtime, HR tries to cap people's salary by maintaining employees are categorized as emergency service to get around legal loop hole.

review_title: Good job to get foot in the door but suspect that you would have a better experience in another bank.
pros: Salaries and benefits are good.
cons: Feel as if this is a sinking ship.  Senior management has not provided a solid vision and inspiration for employees.  Management also seems to not have the skills to lead Citi into current times.   They are more concerned about damage control from the fiscal crisis.  The structure is unwieldy and not efficiently organized with many arms not talking to each other.  The security protocols get in the way of real work at times.  Innovation and leadership are paid lip service and subjective reports are generated to propitiate senior management but the reality is that real innovation and creative thinking are often marginalized.  There is a fear among staff and employees in providing real feedback.

review_title: Its a good job if you are willing to start at the bottom
pros: In my position there is potential for a lot of growth if you good at your job.
cons:
They are not immune from the politics you see in American corporate culture. Is any company really immune though? 
Base pay could be a little more competitive. I took a huge pay cut to come here just to be closer to home. you would think they would have considered my MBA to be of some merit but I feel like I started from the bottom. My base pay is the same as a kid who just graduated from high school and I have been in the work force for more than 15 years.So all in all, education and experience count for nothing.

job_title: Credit Risk Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The best thing there for me was the quality of the people around me. With that said, upper management often was disconnected.  The 401k 6% match with immediate vesting was also very good. Depending on which group you're in, work life balance can be good as well.
cons: Commercial banking is in decline with relocations and outsourcing being performed. Wages also aren't going up. Even with a promotion, you won't get paid more. This isn't a Citibank problem exclusively though, the banking industry is changing. Lots of senior people continue to work there just so that they can hold on to their pension, otherwise, they would've jumped ship already.  There is no longer a pension for junior analysts, so with no retention incentives, there is high turnover.

job_title: Loss Mitigation Specialist in Hagerstown, MD
pros: Some of the best benefits in the area as in vacation and sick time and 401K. Really enjoyed most of the people I worked with. A great number of employees were very dedicated to the company.
cons: Below ave pay, but some benefits made up for a little. Many of the promotions were based on who you know. It appears lately that they have been getting rid of tenured people only to cut costs. Many tenured effected by outsourcing of their jobs are not being hired back for other positions like promised. Citi used to celebrate their long term employees, however now dedicated employees are treated poorly and have no sense of job security like it once was.

review_title: Stay Away - Tough place to survive
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: I would not recommend this company to anyone. I've been with this company 10+ years and have seen it deteriorate to the state of chaos it is still in.  Seven years after the financial crisis the work situation for employees if VERY UNSTABLE.
cons: They will work you to death, suck the life out of you and then lay you off without a second thought as they try to move as any jobs offshore or to low cost centers.  Management is ruthless and treats employees like disposable garbage.  Benefits have been slashed over the past few years and you will pay a big junk of your own medical benefits premiums.  Bonuses are awful.  They haven't even given cost of living increases to most NY staff in YEARS.  Do yourself a huge favor and look elsewhere.

pros: Flexible work from home schedule - 2 days per week.
cons:
Very political environment - mid and annual reviews are handled with Executive, Senior Leaders and Directors assembling in one room to give feedback on hundreds of employees - making it difficult to get noticed if you do not work closely with those around the table providing feedback.  

Although you work hard everyday and long hours with people at lower levels to get the day-to/day job done if you are not working with those influencers then your contributions maybe overlooked.

review_title: FX Operations, pressure and long hours
job_title: FX Operations in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: You learn a lot about Finance and one of the biggest banks on the planet, plenty of different roles available and internal mobility opportunities, potential career progression is attractive, good pension contributions, well organized, helpful line managers, company-wide social events are good fun.
cons: Heavy workload and pressure to complete tasks before deadlines on occasions. In order to save money they are slow to replace staff who leave, so those remaining are left to share the workload and do considerable amounts of unpaid overtime with related additional pressure. 10-11 hours days can be the norm in certain periods of the year, especially in Settlements. High staff turnover, which is both cause and consequence of the long hours and pressure. Salary and bonus aren't better than competitors.

review_title: Merrill Lynch, UBS and other investment firms are losing their Financial Advisors to Smith Barney.
job_title: Financial Advisor in Federal Way, WA
pros: You are compensated for the work you perform.  If you bring in the assets and produce the revenue, you get a share of that and the Company pays the overhead for extensive state-of-the-art platforms and your office.  The benefits package, including retirement options, are the best.
cons: Competition is keen for new clients and finding them in the current market environment can be very difficult.  Also, each branch has a different personality based mostly on the Branch Office Manager (BOM).  So, pick your manager carefully.  Pressure to perform can be intense, whether self-imposed or from management.

review_title: Could definitely pay better but they don't
pros: The work environment involves rigorous training, promotes team work and hard work. Hard work is sometimes promotions. Giving back – community involvement; is a huge part of the work environment and this creates a feeling of being part of something greater than ourselves. It’s a great place to start a career. It is a great place to work if one is looking for work-life balance. A Flexible schedule and great benefits are perhaps the main reasons I stayed with Citi.
cons:
Citi grossly underpays its middle and senior management.  The financial rewards are rarely commensurate with role/industry standards.
Complaints are constantly being mishandled. Anonymous ethics complaints are are not handled anomalously and the whistle lower is targeted after that.

review_title: New Castle DE OPS III is a DISASTER
pros: The Cafeteria has friendly employees.
cons: Where to start. I was lied to in my interview about training and work schedule. I was promised training in my job function, never received any. I was assigned work right away with no information on how to do it and publicly shamed in front of my team when it was incorrect. Interview advised that employees are off before 7pm. Left before 7pm perhaps once a month, constantly worked weekends. 200 analysts in a room without windows, no natural light at all. It was like working underground for 10-12 hours at a time. Supervisors often do not know how to do the work themselves, they just sit back and criticize while their employees drown. The unprofessionalism in interpersonal communication really took me back. I have worked in other financial institutions and never had a supervisor cuss at me like a child before working here. Citi needs to look into this location. It's a very depressing environment to work in and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

review_title: Depends on why you go to work?? For  Paycheque or something a little more?
pros:
Great Benefits
Excellent option for mediocre people who are good at doing nothing
Good for people who strive for work life balance
Good for women who have young kids - lots of excellent work from home options
Excellent training on CYA (cover your @ss)policies and brown nosing
cons:
no regard for hard work or ideas, its all about who you know
no international opportunities
no cross business/functional opportunities
horrible middle-management
no opportunity to grow and expand in your career - its better to quit and come back and they'll hire you for twice the money
disparity between income at the same position

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: It's very difficult to come up with any 'pros'.  Possibly the only advantage to working for Citi is, because of its huge global network, you might have an opportunity to relocate.  However, be prepared to pick up your own moving expenses.  Moving internally is as tough as it would be if you are interviewing from another company.
cons: Citibank has become a white collar sweat shop.  You are expected to work 7 days a week, if necessary, and check in with your boss while on vacation, etc.  Most staff received significant pay cuts in the past few years and management has the nerve to tell staff to be grateful they have jobs.  Massive layoffs every 18 months or so that equates to heavier workloads for those who are left.  No job security, no job recognition.  Only political animals survive.  Lousy benefits for the rank-and-file employee.  The PR this company publishes externally and internally bears no resemblence to reality.  Citi is NOT a great place to work.

review_title: Outdated senior managers should be forced to retire
pros: Citi overall is a great company with CEO Michael Corbat at the helm it seems that there is more accountability and more focus on what matters. They promote alternative work strategies and offer the tools to make your job a lot easier and more efficient
cons: Alternative work strategies although promoted all depends on your manager and there are way too many old school out of touch senior managers that are strongly opposed to it. Very long work hours. There are too many middle to senior managers that are not being managed and show complete disrespect to their employees and their clients. These managers are found everywhere but some departments in citi do not have this issue.

pros: A good place to work just starting out for training all some trainers very good job to have as long as you don't mind the change
cons: So so many changes days you won't know whether you're coming or going as far as your employment status so many stressful situations if you're not a person who handle stress very well this is not the job for you do not go work for this company as you will have a nervous breakdown I've seen it happen with my own eyes so if you're open-minded don't mind changes needed any changes this is a great job for you

pros: relatively high starting salary - can not really add anything else here
cons:
No raise, does not matter how your team is performing
No home office, even though it was globally advertised as the ultimate solution for unused office space
No benefits, even the team socializing events are paid by the employee
Stone age equipment even in the modern office buildings - old,used hardware and user unfiendly tools. massive clickporn just to get something submitted, really frustrating

job_title: Home Owner Support Specialist in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Pretty blunt with current direction. Good cafeteria.
cons:
Current direction constantly changes! 

Accounts change daily. Roles constantly change. Bosses change constantly. I feel sorry for every client I talk to because their SPOC, Single Point Of Contact, changes monthly, sometimes weekly. The systems are atrocious. Having to wait 4 or 5 minutes for the reservation system to reserve the next appointment. Uploading documents that are already in digital format are converted to a format that loses much of the original clarity, so we ask the client for the document again and again. We are getting out of the post sales servicing business and having Cenlar take that role over.  Appointments with clients are cancelled for internal meetings constantly.

I saw another comment about the commission award structure changing; yes that's true. Almost everyone in my role makes less then they did 3 years ago. Of course, there's not that many left in our role as they are being eliminated.

pros:
Policy
Payout
Use to be timing
cons:
India citi technology center is more driven  in very political way. Managers just keep investing time on POC or any activity that help them getting highlighted to upper management. 
People do not bother about business continuity and retaining talent, appreciation of job but buttering and favoritism. 

Now citi is occupied with some tool that track ur machine activity and held against u by local managers. Though it seems confidential on identity but managers call an ye individuals by claiming they know inside info.

U have to aty in office for mentioned time daily... no flexibility now. It used to be good company but since 6 Month all left is politics, favoritism, blame game.

job_title: Home Equity Specialist in O Fallon, MO
pros:
Benefits are fantastic, hands down
Great work/life balance for my position
Remote working opportunities were above average
On site extras like free health clinic and cafeteria were great to have
cons:

Very easy to be siloed into your role and have no way out or any room for career advancement

Company harps on “Power of One” but doesn’t practice what it preaches
