Senior management doesn’t recognize the hard work properly

review_title: Serious need for corporate restructing a slave driving company with Terrible Management
job_title: Risk Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: If you just need to get in quickly to gain some experience to put on your resume
cons: Lack of respect and fairness throughout the company.  Overall culture of the company is terrible.  Pay in alot of areas are below market value. Upper and middle management are poor decision makers, they work off of a Good old boy system, employee are treated like cattle instead of human beings.  They push directives that are not profitable just to show an initial profit and take a loss on the back end.  Some positions which are considered as a promotion but no pay increase.  No matter the position if promoted we only give you 10-15% more than current salary.  Do not care about obtaining further education this will not change pay.

pros: fantastic learning organization that focuses on develping leadership
cons: tonnes of matrix reporting...spiderweb org charts ---makes things slow.

review_title: Don't waist your time and energy
pros: CitiGroup had an interesting call center that has the best facility amongst similar jobs. The benefits package is excellent but  balances out with the low pay rate. The work life balance is great as a competent individual can complete his weekly work load in 40 hours or less. The Schedule is also great if you are fortunate to get a team with a morning schedule. Overall it was fun while it lasted but I could not do it for more. (total stay 1.1yrs)
cons: There is always politics but i have never seen a place that had politics similar to a High School. Not to mention senior management treated everyone below as dumb high school students. I was a top performer for most of my stay there with limited effort. I was always told that performance gets you what you want, however at the end it was more determined on how much ass you can lick by the end of the day. To conclude  i don't lick ass so I am in a better place now :-)

pros: learn a lot of banking business
cons: Managers coming in and out.  Organization structure is too complicated.   Without  proper restructuring,  the organization needs to hire more internal communicators to smooth out operations which make the organization even more complicated.   It is hard to plan for a career in an always changing environment.  No clear business goal and guidelines.    Oral promised incentives sometimes can not be delivered after reaching the target.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Citi is a vast company with many diverse and different people to meet and work with while your are employed by Citi. Working for a larger company like Citi provides security during good financial times in the industry.
cons: When the financial industry starts to encounter tough times, Citi is typically the first to be impacted. Since the crisis, Citi struggled to grow revenues while trying to manage its expense base. Cost cutting and reductions-in-force are quite common during the tougher times in the industry. Citi also strategizes to be middle-of-the-road to average in terms of compensating employees.

pros: The ability to career path and learn many aspects of the industry. The mission and values have meaning and can benefit you if you own them.
cons: The pay structure for internal transfers is not competitive. If you are qualified for the job you should be paid accordingly.

review_title: Stable employment, not the best for ambitious people
pros: Salary is decent. Great benefits. Good work-life balance. Friendly people. Relatively stable employment (depends on the department though). A lot of diferent opportunities. For somebody that looks for a stable employment and doesn't want demanding or stressful job, Citi would be a great company.
cons:
Citi is huge and it suffers from poor management in some areas and bureaucracy. A lot of processes that are vital for the organisation are far from being optimized. Instead they are being constantly patched by different teams and incompetent people.
Don't count on fixing your HR problem easily if it's something more than sick leave or vacation request. 
There are big discrepancies for the same salary grade in different departments.

review_title: Well compensated high stress working environment.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Meridian, ID
pros: The Compensation was good $11 dollars an hour to start with about 3 dollars a sale bringing it to about 17 dollars an hour. Not bad for a kid right out of high school. They were also very encouraging and supportive. The management sincerely tried to make you feel at home. After perfoming my first few months in the top 20 in the nation they offered me a promotion.. After less than 6 months of employment. Very admirable i thought
cons: It was fairly stressful. Sales were so important that it often made me feel sick if i could not meet quotas. Many people leave the sales aspect of the job to just do normal customer service because of the high pressure

review_title: If you rate them negatively on a survey they will retaliate
pros: good health insurance benefits, good parking
cons: Low pay, get beat  out of bonuses, managers throwing reps under the bus to save themselves, had a successful rating based on monthly results then at year end taken away and rerated to unsuccessful and no raise and tuition reimbursement lost.

pros: flexibility in working arrangements, work at home schedules, excellent benefits and vacation
cons: middle management fails to recognize the utterly importance of its analysts. Analysts right now are struggling with excessive work loads and analysts who can't handle it, just walk right out. Initial training for the analysts is severely lacking.

review_title: Poor Management and opportunity and outright corporate misbehavior
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Irving, TX
pros: Good benefits. I hate to say it, but that's about it.
cons: Typically poor management, including severe office politics and under qualified management teams. It would be one thing if people were capable of getting better, but typically management makes the same mistakes over and over. Strategies change very often, with dictates from NY that fail to drive beneficial status, while they refuse to listen to people who know what they are talking about. Management even outright lied in a town hall saying Citigroup had "no significant part in the mortgage security crash" in 2008. Really?

pros: Decent base pay. If you get to a busy branch and figure out how to make the commission work for you, you can make commission. Great place for self learners.
cons:
It's almost impossible to make any commission for the first 6 months. They have these "flavor of the month" products regardless of client needs. We're selling HELOCs. Everyone is getting a HELOC. If they need it or not.
If you got hired because your sales experience and have no prior knowledge of financial products. You're in for a treat. You will get training. With ZERO help on the sales floor. Basically you're to learn the textbook and then just figure it out how to apply it in real life situations. It can be very tough at the beginning. Also the commission structure is made so that you don't ever make any money. You can sell a lot and barely get paid.

review_title: The C definitely stands for Change!
pros: Citi has a strong retail brand in several major US markets and is known worldwide for its financial services. Starting salary was competitive. Very positive work/life balance given that my manager and the team I supported were hundreds of miles away and I could work remotely as desired. I was in CA, not NY where Citi is headquartered.
cons: Constant change at all levels of the organization. The company is still trying to recover from the financial crisis of 2008 and is keeping a close eye on expenses (which makes sense). Constant change means layoffs, changes in management and other concerns to keep you up at night. NY runs the show, which can make it tough for other regions to get their voices heard.

review_title: this will be a useful review if it is read and taken seriously
pros: the way employees are treated for personal time off.  the pay is fair and upper management tries very hard to recognize outstanding employees in very trying times.  there is plenty of diversity within all areas of the company.  there is a lot of room for growth within the company.  you can choose to move all over the country for promotions or lateral movement within citigroup global markets.
cons: communication from upper managment is somtimes too late before there are rumors spreading throughout the company.  changes are often made before going out to the field to get opinions from the employees that these changes will effect in a major way.

pros:

-Time Off scheduling is fair
-Work Schedule is fair

The Supervisors run the department while the Managers over-delegate the Supervisors, and in turn delegate the Associates as if they are Supervisors. review_title: Too many competing interests with no collaboration among people. Not a steady work atmosphere.
job_title: Lead Analyst-Finance in New York, NY
pros: Good Benefits, but can be quite expensive when compared to other employers. Vacation and disability plans are excellent.  The company promotes growth for its employees, but can be hard to get noticed in such a large environment.
cons: Management can be arrogant as some think they know everything. Ego's are pretty big which leads to the arrogance. Some managers from prior mergers lead by "stating the obvious" with no real guidance or solutions.  Promotions are based on who is on the promotion committee that year and who is plugging for you. Too political of an atmosphere. No wonder they almost went under.

review_title: My experience has been challenging, but not rewarding.
pros: For starters, the benefits are ok.  I have accumumulated 4 weeks of vacation time and get paid for all holidays. There is also the ability to work for the company in different locations.  I've worked for the company in 3 different states.   Depending on which state you work in, the opportunity to be promoted is higher.
cons: I can mention a few of the downsides of retail banking.  If you work in the branch, expect a six day work week.   Count on missing your state required 10 minute breaks.  If you want to enjoy and uninterupted hour long lunch, you should leave the building.  The are too many constant interuptions during break times and during working hours.  There are always countless #1 priorities.  So, to excell with this job, will have to master distraction management.

review_title: Meridian, Idaho - Call Center Handling Customer Service for All Credit Products
job_title: I Had Several Jobs in Meridian, ID
pros: There are some excellent and enjoyable people to work with there.  Some of them really believe in doing a great job and their enthusiasm and ethics show.
cons: There have seemed to have been some people placed in positions of authority who have distinct ideas about the demographic segments which will be given opportunities for advancement and if you are not in those groups, you will be passed over, not given as good of raises and given platitudes instead of opportunities.

review_title: The C in Citi Stands for Change
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great benefits (health insurance, sick time, and vacation time from day one, 401K, Gym on site. The bank is re-inventing itself into a digital bank.
cons: Pay is low, but OT is often available at time and a half. Change is constant.  I had 5 managers in 3 years. Policies and procedures change frequently. Heavy turnover in customer service positions. Most don't last a year.  It is extremely difficult to move from an hourly job to a salaried job. There seems to be a giant invisible wall that 90% never get over. Even some really talented people can't make it. Yet Citi claims it is a meritocracy.

review_title: Use CitiBank because they will use you!
job_title: Account Representative III in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Benefits. Compared to other companies in the financial sector they offer good rates for health insurance for POPs, as well as dental and especially vision.
cons: The high turnover rate at Citi Cards in particular make the workplace hard to function due to the poor knowledge of new associates. Weight is put strictly on the ability to meet goals. Most of the jobs are going to India - because it makes good business sense - so don't expect job security. Moreover, the vertical structure at the bank, where managers look-up to senior managers, is a little sickening. This type of vertical structure makes it hard to give proper applauds to employees that offer good work in other areas besides what upper-management seems is the best.

review_title: I would recommend Citibank as an employer.
job_title: Financial Associate in San Antonio, TX
pros: Citibank really does have a very supportive, flexible work environment. The benefits and amenities at the site are really quite nice. Childcare, gym, cafeteria, break rooms, etc all make for a pleasant work environment. The direct management is a great group of people. They will go above and beyond for their employees. The training is extensive and the direct managers will do everything in their power to get advancement opportunities for you. You don't have to work there for 10 years before moving up to another department or getting a promotion. The vacation time alone makes working there worth it. I really do enjoy working for Citi!
cons: The pay scale needs to be adjusted for people that are performing more complex jobs. Based on competitor pay I think Citi is shortchanging it's front line people.

review_title: Rewarding experience but need to be flexible to adapted to senior management turnover.
job_title: Technology Management in New York, NY
pros: Fortune 100 company with a very large global footprint.  A great number of the best and brightest individuals. Strong and stable balance sheet.  Significant financial and human capital to invest in innovative solutions.
cons: The culture tends to be passive/defense where interaction with people is guarded so that  individuals are more concerned with their own sense of job security - don't rock the boat.   The tumultuous nature of the banking industry itself reinforces this culture. Starting with the sub-prime mortgage crisis of 2008, restructuring, outsourcing and workforce reductions are common in the big banks.   At Citigroup, senior management turnover has more frequent than other banks since the 1998 Citicorp and Travelers merger.

review_title: I really expected more... And once I leave... I will sleep again...
pros: Lots of training's, I really had a good team, real players. A big chance to know about many areas of work.
cons: Walls ans walls of bureaucracy. You keep making reports, UAT's and many things that only make happy somebody in other country but at the end you don't understand your contribution to the Corporation and it is nobody interested in making you know it. In almost two years HR has been a "urban legend" in our country.  Everybody feels that in the last years is has been developed a culture that the bank is waiting for you to make a mistake to get fired.

job_title: Personal Banker in San Diego, CA
pros: Hourly Rate is impressive and commission is definitely tangible as well as fruitful. Training was extensive and informative, Not as sales pushy as other Big Banks. Citibank paid for Gas and Hotel because we had to go up to LA. The San Diego District has a summer BBQ cookout. As far as retail banking goes it's not a bad gig.
cons: Internet and server is dreadfully slooooow. You can have a whole conversation with a customer before a webpage can load up for you. Almost everything in the system is outdated and extensive. They take the KYC account opening process to a whole new level which you have to do manually. And so much paperwork for every customer, never ending. Bankers take the role of operations and sales in the Citibank role. Where as some other banks only have you worry about the sales side.

review_title: Reviews based on other departments performance
pros: benefits you will need them with the amount of work related stree that you will have
cons: Sales your performance will be based on others departments performance. Closings are based on processing and underwrtiting where it has been  backed up since day one and years later nothing changed.  But performance is based on your closing numbers and pull through. These are not in your control but is part of your perfomance. If you are a top producer who works off site you will to well. But if your average prepare for many poor reviews because your numbers are compared to those who do have the same working enviroment as yourself. They do hire often because most choose to leave as soon as possible. It is tough to make good money there.

review_title: challenging environment - no meriticracy - lots of empire building
job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros: work life balance is respected.  diversity is the norm .... salary is competitive... telecommuting is accepted....lateral job movement is encouraged... big enough to let you move around
cons: too much turn over - older employees with high salaries are shown the door and replaced with younger cheaper resources who believe they are entitled to their position.  some of senior management coomse from non-financial background and hires more non financial managers to create a culture of ignorance about banking.  Big bureaucratic environment where no one is ever responsible or accountable for anything.... many think that is a positive!!!

job_title: Senior Vice President in Long Island City, NY
pros: The company is big and does hire back ex employees. They have best practices that you learn and take with you to other companies. The people are smart and I have met a few friends that I still keep in touch with.
cons: Of the 4 managers I had in 4 years 3 of them were mediocre at best. They were more interested in their own careers than helping to develop their teams. It's a political place to work in and you gotta learn "how to kill or be killed". That was a saying that one of the MD's I supported told me. And that was exactly my experience.

review_title: Benefits are good, that's about it
pros: Getting paid sick pay that you can use virtually whenever you want and however you want, getting paid vacation from the very start, health and 401K options from the beginning is also solid.  Most part timers here worked just for the benefits alone.
cons:
Having actual knowledge and skills will not be a factor in getting higher positions, if you are not part of the favorites, you have no chance of ever moving up.

HR and Ethics will do absolutely nothing in your favor, even if you have proof, it all comes down to how much they like management.

If you're someone who keeps to themselves and has zero motivation to move up, this may be the job for you.  That isn't an insult, it's meant for those who are not going to be disappointed when they find out someone who is buddy buddy with the management gets the position and you didn't.

pros: Gym on site (£40 p/month)  and private doctors on site (expensive)
cons: No pay rise for 4 years. Poor benefits, only 23 days hol and only 7.5% pension. Working from home and flexible working is not a Citi standard it is totally dependent on your line manger. Poor VOE results year-on-year but nothing done to improve them. Cost cutting everywhere at staff's expense. Everything that can be is offshored

job_title: AML Compliance Analyst in Brandon, FL
pros: Decent pay for the job.  If you work for the right manager you can advance annually, enjoy your job, and be rewarded for your hard work with praise and (small) annual bonuses.
cons: Working for the wrong manager or team lead can make this a dead end job.  No matter how much good work you produce or knowledge of products you have, if you're not part of the right clique it won't matter.  Your accomplishments will be viewed as their accomplishments and you will watch others advance at twice your pace.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Amherst, NY
pros: Work from home when needed, decent vacation allowance.  That's really about it - not much going for this company other than that.
cons:
Upper management is completely out of touch with the people below them. I'm actually amazed that the bank still functions, generates a profit, and satisfies it's shareholders. Reports are never done on time. Things are always thrown together in emergency meetings just to get reports out. 

This company is awful. They provide zero training once you start, leaving you to completely fend for yourself. This is expected in most jobs but there should be at least a small amount of support such as how to actually use the systems specific to the bank. You can't be expected to come in and know how to use a program or database that you've never used before. 

No organization skills by upper level managers and whenever anything goes wrong it turns into the blame game. It's always the Directors or SVPs blaming their VPs, AVPs, and Analysts. Hey never take responsibility for themselves, and are extremely unreliable.

pros: I received benefits from day 1 and they have a matching 401k. When the workload was heavy they offered overtime. I generally enjoyed the culture and most people I worked with
cons: There was constant change in structure and high turnover during certain periods. The pay was not the best and my average salary increase was about 3% a year. Sales compensation in my position was  not always based on individual performance but was also combined with how the department performed as a whole that month. This lead to lower compensation at times even though my performance was high.

job_title: Collections Specialist III in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Loved the company and the job and miss it.
cons: Management not on the  same team. Did not support associates one or two may have known the job and what was expected the others just walked around because of the title with no clue what was going on.

job_title: FICC Research & Strategy Analyst in London, England
pros: Global teams and coverage, loads of responsibilities from the start, decent and growing external research credibility. The 'Citi velocity' platform is one of the better ones from the bulges for communication and info dissemination.
cons: When I left, there were many juniors who also left at the same time. That year they had hired a lot of Ds/MDs so the bonus pool was dramatically cut for the juniors, which was sad. It was a strange exodus of sorts. One young female analyst became pregnant and when she returned early they still didn't give her old job back, she had to start covering another sector. Also, I left just after MiFID2 started to ramp up, I heard there is a lot more admin to do now, to justify the salaries of research folk. Sadly a lot of people I knew at Citi were just fired after I left, so I know only a handful of people who are still there.

pros: pay no experience at all as a collections rep and started at 11.00 per hour full time,  The VP were always on the floor talking to us and wanted to make sure we as employees were happy!!!!!!!! Citi is a great place to work and all the ubit managers are very helpful and fun they made sure that we received all the information we needed and the building that i worked at was amazing Citi made sure that we were always taking care off there was a on campus citi bank that way we could just walk to the bank instead of driving to one we even had a food court on campus with real chefs it was great
cons: benefits!!!!! while i was there i couldnt get any straight answers on why my benefits were always messed up.

review_title: This company validated my aversion to huge corporations
pros: Great benefits, and nice perks if you are in NYC.  Free museum entry (at least before the meltdown.)
cons: Terrible organization, clueless top management

job_title: Senior Software Developer in Irving, TX
pros: Remote work is awesome for a work life balance.  I work with some very intelligent people.  Lot's of room to grow and learn existing technologies.
cons: As a software developer i want to stay away from making widgets.  I want to work on projects that are interesting, and give me a chance to build new technologies.  Citi as a company isn't focused on this.  They care about reducing cost (as they should), stockholder perception (as they should), etc. I am projecting my career goals here; however, there are limited opportunities to invent.

pros: As a first year, I was lucky that one of my VPs didn't believe in unnecessary face time, and was a little more understanding of your life outside of work, as limited as it was.
cons: On the other hand, he tended to have anger bursts/explode at the tiniest sign of you questioning his authority, while one of the associates was more of a passive aggressive type who would smile and pretend everything was okay, but then talk behind your back and sabotage you. I witnessed this with one of the second year analysts who left shortly after I started. I also found that HR really only sees you as another replaceable part to be worked to death and ditched - and then they wonder how come their retention rates are so low. And once you're out, it's as if you never even worked there. After I quit, my administrative assistant failed to submit my expenses before they closed my internal employee account (and he had plenty of time to do so), so then they billed me. Regardless to say, I would never work there again in a million years.

review_title: For the most people the "job for now"
pros:
- great people
- company does pay extra for extra hours, which sometimes doesn't happen in Poland
- it was pretty easy to get promoted fast
- considering the size of the market, after few years you can get paid really well
- because of the security of the systems, you actually work only in the office, no taking work home
cons:
- lack of reasonable internal movement opportunities (guy who knew Arabic was working with North America transactions, just because nobody cared, even though the same hub was working with Middle East too)
- the initial salary haven't changed in few years
- quite often there was a pressure of working after hours or on the weekends
- the job isn't as interesting as they are presenting it; most of the time you work in the Excel, google maps and google in general, doing job which in 15 years will be done by computers anyway

pros: It’s a job/career and pays a bill.
cons:
-1997 PC/software functionality. Literally the place has more workers doing manual inputting than automation.  Basically. You have button pushers making $120k annually.  It’s ok since the contractors and temp jobs will come and optimize the sub-optimal processes and flows. 
-VPs and SVPs are everywhere. They’re kinda like stray dogs that don’t do anything but are isolated from the real work.  Oh they’re usually unqualifed and over-paid resulting in the analysts and AVP doing 99% of the department workload.  Just go on LinkedIn and view the escalation style with these professionals.  
-industry is a joke.  Company had many placeholder jobs that require no brains therefore will just fill in order to meet quota.

pros: Always a new challenge with lots of different jobs to gain experience in. Benefits are very good. Telecommuting is a very viable option.
cons: Lousy salary, overworked as a standard, political back-biting, competition as a culture with no collaboration. Upper levels of technology workers are leaving in droves for greener pastures lately which is causing bottle-necks and pain points due to departure of knowledge.

pros: CITI was a constant education and had a great team environment. The team education was one of the strong points.
cons: Lack of upgrades or the timing of the upgrades. The technology was ancient until recently when they upgraded. Not a futuristic upgrade but an upgrade to help CITI compete with other corporations. Having upgrades gives corporations a cutting edge above their competitors.

review_title: Citi takes care of it's people...
pros: Great benefits, paid-time off, maternity/paternity, 401K are all above average. It is a very positive and encouraging culture, employees really work to do the right thing for the client. The employees drive the culture from the bottom up and leadership supports and encourages this. There are a lot of community involvement opportunities.
cons: It is easy to become trapped in a job you don't love because the benefits and pay are hard to beat at comparable businesses. Internal growth at some sites is limited by what businesses are handled by the site. If you are willing to relocate you open yourself up to endless opportunities.

review_title: Cash Management Sales and Maintenance, for Global companies in and out of Korea
pros: Extensive global network - gave me an understanding of the global financial markets and each markets' in-country uniqueness. After 7 years of global sales position, now working on Korea in-country sales, where Citi has a strong capability breadth as local and global bank. Was able to gain expertise as both local and global banker.
cons: As market leading global bank in Korea and its size, the cons are that Citi cannot adapt as quickly to the changing market and innovate as much as the market requires. This is an exciting time to bring changes in the Treasury arena, but feels like I am being tied down to the old ways. Would love to work in an environment that allows creative solutioning and capability development that will make my Clients happy.

review_title: Good place, but there is room for improvement
pros: Good brand name - people know Citi. It sure does have recognition. On a flip side, some people see Citi as a credit card and mortgage company... Benefits are pretty decent, good vacation allowance. Because Citi is so big, it can provide opportunities to work in different departments, regions and even countries. Not sure about compensation in other cities, but its very competitive over here compared to other banks.
cons: Working at a big company has its drawbacks as well. A lot of times communication is broken between departments. Sales goals are nearly impossible to reach eliminating a chance of promised commission. Not easy to move up - Citi's presence in Boston is still very limited. Insurance premiums are fairly high, but I guess they are high everywhere these days.

review_title: Citbank a strong company to work for that will act in good faith in hard times in our economy.
job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Dallas, TX
pros: Not only is Citigroup a common name in the world, it is also one of the largest companies out there w/ many affiliates. Citibank has great opportunites for growth and advancement.  Provides great benefits and compensation. Sky is the limit, when making money, I am always motivated to make more each month. There are extra incentives every week, that make the job exciting and compatetive with coworkers. Hours are fair and covenient for employees to have a life after work.
cons: Not enough banks yet, especially on the Western and midwest. Everyone is concentrating in finding something wrong with banks nowadays, putting Citibank in the headlines all the time. Stock market has been down the last couple of days, due to economy and loss of Wachovia buyout.

review_title: Too many senior managers running the show with insufficient knowledge or ability to do so.
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Very fast paced work environment, able to learn different things, whether within one group, job posting to other groups, or involuntary reorgs.
cons: Senior mgmt decision making process very "shoot from the hip"; constantly changing priorities mainly due to indecision; extremely political environment; extremely difficult to advance with constant hiring of outsiders into senior positions.

review_title: Overall, a good place to work. It's all what you make of it.
pros: I happen to have a set of good senior managers directly around me, so it makes things quite satisfying. I have also managed to acquire a good team under me - excellent people. The work is for the most part interesting, and the work-life balance is good. They do recognize top talent, just wish there was more of it.  There are some good people, there are some bad. Still trying to figure out who's who sometimes...
cons: Just wish we had a higher percentage of really good people...I think Citi is just too nice sometimes and really needs to clean house a bit more. Most of the groveling comes from those who should have departed long ago. Sorry if that sounds harsh, but it's the truth.

review_title: Good institution with great flaws in key areas of startegy and employee retention.
pros: This is a global institution which has best-in-class standards in terms of product offering and dedication to clients. Good training is offered to employees (or at least used to be offered before the expense cutting regime started). Among local banks, Citi is still revered as the best place to work due to misconception that compensaton is the highest.
cons: As a global institution, Citigroup is often tone-deaf to local needs in terms of compensation increases and benefits packages offered in order to attract the best talent. Very hierachical and full of career-bankers who believe that years worked in the institution equal talent.

review_title: If you are thinking of being a temporary worker, beware!
pros: Interacted well with other analysts who started at the same time as me. Trainers were helpful during the training period.
cons:
I was among a group of anti-money laundering analysts working at Citigroup through a temp agency. We were told that the job was temp-to-permanent, and that as soon as we passed a quality check we would be hired as official Citi employees. Instead, toward the end of the assignment date, all were dismissed (and informed not by our superiors at Citi, but by temp agency employees) without warning or notice, because the positions were being eliminated. What’s worse, I checked online the following day and the temp agency has posted more identical job listings for a new group of analysts. Seems like the positions were not eliminated after all.

No vacation time, no benefits, not treated well.

review_title: Just a big name to work with and tell your friend that I work for CITI
pros: flexible,good name in banks, work from home, training and vacation benefit
cons: Very poor salary package for beginners, hardly peanuts :(( Infact temporary staff gets 3-4 times the salary then the permanent ones. Very jealousy and unhappy with pay package as it include super and tax which leaves me with nothing. Boss appreciates ur work but no rewards, no bonus, no increment in salary packages nothing.Just very dry Feel like I earn so much but still I don't own anything .Wana go Shopping Spree for ages with a secured bank account ;)

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: If you are a star performer you will be noticed because there aren't that many there
cons: Overall the company lacks a clear strategy, for years it was buy everything in sight and grow that way. Now we no longer do purchase companies but due to poor integration of prior acquisitions the company does not perform as well as it should.

review_title: A very 'corporate' workplace with great culture
job_title: Credit Operations Specialist III in Gray, TN
pros: We have really great people. Even though there are 1,800+ employees, most people feel like more than a number. Benefits are above average, pay is fair, time off is excellent (146+ hours paid per year), some 4-10hr schedules, lots of overtime opportunities. The list goes on and on. Best environment I've ever worked in; almost unbelieveable for a site this large.
cons: Policies and procedures change frequently and there is always conflicting information (published on intranet, passed down from supervisors, sent around in emails, hear-say on the sales floor, etc.).  The IT infrastructure is lacking: the systems feel as though they were pieced together with no sight of the "big picture."

review_title: Capable colleagues. Size of organisation is challenging to manage
pros: Good quality capable colleagues and a myriad of different possibilities for future job roles and locations. Evidence of increasing sanity of senior mgt team.
cons: It's a very big organisation which makes it tough to find the right people quickly to understand or get things done. Citi is far from unique in this respect, but big banks still trying to manage by command and control type management which is demotivating and ineffective.

pros:
High salaries for those entering the company from outside
Brand recognition with a large international company
Mississauga office is easily accessible and well maintained
cons:
Canada is generally ignored as far as the organization is concerned as a whole
Company is heavily segmented. You literally have no idea what's going on in the rest of the organization
Inflated job titles mislead people (everyone is either an AVP, VP or SVP)
Most of the perks/benefits that come with being a Citi employee are only useful to Americans.
CFSC does not pay bonuses... maybe somewhere between $500-$800
No clear transparent bonus compensation plan.  You get a couple hundred dollars at the end of the year but have no idea how it's tied to your performance evaluation.

pros: Great cafe with a Starbucks; great fitness center and nurse station
cons: Awful technology; poor,  inexperienced management; filthy facilities. Great job for VP level or higher; awful for everybody else. Culture is egotistical snobs that cater to rich clients and the hell with everyone else.  You can work there years and never meet the people on your team since there are no name plates or any way to identify anyone who works there.  Benefits are expensive and cover less and less.  Career opportunities are a charade, hidden in a maze of acryonims and corporate jargon meant to disguise and deceive jobs that really suck.

review_title: A typical big bank in many ways
pros: You will be working amongst awesome international retail associates and clients. They will enrich your views about the world outside of U.S . It has been a previlige to meet them.
cons: Very little support from the back office which are mostly located overseas. You will not be able to call them to get clarifications. When things become challenging, you will be left on your own to deal with angry clients who are constantly screwed over by the back office. Your sales efforts are constantly captured incorrectly which require constant follow up. Upper management sits around collects big paychecks and does not care about associates real feedback on what needs to be improved. You are pressure to meet goals that are unreal and expect to be set up to fail. They will make stuff up to throw you under the bus to save themselves from any liablities.

review_title: Good opportunities depending on where you're located.
pros: Given the company's size and scope of financial services offered, there are lots of opportunities to network and move around within company as your career interests change.  Compensation is on the higher side if you work in the right group (Markets and Banking).
cons:
This is more possible only if you work at headquarters in New York.  

It's a huge company with a lot of bureaucracy.  Morale has been pretty low lately given all the negative issues surrounding the company and about three rounds of layoffs since the beginning of the year.

review_title: Great company to see many sides of the business and gain exposure
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Chicago, IL
pros: Huge company with ability to move around if live in major city.  Many different departments if looking to try different positions.  Great benefits package.  Developing relationships with other deparments will help moving up the job ladder.  Bonuses have been good the last couple years.  We will see how they are this year though as most probably will not be very good.
cons: Firm is very large.  Company has been beat up in the media.  Tough to get ideas implemented.  This company is Corporate America.  Senior Management has made bad decisions in handling assets of company and we are now in the news nearly everyday in a bad way.  Annual Salary increases have been pretty low the last couple years.

job_title: Smith Barney Financial Advisor in Baltimore, MD
pros: I've been with Smith Barney for less than a year now as a Financial Advisor Associate, Smith Barney has a good reputation, technology, and talented employees within the wealth management industry.
cons: The firm only care about how much assets you bring in as a financial advisor. Therefore, the firm train you well on how to prospect relentlessly but you have to basically self-learn about products, how to use technology, and how to do administrative paperworks. You are really independent from day one, and it is quite overwhelming. I was so disappointed by the firm's lack of support in terms of product or financial planning education for new FAAs. You have to bring in about a million dollar a month to be a very successful FA and it is very very difficult unless you have rich family background or established book of business.

job_title: Financial Associate in New York, NY
pros: A good reason to you'd like to work for Citibank would be if you genuinely love teller work. Citibank empowers its tellers with many abilities.
cons: Everything else you can literally think about on a workplace aspect. Seriously. This company does not follow what it preaches. Management is irresponsible and many times aren't sure of what they are doing unless they are going by their policy & procedure reference (which they still always mess up on even with the reference in their face).

review_title: Worked on a business analyst project for the Market Data groups here.
job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Smart, friendly, and well-adjusted people. People willing to help whether you're part of their team/project or not. Relatively agile for a large company, good office location and amenities.
cons: Scope of projects I was given were relatively narrow. Typical problems of working in a large organization:  Lots of hoops to jump through to get management or HR/payroll/finance approval for any changes to project parameters or to do simple things like get various approval papers signed for things such as personal trading declarations. The processes for these types of things did go pretty quickly considering the steps involved.

job_title: AML Compliance Analyst in Tampa, FL
pros: Great People and an enjoyable, fairly relaxed atmosphere on any given day --  (when the "cons" aren't working against you".  The work is interesting and challenging.
cons: Unpredictable workload  resulting in existing staff having to "power through" any heavy months of activity.  The idea of an 8 hour day doesn't exist the last two weeks of any month... just too much to do and not enough time to do it.  This "maximizing efficiency" approach can start to feel like your full time salaried position is a definite disadvantage, resulting in earning less and less per hour.

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in New York, NY
pros: Overtime eligible, standard benefits, average pay for outside hires
cons:
Unfriendly culture at the retail level.  Managers show favoritism to specific employees, letting them get away with things that could be grounds for termination for others.

Nearly impossible sales goals leads to employees pursing aggressive tactics or risk being reprimanded.  Fellow employees especially bankers do not help each other out and steal clients because of the cutthroat sales goals.  

No friendly or team oriented environment, managers and co-workers treat the job as a paycheck and would not enjoy staying one minute longer then required.

review_title: Excellent for customer and pathetic for employees
pros: money is the only reason to work here
cons: Based on your 3000 calls in a month a single mistake in a single call stops your confirmation. People get thrown out without notice period in a single day, They hire new batch and the very same day ask an old employee to leave and don't even allow the former employee to use the washroom and collect their bag. Very unprofessional. They extend confirmation for 2 months after half year of service and then on the 10th or 11th month without prior notice kicks you out. This practice is very old people don't express this out, as this is a disrespect  and an embarrassment, but few of us found it very insulting and no job satisfaction as the customer's will be bombarding at the phone continuously to us and the supervisors will bombard in your break time, hence we left with dignity.

review_title: Don't do it if you want to work in a stable environment. Find your opportunities elsewhere.
pros: Good initial pay. Diversity programs throughout the company seems very good. Cafe, gym and medical services onsite.
cons: Too much red tape on everything. Very political environment so very few people will go out of their way to help you. Some teams do not care to do the right thing, they only care about the procedures even if it is obviously wrong and can be changed with a little effort. Employees never know what is coming down the pipe until it it implemented. Employees are constantly talking about how they are always nervous about their jobs. Benefits are nowhere close to where they should be for a company this size . Employees in some areas are expected to work hours that are not human with no sort of comp time. Employees complain about little or no raises or bonuses for years except for management. Parking can be a real challenge.

review_title: If your not on phones you may have a better experience
job_title: Loss Mitigation Specialist II in Tucson, AZ
pros: People and atmosphere was great.  Managers were very knowledgeable about the processes. Also very diverse company.
cons: Collections expectations were too high and systems were not working properly half the time to be able to take a payment much less collect. We were deducted our unplanned time for being late from lunches and breaks even one minute. On top of phones had to adjust your time card or the whole team would be dragged down with percentages. And you were discouraged from getting off the phones to use the bathroom.

review_title: Great people to work with but dated and monolithic culture
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: The long term employees are very committed to training and mentoring newcomers, and first line management seems to be merit based and communicates expectations and corporate goals well.
cons: The management lines are so gerrymandered and execs are so loathe to take responsibility that any change or task requiring crossing basic organizational structures is Sisyphian.  The services catalogs are either non-existent or fractured, and responsibilities are being thrown at buckets that make no sense.

pros: Joined after the crisis expecting to find a culture based on admission of past mistakes and a desire to make the bank better. There are still some very smart people there, and at least some of them do think that way. Willingness to give you responsibility and ability to get involved in very important things
cons: You can be given significant levels of responsibility and then discover you will have no budget or resources to actually deliver. Senior ranks heavily comprised on people who have never worked anywhere else, and have no idea about industry best practices. Diversity of opinion and credible challenge is not something that Citi embraces.

pros: Still a good place to work with great benefits, vacation time and flex opportunities for your work life balance.  Senior Executive Management has made a big push to improve the employee relationships with management.
cons: The Senior Executive Leaders are engaged, supportive and working hard to improve the Citi image.  This looks and sounds great in the news and in print.  Middle management, i.e. Managing Directors, Directors and the SVP level, they only care about making their bonuses.  They will sacrifice anyone as long as they make their numbers and bonus.  When they no longer have the leverage, either your gone or they take the package and run.

review_title: Very fast-paced environment without guarantee of support or training
pros: Salary, Depth of Experience gained, Highly Intelligent Colleagues
cons: Some employees are able to justify managing global complex relationships between stakeholders by obstructing internal communication and insulating themselves into work silos where the same work is likely to be completed by multiple people multiple times, while other employees are expected to provide constant updates of imminent progress. This progress often depends on approval from some employees who are causing the obstructions so that they handle less work.

review_title: This company is good place for retirement, but not for people who want to make some achievement.
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Irving, TX
pros: Lots of vacation time--I almost feel guilty for having some much time off.  The company is strong and stable. The company provides fitness facilities and nice cafeteria. Some people go to exercises and have a shower during lunch break. Most people go to lunch at company's cafeteria and it is easy to socialize with coworkers. The foods are good and prices are very reasonable.
cons: It is very hard to get things done. Lots of unnecessary and absurd procedures to follow. Some people only care about following company's procedures or policies and keep themselves out of trouble. It is so frustrating if you want to get something done.

review_title: A very demanding place to work
job_title: Relationship Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: It is a very progressive environment in which to work.  For a big bank there is a focus using current to advanced technology.  Policies and procedures are clearly defined in an online knowledge management system.  In the event one cannot find the answer online there are phone reps available to provide support.  Compensation is generally above the industry average.
cons: There is significant pressure to perform.  Work/life balance is difficult to achieve and not well supported by the business.  The corporation as a whole is struggling, as is the rest of the financial services industry, so there are a lot of changes that are unique to this business cycle.  There have been at least three to four rounds of lay-offs in the past 18 months with more streamlining anticipated in the future.

review_title: Strong brand and credibility in marketplace
job_title: Financial Advisor in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Distinguished organization with strong brand. Strong analytical support including help desks for all topics. Flexible platforms allow for customized investment strategies.  Focused on comprehensive financial planning and tools are satisfactory. Compensation package is attractive. Very entrepreneurial environment which works for more established FA's.
cons: Very big and too much information to navigate.  Too many platforms for advisors to choose from, each with a different fee schedule. Lately, issues with financial stability affects prospect perception. Employee cuts may affect customer service. Not much support for newer FA's. Throw you out there and figure it out on your own. No marketing budget so you have to spend a lot of money to make money.  A lot of focus on cold calling rather than other marketing strategies.

review_title: Challenging and in need of efficiency
pros:
The work is interesting and their is always room for improvement.
The days fly by because their is always plently of work to do.
Everyday is different, twists and subjective decisions make you stay on your toes.
cons:
There is a disconnect between management and what lower us lower level peons are doing.
The nature of the division forces 300+ people to make subjective evaluations. 
Continuity and objectives need to be unified.
Or providing continuing training while also increasing analyst freedom.

job_title: Java Software Developer in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Salary very high for position. Willing to try new technologies for applications. Management (at least in my experience) has been very nice and approachable. Office is in a very good location of Dublin. Also office is of very high standard.  Overtime is not a major part of their culture in my experience - apart from releases which take part on Saturdays (from home). Ability to work remotely.
cons: All the red tape. My god the issues they have for even requesting the most simple of updates (like database updates for example) even in test environments. In my experience, very little social interaction between employees. Teams can be across different continents (even 3!) which creates time zone issues and lack of clear / constant communication.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Citi's Global reach and large volumes and applications pushed me to think big and think globally. It allowed gave me exposure to multiple asset classes and business lines. It gave me opportunities to visit countries like Russia, Bahrain, the UK and the US.
cons: Being a large company, they have several HR policies which are of a 'one size fits all' kind.  The green card processing policies left much to be desired and caused a lot of frustration.

review_title: More cons than pros in Ohio
pros:
Benefits and vacation time start your first day of employment which is nice since most places you have to accrue vacation. 

Flexible with schedule changes if an emergency arises. 

If you're doing your job even moderately adequately you're guaranteed a raise each year.
cons:
Workload is uneven. The better you do the more they give you. 


News leaked that 2000+ employees were being laid off Citi wide and no one in management has yet to address it with anyone at our site and who it will affect. In fact they feign ignorance that it is even in the news. 

People get comfortable and spend 30+ years and retire in the same position so there is no opportunity to advance unless you're willing to move out of state to a different site.

pros: The organizations is large, and allows you access to a lot of facets of banking, if you look hard enough. Benefits are pretty good, and the prestige associated with the bank garners a lot of outward respect.
cons:
Company culture is inconsistent, and largely dependent on where you are in the bank. Internal mobility within the bank from one department to another seems generally discouraged or hard to come by. 

How you are treated [by the bank] differs a lot where you are. Technology based jobs within the company see a much slower and neglected environment. Bonuses are smaller, and money is tracked more carefully (100 dollars for Microsoft Visio, not happening). As opposed to client-facing positions, where bonuses might be larger, employees get more on-site benefits (such as free food after a certain time), and money flows more freely (1k USD to ship a box -- consider it done).

pros: Challenging work, great resume builder. I had an excellent manager and team. Ability to work from home when necessary. Good focus on ethics.
cons: Back stabbing and snide comments are not uncommon. Long hours--to the point that my good salary was just mediocre because I was working 70 hr work weeks. Management does not recognize the changes that really need to be made to make the business efficient and effective--off-shoring may cut expenses on paper, but the technology lags and other inefficiencies will still remain and even be exasperated. Teams were under-resourced to make the books look better (6 mo + delays, with no change to workload or team productivity expectations).

review_title: Good place to start and get XP, but don't want to stay too long
pros: Citi has a great company culture, and a good work life balance.  They salary is quite good for Hungarian average, but if you are into money more then the above, you can find better.
cons: They want to believe that they are Tech company as well but they are mostly mediocre.  Management choices are entirely only for themselves not the company. Even at a low level the management is too much into politics. As an International company they want to muscle American ideals into the local employees instead of taking a bit of time to understand them and then know how to motivate them.

pros: Great sales experience, good benefits, set schedule, good amount of time off, decent pay for a beginner in sales field.
cons: High stress atmosphere. Many people that work here have mental health breakdowns. Many of the clients are from the New York City metro area and they extremely demanding, they will scream at you, swear at you, threaten you and hang up on you several times on a daily basis. You will have to follow many metrics, most of which work against each other to bring down your sales bonuses. (I.E. They have this thing called offer rate. You have to offer sales on every call or it counts against you, while at the same time you have handle time which has to be short or it counts against you. Obviously these two things are designed to work against each other. It's a balancing act. Also many of the jobs are outsourced, as are the resources.

pros: Great pay, I am technically an hourly employee with a base salary and I can earn time and a half for overtime. Last year that afforded me an extra 10,000. Some jobs are very flexible with ability to work from home
cons: Team size is not as large as it should be. My current job needs about 3 more people to operate efficiently. Annual raises are distributed evenly across the floor regardless of job difficulty (this could be a good thing if you are on the “easy” teams). My opinion is that I am currently on a bad team, other teams are great working environments. My previous roles I was very satisfied with. Some employees are just there for the paycheck, not all motivated individuals

review_title: Overall this is a great company to work for and if given the chance I would go back
pros:
Large corporation with a small company feel. Since the company has different divisions and they allow then to run pretty autonomous.
Great benefits package. Their benefits package is all inclusive that you do not see anymore. They have the regular stuff along with dissability, 401k with matching along with supplemental retirement. 
Willing to look at different options and ways of doing things
Employee and community concious, they provide avenues for you to support local causes with their sponsorship. Donations taken out pre-tax and company matching.
cons:
Large Corporation so they can move slow on changing to new technologies.
Decisions can be handed down without looking at the impact on actual production at a lower level.

review_title: Times have changed a lot since starting with this company. May be good again one day but for now- too much uncertainty.
job_title: Branch Manager in Jersey City, NJ
pros: The best reasons to work for citigroup are the training, which is extensive and the employee benefits.  Until the last few years, company growth and new job potential was a big factor for liking the company.  The one good thing hat has come about recently is that it appears that we are finally starting to see some light at the end of the tunnel and the company may be stabalizing
cons: Downsides are the uncertainty and the cutting back everywhere within the company. WHen I first started there was flexiblity in terms of employee bonus and recruiting. That is no longer an option for either.   Watching the company stock fall to the sub $1 range

pros: Health insurance used to be amazing. With the new CEO, things have gone downhill. The culture is great, if you are part of a group. There are fundraisers for the community, pot lucks, and bake sales constantly. The break rooms are full of coffee and vending machines offering anything you can imagine.
cons: They are constantly restructuring the company. They expect people to do the jobs of 3 people. Some of the higher level management is completely clueless. Others are brilliant. You have to hope that you get a good one, or your work life could be awful. There is a lot of favoritism within the company. They promote meritocracy, but employees never see it.

review_title: Full of Bull, and absolutely no equal to Merrill Lynch.
pros: I was able to keep my lights on and feed my family with the help of some savings.  The office is located at the Galleria in Houston, so when you have had enough for the day, you can walk the mall.
cons: Desk head is interested in limiting traders term, and collecting trade ideas from his traders to put in his own book.  Absolute dictatorship, where the leader works towards a goal of destroying individual confidence and self worth, creating an environment where the trader loses confidence in their abilities, resulting in fear of losing money. Pure definition of individual greed limiting collective goal of making money.  Environment is shaped by the leader to keep himself at the top.

review_title: Great place to build a career
job_title: AVP- Ops Analyst in Buffalo, NY
pros:
Huge company name located in Buffalo
Many different back/middle office positions here.
Pay is pretty strong for the area. Good benefits. 401k matches 6%.
Work/life balance is good
Lots of paid time off
Ability to work remotely
Co-workers are typically pretty relaxed, low pressure
Pretty good promoting within
On site fitness center
cons:
Can be a little bit boring/slow at times
Can be a little bit overwhelming/fast at times
Front office/product/sales types from NYC/London seems to look down on you. Not everyone, but some of the cranky NYC people do
After getting used to a role, the challenges become less and less
It's a very, very large global company. At times you're just another cog in the wheel.

pros: Good health and dental benefits, generous PTO policy.  Management pretty hands off and doesn't make you work OT.  Good support for policy questions, co workers friendly and supportive for the most part.
cons: Layoffs are always in play at Citi, so go in knowing at some point your likely to be dispensed. I've seen employees with 10, 20 or more years been chopped over the past several years.  The office environment is pretty lame, but can be better depending on what manager and group you work with.  May or might not get raises every year so don't be shocked if you don't get one.

review_title: A very good company for average life expectations, but not the best place for hot-shots and maverics...
pros: Good brand name, better compensation then most of the local banks, friendly worker environment, steady workplace if you like, in-house trainings. Also it is easier to find jobs in market after getting labeled as a "previous employee of Citibank". Although the group got smaller, currently it is reorganizing itself, so the change yields to new opportunities to show yourself and go further. If you are interested in a career in banking & finance, Citigroup provides a solid name and opportunities for the ones who wants further in area...
cons: less opportunity to move further, bigger than it should be, senior managements failures in decisions, unnecessary long bureaucracy, rivalry for power between departments (which encumbers the speed of process), unnecessary outsourcing, not enough planning

review_title: Good place to start a career in banking and finance.
pros: Most of the managers I have met have been very approachable and more than willing to share words of wisdom. Excellent training and mentoring program. Decent opportunities for career advancement.  The work atmosphere is really nice and the company makes the effort in taking care of their employees. Compensation and benefits are on par with most other banks.
cons: As in many places there is always the usual office politics going on that can affect the way the team functions as a whole. You'll encounter a number of fellow employees who are only willing to look out for themselves and will shamelessly do whatever it takes to move up the ladder.

review_title: Poor management and HR.  Unwelcoming staff and poor career opportunitries - NOT recommended
pros: Scale of the organisation - otherwise none
cons: Extremely poor management - unfriendly staff, no HR induction - unhelpfull people in all departments.  Backstabbing

review_title: THE WORSE PLACE EVER TO WORK-- JOB SEEKER BEWARE
job_title: Loss Mitigation Specialist II in Florence, KY
pros: Only thing good about this place is the pay. I can not say any other good words about this place.
cons: HORRIBLE training-- 6 weeks of "learning" absolutely nothing, Managers are just absolutely unprofessional and down right heartless, CONSTANT system issues- which YOU end up getting in trouble over, And the worst part--- Ask one question- and literally get 10 different answers-- and YOU get into trouble, because you didn't choose the correct answer. They expect you to keep up with hundreds of different procedures-- and they change them daily. You don't have time to blink during your work day, and they expect you to keep up with all the changes. This place is just a freakin' joke.....Plain and simple.  Don't waste your time!

job_title: Vice President IT Service Management in Warren, NJ
pros: Competitive pay. Learning opportunities. I had a good starting salary, but few raises over the years, and no bonuses for my last 5 years (even though I was consistently rated an exemplary employee). They paid for me to get a good deal of ITIL training, and once I left Operations, I did have opportunity for growth and expansion.
cons: Politics, Lack of concern for employees. In my 11+ years of constant power-shifts and routine layoffs with Citi, I never felt secure in my job. Through many years of mergers and acquisitions, a culture of fiefdoms developed, which stifled real progress, innovation, and reasonable business management. While pinching pennies on business critical initiatives, they routinely wasted millions on the absurd pet projects of executive "leaders".

review_title: Too big to truly bother with the individual
pros: Nice office, flexible working (from home) widely applied and works well in practice although the long hours and 'being on' at all times is almost expected at every level which affects work/life balance
cons: A lot of senior managers rule by fear - and are allowed to by a HR team that seems to want to please (management) more than anything else.  The culture is basically 'fit in or ship out' and you really only get one chance....if you don't manage to impress the right people you are very quickly on a sticky path!  This seems to be the same across all levels so there is little 'firm' strategy and longer term goals. Communication becomes ambiguous because everyone leaves room to change their minds or claim that what they originally said meant something else, to cover their own backside.

review_title: Great place to work...if you know how to work it...
pros: Relatively new to banking, but have been here nearly 3 years.  Overall great experience.  If you are motivated and willing to step up, you will get noticed and rewarded.  If you're looking to fly below the radar, this probably is not the place because people form opinions rather quickly and you can get stuck.  But if you're willing to get out of your comfort zone and try new challenges, you will really stretch yourself, learn a ton, and be well compensated.
cons: Not really a negative, but Citi is so large you are responsible for your career.  You need to network and form relationships to move your career forward - no one will do it for you.

job_title: Software Engineer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: nothing much really I totally wasted my 4 years of my time (2012 to 2016) , I still regret why I signed the offer back in 2012, Directors are blind and dont give ... about their staff , nothing Positive to talk about really ...
cons: worst company to work for ,low wages,0% bonus for my entire period (4 Years 2012 to 2016) ,0% pay hike for my entire period ( 4 years 2012 to 2016) , management dont want developers moving from Belfast o London (High Paying Place),Tier 2 employers are treated like slaves.technology is ... just application support really not much innovation, if you are young and dynamic stay away from Citi Belfast , try to get into Citi London at least you will be on the high end salary.

job_title: Senior Technical Specialist in Warren, NJ
pros: Great work life balance, 401k and healthcare plans. Some good managers who are really good leaders and promote growth, but  category of leaders  is very less as compared to number of managers in Citi.
cons: Offshore and consultant centric environment, promotions and full time conversions  are based on relations, too many SVPs, VPs with no behavioral skills. Less opportunity if you are a tech savvy and a full time employee because all development and design related work is done by offshore.  Working model is not different that any overseas consulting firm with onsite-offshore setup

review_title: Big company, too big to fail, too big to succeed - both as a company, and for the individual employees.
pros: Citigroup is a big company, there are lots of opportunities to grow if you seek out to them. A person can meet people that he/she never thought existed or learn about things that he/she never heard of.
cons: Big company, you can easily gotten lost if you are not aggressive. Like everyone else said, you are just a number - or as they put it, a P & L. In business, it's about how much you can bring in. In back office operations and technology, it's all about how many people you "manage". Huge disparity in pay scales depending on your group - in fact, there is no "Citigroup" culture, it's all about the culture of whatever group you wound up in.

review_title: If there aren't any other alternatives, at least its a job
job_title: Sales and Service Representative in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Citi has superior insurance, including dental and vision.  The facility is well kept and inexpensive daycare is available as well as a gym, post office, and medical center.  There are family movie night in the cafeteria and various weekend events throughout the year.
cons: Pay for sales and service representatives is $11.60 per hour.  The "bonus" you hear about in training is almost unattainable because of the complexity of the bonus calculation formula.  Managers want perfect customer satisfaction surveys but encourage high pressure sales techniques.  Everyday you hear about talk time, offer rates and sales results.  Don't expect any respect from your managers or the people you talk to on the phone.

pros: Salary is quite good, positive benefits.People friendly and positive but naturally it all depends on what team you end up. Have eyes wide open and don't let anyone to disrespect you.
cons: There are some good projects which you might complete with success but it all depends where and with who you work with.

job_title: Compliance Analyst in Long Island City, NY
pros: Some very nice people depending on your department. I cannot stress how important it is to know how to gauge your work environment, management and peers.
cons: Extremely cut-throat, I cannot work in a place where everyone throws everyone under the bus. This is the environment or at least department I worked in, no hard feelings I wish I was told this by staffing agency. My trainer was a pirate and his boss was a perfectionist so it was a very intense dynamic. I would not recommend this to any contract employee, basically your setup from the get-go unless you come from a previous environment like that where you know to operate.

pros: There is a start and an end. The team and people that work there are smart/fantastic/passionate. You learn a lot from each other, and the work life balance is great
cons: They do not make non-exempt employees feel valued. If you are exempt you get a lot more flexibility. Even if you get a good year review, you are not guaranteed a merit increase. Salary tends to be on the lower end.

pros: Wonderful Benefits, sub-par pay and a nice amount of time off. It can be where you move further, but there may be some issue depending on getting past the lower part of the job first. Really work hard and you might get a promotion.
cons: The call center mentality, there is a reason it has roughly a 6-month retention rate. It gets a bit difficult, there is a difference in handling customers face to face versus over the phone. Have a thick skin or don't accept the job. There is some help, but scheduling and trying to switch departments you have to quit and reapply hoping they have a different shift available to you.

job_title: Credit Specialist II Retail Credit Services
pros:
Paid training, and the work is very easy as long as you pay attention; it's just extremely repetitive.

They give great benefits, and almost a months worth of paid time off. You just have to be careful to not go over the "unplanned" time.

There are some good options to move up, but they are free and far between.
cons:
You won't know how to do the work being expected of you once you're done in the training. You'll be put on the floor, and told to read procedures and figure it out, but the people around you are usually willing to help out.

A lot of the problems just come down to bad communication, but management would rather keep saying it's the agents responsibility to stay up to date rather then actually talking with line level reps to make sure everyone understands, and is in a good position to succeed.

job_title: Audit Manager in New York, NY
pros: There are a lot of great opportunities throughout Citi considering how large it, and also in the audit department. There is space for promotion or movement in the company between departments.
cons: Because of how large the company and the audit department is, and with teams being compartmentalized, it's also a hit or miss regarding your growth opportunities depending on the team you're on. Some senior managers empower their teams, some don't, and others are outright unethical. But that's to be expected in such a large company, not everyone is going to do the right thing.

review_title: Citi is still a good place to work, it pays the bills when many are struggling.
job_title: Vice President in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Flexibility and benefits. It's a large company with plenty opportunities. Good stability and very flexible with people that want to work from home.
cons: The company is not doing well financially. No raises, very tiny bonuses if anything.

pros: One of the best reasons to work at Citigroup would be the amount of potential exposure you can get to all of the different aspects of banking/financial services.
cons:
Career advancement is poor - there is not much mobility.  This is definitely related to the current market conditions, although all other banks are performing at a much better rate.

This is a company where if times are good, then things are good.  If times are bad like right now, it is quite depressing.  The morale is very low as there is no incentive to do any more than your minimal requirements.

review_title: Citi has to get out of it's own way
job_title: Senior Vice Predident, Architecture in New York, NY
pros: Citi is a place to learn the craft of banking, within whatever profession one works in, for me, I became both an executive and a talented architect for technology while I was there. It has a smart work force, all dedicated to doing a good job. It has sufficient power in the world, so that a person can build a great external network.
cons: It suffers great paternalistic centralized control, which leads to an arrogance in which the best ideas from below, and from the regions are not given sufficient weight. This leads to frustration in the work force, poor results for the business, and great nepotism in the work place. Most folks I know at citi are simply getting a pay check, hoping things will get better.

review_title: Great company if you are in the right group
job_title: Accounting and Finance in Irving, TX
pros: Work/Life Balance, Insurance, 401K and plenty of opportunity to try different jobs/careers if you are unsure.
cons: The company always has a flavor of the month and lacks direction.  Recently it has gotten better, but we'll see if they stick with it or not.  Many people have long tenure, which can be seen as good, but it also means that advancement sucks and everyone is resistant to change.  It seems that Citi wants to move forward, but they can't do it with the same old thinking that got us here in the first place, which is what they have.  Politics and multiple layers of management that have been in place for 15+ years and are just concerned about checking the box and will probably retire in the same position in another 15+ years.

review_title: Citi, like most IBD programs, offers a great place to begin a career.
job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Citi does very well to invest in its juniors, and there's a focus on retaining some for eventual promotion. Some other firms 100% assume that as an analyst, you're not going to stay and therefore will not invest in you as heavilty (e.g. client exposure). Most banks on the Street, Citi included, however, are supportive or their analyst recruiting after their 2-year program.
cons: Despite its excellent training for analysts, Citi has had some trouble with managing its brand, especially with how much change the organization has gone through in the past several years following the collapse. Pay traditionally has lagged behind the street, but recently there has been some effort to match the street.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: It has been a pleasure working at Citi.  I've worked at other large banks and found the corporate culture at Citi to be more welcoming, collaborative and supportive.  I'd definitely recommend working for this firm. Of course, variances may occur depending on which department you work for, but overall, I'm pleased.
cons: Recent reorganization and cost cutting efforts (which are experienced across the banking industry) have reduced staff and changed many functions.  Of course, only time will tell if the changes boost the bottom line.

pros: Flex time and freedom to work from home. The salary is slightly ahead of the industry package and the bonus is consistently 15%. The salary package makes it very difficult to leave. The company matches up to 6% in stocks and the medical and dental coverages is up to 90%. The contractual work week is 37.5 and over the entire year, that number is fairly accurate.
cons: There are jobs posted on the company intranet for internal movement but candidates are already flagged for these positions so the jobs aren't really open. Management seems disconnected and uninterested in viewing people as resources. Training courses outside the city are frowned upon.

job_title: Desktop Support Manager in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Large firm, secure and intelligent staff ready for support if needed with lots of room for improvement leading to opportunities unparalleled in a smaller better run institution.
cons: Lots of know it alls who really don't know it all.  Too much bureaucracy to be considered a dynamic institution.
