They are completely under the government microscope fo compliance and as such cannot move fast even if their corporate life depended on it.  Run by accountants who do not understand the quality of investments in personnel.

pros:
Where do I start? 
I loved working for this organisation. They knew how to support their staff in everything. Training, development,  opportunities, career progression and so on.
The whole operation was ran effectively, professionally and efficiently. 
I worked as a Vendor Manager and loved every second.  Loved my vendors, loved the team I worked with, loved every day and I miss this place so dearly.
I would have stayed until I retired, if they had let me but unfortunately the location of office I worked was winding down  and therefore I was made redundant. But even up to my last day, they were amazing. Kept me informed at every step of this process regardless of whether it indirectly affected me or not. 
As I said "I miss this place so much"
cons: Absolutely nothing. They were amazing and I wished I remained working for them.

review_title: Not a bad company for Belfast.
job_title: Senior Compliance Officer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
- Networking opportunities
- Everyone deals with the same Citi wide issues so you tend to bond quite quickly with colleagues
- Salary good for Belfast
- Having Citi on your CV will always stand you in good stead and will give you plenty of opportunities for being headhunted.
cons:
- Long hours expected
- Belfast based teams seem to pick up a lot of other regions work due to inability to complete but yet be kept in more junior C levels.
- Most teams are very slow to replace attrician leavers resulting in understanding and more work for remaining employees
- Inability to discuss salary with colleagues in order to obtain a benchmark/expectancy

review_title: Excellent company marred by endemic bullying and unethical conduct of manageny
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Excellent salary and staff benefits. Pension, health insurance, and onsite gym
cons:
Widespread and normalised bullying. Environment that fosters competition rather than collaboration. Middle management taking credit for the hard work of their staff, but will gladly make scapegoats of the same people when things go wrong.
Management that feel threatened by staff who are engaged and motivated.

HR departmentis indifferent to anything outlined above.

pros:
The benefits.  They are very generous with their dental plan and fairly so with their education reimbursement.

My manager was also quite flexible with giving time off when requested.  However, she was more of the exception than the norm.

Because of the size of the company, you get to meet a lot of people and network.
cons:
It is a very large company and it is very easy to "get lost in the system".  This often means that it is possible to be passed over for promotions and advancement.

They do not hesitate to lay off their employees either.  Often employees hear through the media before they are told by their management.  Even managers who have been with the company for 20+ years are laid off without notice.  It may just be the culture.

review_title: A nice place to work, but compensation is stingy
pros: Flexible Work Schedules.  Very supportive and understanding local management.  Opportunity to work from home (with demonstrated experience/proficiency) a day or two a week, or during bad weather when roads are dangerous. Great benefits, comparative to other companies I've worked for in the past.
cons: Compensation is below average. Annual raises, if any, are around 2-3%. Employer requires 40 hours minimum of training each year; even if not job relevant (this may be a local expectation).  Job-relevant training can be very limited, and is often "learn it as you do it".  Constantly going through cycles of downsizing and/or hiring freezes.  Constantly restructuring the HR tree.  Great opportunity for a first promotion; however difficult to be promoted into a first-tier management position; and even more difficult to be promoted into higher management positions:  think "glass ceiling".

review_title: People doing the work used to be quite good.  Management focused on cost cutting.
pros: Good work life balance, if you have the right manager, then you can work from home some of the time.
cons: Management focus is only on cutting costs, primarily leading to moving jobs from high cost locations (e.g. New York, London, Singapore) to low cost locations like Tampa or India - completely ignoring the depth of experience and skill levels of the staff in locations they deem as high cost.

job_title: Personal Banker in New York, NY
pros: Compensation plan is great. Have to grind to make your numbers but worth it at the end of the month. Meet amazing people at your level (branch level)
cons: Pressure pressure pressure. At first it was fun making numbers and being competitive at your own pace. Then it just got extreme. Upper management needs serious branch trainings so they can see what we go through on a daily basis. The company started closing branches cutting hours and expect customer service to be excellent yet inconvenient hours. Pb salary is low but compensation helps just pressure is crazy. Promotions are who you know

job_title: Vice President Finance in Tampa, FL
pros: A much improved and strong emphasis on work/life balance.  A solid company with a strong customer focus.  Also supports training both in hard and soft skills, anti money laundering, Oracle Financials training, Excel and PPT skills training.  Soft skills included diversity training, communication skills, and much more.  Compensation is reasonable, and my separation package was quite generous to compensate me for my 30+ years of service.
cons: An atmosphere of empowerment is needed by management, but as it is a financial institution I can understand that some critical decisions need to be made by those that are "in the know".

review_title: lack of corp wide UNITY. The focus should be many, many groups, but only ONE COMPANY.
pros: looks good on your resume.
cons:
lack of corp wide unity.   All the purchased companies that make up this giant,  will not work as one.... 
there are parts of company directly competing with other parts of the same company... or taking food from 1 hand and putting in other hand...the net results is minus zero, if you consider both groups, man hours spent.
many seniors thinking they that are above the law, for short term gains, but should think for longer term. off shoring may help bottom line for next several quarters, but will hurt 3 to 7,  years out.  It takes 2 or 3 Indans to replace 1 American

review_title: Had High Hopes, Shattered by Citi Management
job_title: Assistant Vice President, Project Manager in Columbus, OH
pros: I was asked to return to a company Citi recently acquired in 2007.  With that, I believed that the job that I was doing was going to help our clients and our staff be successful.  Instead the dysfunctional organization continued to spend money on bad decisions and upper management was not held accountable.  I delivered my work on-time, bridged fractured client relationships and began making end-roads to baselining our staff with Citi's delivery model.  Suddenly, I was caught in the middle of the 50,000 person layoff and yet am the only senior project manager who was relieved of their duties.
cons: Day-to-day, staff are not sure what changes are going to happen.  The management staff in Columbus don't talk with clients, their own staff which leads to no one really knowing where the intiatives are going.

review_title: Escalated concerns of customers is being handled by one person in the Manila site; Information systems too complicated
pros: The Information technology being used are up to date; Salary is fair and reasonable for employees with experience
cons: Information System Software are not user-friendly--too complicated; Escalated concerns are being handled by one person (female) in the Manila Site (in other places officers cannot be contacted also) and cannot be contacted by anyone for follow-ups--main reason why Australian Customers who have escalated concerns are not happy with Citibank Australia Customer service

review_title: DOD Travel Card - For a company that has been established for 200 years - what a joke!
job_title: Client Account Specialist in Norfolk, VA
pros: Select member of management attempts to keep employees motivated.
cons: There are hardly any polices/procedures that are enforced regularly. If a manager wants something they get it, but if you are not on the senior leadership team you are treated unfairly. Managers seem to have no education or background in managing people. Reviews/evaluations are given out by opinion, policies in the company-wide handbook are not enforced and employees are told to ignore them. Associates and Project Managers have more experience in this field then the managers.

review_title: Big company with lots of opportunities
job_title: Vice President in Long Island City, NY
pros: Being such a large company with a strong global presence there are many lateral movement opportunities.  Movement is allowed after you've been in a role for about 18 months.  There are many opportunities to network within the company and move laterally.
cons: In almost every role you'll have to manage your manager and your day-to-day work will be secondary.  Promotions within your current role or team is extremely rare.  One has to move to another team to move up a level or leave the company for a few years and come back at a more senior position.  Although attempts have been made to "flatten" the management structure bureaucracy still exists.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: It's easy to move within Citi, they have a good internal job website.  As individuals, there are a number of good / nice people there.
cons: Headcount cuts EVERY QUARTER for the last 3 years. Workload is increased, headcount shrinks. Senior Mgt has no knowledge of or interest in its employees. Work/life balance is non-existent. Take a look outside of any NYC Citigroup building Monday thru Friday from 7pm onward... there's a constant stream of food deliveries all night long. Go see, this is verifiable. There's also a constant stream of black cars all night.

pros:
You may learn a few things what I learned there is to work hand in hand with younger employees learned how to manage my time, learned about project management on my own.
Learned to get key players fellow workers in order to learn and do my job.


Good work/life balance.
cons:
Training is just enough to get you to do your work.  Micro managed all the time.  Company culture treats contractors a dime a dozen.  I didn't feel welcomed working there and left me high and dry.  Also, management is not clear. They rarely speak to you face to face and would rather have some other employee speak to you on their behalf.

Terrible experience.  If you have other options pursue them .  Think twice about citit especially if you're a contractor.

pros: Okay commission if you're a great salesperson. Lots of pressure at the teller line to sell products
cons:
Key driver score is a customer satisfaction survey conducted anonymously by Gallup on behalf of citibank. It's tied directly to everybody's annual bonus from teller to region manager. On a scale of 0 to 10 if the customer rated 0-8 for the interaction it counts as ZERO. 
Everybody freakin hates it. 

Also anti money laundering is big since this is a global bank. And the tellers are required to gather clients info if they did cash transactions without a debit card. That includes phone numbers occupations plies everything on your drivers license and the blood of your firstborn son

pros: Friendly atmosphere. Casual work environment. Mentor programs offered. Good employee recognition programs. Management is open to ideas to improve relationships with our bank customers and most delartments try to intetact well with each other and act as allies rather than advisaries
cons: Seems to be little promotion from within. Most moves to other departments do not involve pay increases but are lateral moves even if greater responsibilties and skills required. Salaries not in line with actual responsibiltes and work done by some departments and associates.

review_title: Always save a paper trail to cover any errors that might come your way
job_title: Client Onboarding Analyst in New Castle, DE
pros:
Is a reliable job
There is some really good coworkers
cons:
There is always someone to put the blame on. I remember my first manager used to tell me you always want to save a paper trail because when the bomb blows you don't want to be the one that is holding the burned paper bag.
The management tend to be unsupportive
Shady individuals
The volume of work is high and it is not enough pay compare to other competitors
The structure of how work is divided is not fair some individuals could get from 50 to 70 deals while other could get 15- 20 deals. 
Management allows for other departments to come down on you. Too unprofessional.

review_title: Horrible work culture and terrible leadership above the branch level.
pros: Branch level leadership is good in most locations and all of the personal bankers and relationship managers are great to work with
cons: Everything but the listed pros. Terrible culture, intense sales pressure, intense pressure to receive perfect customer service scores which fall disproportionately on the tellers (if a client has a bad overall impression of the company or just had a bad recent experience with the company it will be captured in the teller's customer service survey, despite the fact that they may have nothing to do with it), regional level and national management is a joke; I was dumbfounded by the intelligence level and competence of people who run such a large retail bank

pros: Awesome employee culture of acceptance, diversity, and autonomy. Citi is a very employee oriented company that cares about you and your family. Citi provides exceptional care in all aspects of life and wellness.
cons: Even though I received the very rare ratings of 2 and then 1 consecutively, Citi was not able to retain me when my division closed. I feel this is a great disservice to its best employees to be unable to reassign. They told me to keep reapplying for new jobs, but the local recruiters did not know how awesome I was. They lost a highly exceptional employee to red tape.

pros:
-Flexible work (very considerate of work/life balance) and a lot of vacation time.
-Good benefits and opportunities for bonus and merit increases (ranking system to determine this is a bit of a political game, but it's still good money comparatively. 
-Tech org is quite wide, allowing for horizontal and internal role changes.
-Provides a lot of resources for Job Training and self-improvement courses.
-Working for a global entity with instant brand recognition. Opportunities to take part in a lot of Citi sponsored community service and outreach programs.
cons:
-Limited travel opportunities unless you're working on the latest hot item or are Sr Management. Having a Global presence makes for very early and late meeting times to accommodate.
-Senior Management is often contradictory and constantly changing across the board. Makes strategic initiatives near impossible to fully implement as intended.
-Culture has taken a hit with the constant changes in the last 5-6 years.

review_title: Management team was abivalent towards new hires and offered no guidance to ensure success
job_title: AVP, Quality Assurance Manager in Blue Ash, OH
pros: The benefits were outstanding!  22 vacation days, and 12 "personal days" which were to be taken for any given reason...that along with 10 holidays -- astronomical!! They were very concerned with VOE, the Voice of the Employee.  This was a new concept for me as I was surrounded by the mantra "VOC" Voice of the Customer and our bottom line was obviously tied to bringing in new customers and/or clientele.  The Blue Ash facility is outstanding and a real plus to the community.  I think they'll eventually make this facility the de facto Center of Excellence; but it will take time.
cons: The management team in Long Island City was horrendous about assigning responsiblities, guiding new employee's or offering constructive feedback.  I knew that I had made a mistake after just 3 weeks of accepting a job with them.

review_title: Citi is Large, your happiness will depend on which group you work in.
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: For now, we're one of the few I-banks left, and we're quite committed to surviving.  Citi is a large firm with over 350,000 employees, so your happiness will depend on which group you work in.  I work across many of the businesses in a support function and find the folks here in general to be smart and helpful.
cons: I've heard that comp is usually on the low end compared to the Street.  But there's not much Street left now, so......  Compensation will vary dramatically depending on location. New York City pays in commiseration with the cost of living.  The same position in other areas will vary.

review_title: My boss didn't know what I was employed to do
pros: Great team, if you're hired into a good team. But as the managers typically do not care, a bad team rarely gets better. I loved my team though, until things go awry at a much later stage.
cons:
My boss didn't know what I was employed to do, literally. We never communicated, and I only found out when the secretary got my role wrong and insisted that it was my boss who told her.

Hence, no point talking about appraisals..or fair compensaion...or career progression... I couldn't figure what was happening..until..the secretary incident.

And when the boss makes it an all boys club, I should have known better than to have stayed and worked my ass off.

review_title: Great international recognition but the usual workplace politics
pros:
International recognition of the bank and your work
Ability to work with a high calibre of individuals
Excellent mental challenge
Department management very approachable
cons:
Management training is limited to senior management. Low-level management (i.e. team leaders) typically receive no guidance as to how to mentor their junior team members. Some individuals are very good mentors, others are awful. As a graduates therefore your career progression can be a lottery - i.e. it depends on who you get as your direct boss, and often you do not have a chance to rotate around teams.

At times there is a perception that career progression and salary increases are gained by threatening to leave rather than being loyal to the business. A classic characteristic of the financial services industry.

Senior management turnover has been to high in the past

Working in Canary Wharf

pros:
I have been with the company for less than a year and it has been the best job that I have ever had. Competitive salary, benefits, and 22 days of regular vacation time. There are also bank holidays and 6 days of unplanned time that can be used as sick days or when you just need to take off unexpectedly. 

Many opportunities to change job roles within the organization after you have been in your current position for at least 1 year and have had good performance reviews.
cons:
Huge company and it is easy to get lost in the crowd. 

The culture of meritocracy leads people to be very competitive as you are ranked against all of your peers.

review_title: Great Company to work for in the past
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Good salary and benefits including time off! 
Opportunity for personal growth and advancement! 
Most employees are professional, conscientious, hard working and results oriented when properly trained and coached by their  managers.
cons:
In the past the company was one of being known  for taking care of their employees and  customers all while growing their business and bottom line.

Over the past several years they changed many of their senior management team who are all trying to reinvent the wheel. Many layoffs causing remaining staff to be overworked with unrealistic goals.

The staff does not tell management their feelings  for fear of being managed out.
High staff turnover in the branches causing customer dissatisfaction.

review_title: Decent environment  in the investment bank,  but a lot of dead wood
pros:
good benefits ( health care options, 401k  match, etc)
great global reach.  citi has a footprint in nearly every country.
 relatively stable compared to other investment banks
cons: a lot of senior management comes from the Salomon/CitiCorp  days,  and are very far behind the times.  Many wind up being simply cheerleaders or,  worse,  simply bad managers.  Unfortunately,  being on great terms with these dinosaurs is key for moving up

pros:
Global presence gives you global mobility opportunity, exposure and a wealth of knowledge. If you are patient, consistent and willing to pull your weight, you have a great opportunity to succeed.
Citi has many great training resources, which include online and in-class alternatives. These are frequently updated and are available to complete at your own time and pace.
You will meet and learn from a greatly diverse base of professionals that will undoubtly develop you personally and professionally.
cons: Huge companies sometimes have limitations - bureaucracy, lengthy decision making, decisions that sometimes seem unfair. Also sometimes feels as decisions are purely driven by desire to please shareholder instead of client and/or employee satisfaction.

review_title: Experience in IT very good the first 10 years but over the past 5+ years, morale & environment have gone off a cliff.
pros: Opportunities to advance and learn were great.  Remote work option was encouraged from upper management on down (within IT areas not requiring a physical presence).   Benefits and time off policies are pretty standard for the industry.  Most people work well together (even across disciplines) to get the job done.
cons: Recent management changes placed focus on reigning expenses, with an increased focus on personnel (versus productivity, automation, etc.).  This has contributed to low morale within IT areas.  Company is focused on moving IT staff to lower cost locations (midwest and overseas) and/or outsourcing certain support tiers.  IT management power structure has shifted overseas.  Trust within regional teams has become a major issue between staff and IT upper management .

review_title: Big Company with typical complexity, but doing good things!
job_title: Senior Vice President in Baltimore, MD
pros: Good health benefits - Vision coverage always gets positive comments from the various optometrist I have used.
cons:
As with any big company, with whom you work will dictate your experience.  I'm blessed with a good boss, but some higher-ups are a bit more closed-off to suggestions and may not be as in-touch with lower level employees as they could be.
Always too busy to take desired training for growth.

review_title: Good people to work with but poor upper management that doesn't care about employees.
job_title: Mortgage Closer in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Enjoyed the festive decorations and atmosphere for holidays and various events throughout the year. Even If you did not feel like going to work that day walking through the front door and hall can lighten and cheer up your mood which is always a good way to start your day.
cons: Too many changes made not enough focus on longevity, just looking for the quick short sighted gain at the expense of employees with little or no care from upper management.

review_title: great place to work and grow
pros: great place to work everyone is very helpful and proffessional and there are alot of opportunities for career growth Great management. Intelligent coworkers. Interesting Work. Allows multiple Work-from-home days per week. My schedule has always been flexible since ive been working here.
cons: parking can be better at citi, there is a high turnover of employees to toher banks for better pay. they start almost every employee as a contractor at first so when you do get hired your eligibilty to be promoted does not incoroparte the time you spent as a contractor. May be losing work from home days soon.

job_title: Personal Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Decent benefits package, with exceptional employee discounts.
cons: You will have your sales stolen, and given to other PB's. This depends on what relationship you and your Manager have. I was personally on both sides of the coin. It is not in your favor either way. In my case, you will be told you cannot take your vacation days, sick time or bereavement for your immediate relative.  There is no support from any level of management. The systems are archaic, at best. "Banker Support" does not exist. You will fail an audit because you will only encounter broken links on the "Citi help site" to access the newest answer...This is because changes occur seemingly overnight. Entire departments will be wiped out from one day to the next, and you will have no one to contact to reach out in order to help your clients. In all my years in banking (10+ years) Citi sets the branch level employees up to fail as no other institution I have ever known. I would not recommend this employer to anyone.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Equal opportunity , lot of responsibility and diversity.
cons: Even unqualified employees are getting responsibilities. They lie a lot and don't work.  It appears only the greedy are getting top jobs. The entire senior managers  are fraud in Asia.  couple of them are bullies and influence others to do wrong things (stealing money) Reporting  to New york was of no avail as they are doing bigger fraud with Bill clintons of the world. Shameless bankers. To call them thugs  is not be a mistake.

job_title: Senior Software Developer in Mississauga, ON
pros: Salary is a little better but that is it.
cons:
1. They are running a sweatshop at their Mississauga office.

2. It has a very bad crowd. People, they talk all the time, they don't even care that they are disturbing other people. 

3.  You don't have a preassigned desk, you have to find an empty desk. You also have to clear your desk after work.

4. Every desk has a VDI and you are supposed to connect to your remote machine with the help of VDI. Everything is very slow, and the machine hangs all the time. Even you cannot connect your headphones to the VDIs.

5. A lot of people do support work and get over 300 emails every day (not exaggerating), bad place to learn anything technical, just remember it is a bank. 

6.  You are expected to work over 10 hours every day.

7. They don't have coffee machines, unlike most companies. 

8. Dirty restrooms,  you will feel as if you are in a public restroom.

review_title: Working for Citibank will give you gray hairs.
job_title: Financial Center Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: There used to be good reasons to work for Citibank but I honestly can't think of one right now. The benefits are good I suppose. Women are granted 100% paid 13 week maternity leave. They have come up with this new comp plan called "Citimax" which is designed to pay people less. Of course, senior management sings its praises.
cons: Micromanagement, micromanagement, micromanagement. Endless firedrills, emails, stupid and ridiculous micromanaged deliverables. It's driving me insane!!!!!! I got screwed out of five grand because management RETROACTIVELY altered the comp plan. Of course, no apologies or hardly even an acknowledgement of how wrong it was.

review_title: Just show up, do your job and not have high expectations of promotions or bonuses and you will be ok
job_title: Short Sale Prospector in Irving, TX
pros: you get major holidays off, recieve decent benefits, work with a diverse group of people, get 5 sick days off a year
cons: Upper Management such a Operation Managers or Directors have no idea of what to do or how to answer their employee's questions. Have no leadership abilities. Very sad situation to be in when trying to accomplish a goal that is set by them when they have no idea of what the employee's job discription is or how to do their job.

review_title: Avoid this employer at all costs!
pros: There are a few good managers and jobs.  Do your homework and talk to people who work there to find one of those areas and you will be fine.  They do exist but are hard to find.
cons: There is constant re-engineering to outsource jobs. All the smart people are leaving in droves. Employees hired off the street for the same job get paid more than long time employees due to salary caps for raises and promotions once you're in.  Idiots, yes men and liars do well here.  I am grateful to have found a new job and get out of there when I did. There's a lot of favoritism and unfair treatment. This is the most dysfuctional place I've worked. It was a great place to work when I started, but not any more. It is sad to see where this company is headed. I used to love my job.

pros: Relaxed work environment, flexible work schedule, excellent 401k match, good to excellent direct management (from an interpersonal perspective), decent work/life balance
cons: You're in the mortgage business, which isn't exactly loved by most Americans these days. Mortgage industry is in a lull and the company reflects the reality of the market. Job is on the line from a quarter to quarter basis. Don't know when it's going to be your turn to get thrown to the curb. Below average pay. Non-existent training. Unlikely to move up in the company. Bureaucratic at times and co-workers can be more interested in being catty and combative instead of getting things done.

pros: One of the best training programs, international opportunities in a very large corporate, Have to maintain a work life balance in a claws and fang environment. Huge resources that can be tapped into and great response from fellow Citi employees, culture is appreciated amongst peers.
cons: Work life balance can be a challenge in some areas. Personal growth is too. Independent thinking not necessarily appreciated. Must be a "company " man to advance.

pros:
Citi sees some of the largest trading volumes of the industry. As such you will get access to every product and trading instrument on the market today. It's a great place to train and learn the ropes. 

To boot, if you do well, you can stay and have a successful career across citi's global footprint, changing cities, functions and rising the Wall Street foodchain.
cons:
Trading margins are shrinking and so it's getting harder and harder to get in the door. The best way is to come straight from undergrad or masters (or quantitative PhD) programs. 

Citi is a large company and so there is a fair bit of politics.

pros:
It is a bank so pays well, despite less so compared to other investment banks.
The location is central.
The building facilities are clean, except for toilets.
Pays for limited private health insurance.
Contributes to gym fees.
Pays less but job is relatively more secure.
cons:
Very MD oriented, you normally have no say or visibility unless you are an MD.
Does not pay bonuses (or very minimal compared to the rest of the industry)
A lot of petty rivalry, going behind people's backs and politics.
Despite the contractual hours, you end up working a lot more due to peer pressure.
Not a lot of chances to progress your career. You have to do the years to get a promotion. It is like the military in that respect.
In certain teams the turnaround is very high due to low employee satisfaction and higher pays in rival companies.

pros:
Conveniently located for buses and trains in Dublin.
I really can't think of any others, of six years here I enjoyed my first six months and my first six months after an internal move.
cons:
Complete lack of a culture - plenty of talk but almost no action. Your employees will ultimately do what you reward them to do and there are precious little
Money - six years without a pay rise (with the exception of an internal move / promotion.
Leadership - It's just non existent. Plenty of managers, but no leaders.
Training - almost non-existent, the online training portal is a jungle. I've never been set any goals or targets as it relates to training. Any courses I've taken have been off my own back having waded through the aforementioned jungle.
There are so many talented people in the organisation who have gone stale due to a lack of direction.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Gray, TN
pros: Citi prides themselves in diversity which is great. They also support the community through volunteer endeavors. They pay is a little better than average as far as Call Centers go. I worked at their call center in East Tennessee. They have consistent schedules and do not do much mandatory overtime, this resulting in good Work/home life balance. The management is decent as well, some are even great. Not all of them are great, but many are. The health Insurance is amazing!
cons: The pay even though slightly better than many of the other call centers in the area, is still fairly low. The work was not fulfilling to me, it did not make me feel like I was making a difference in the world, which is important to me.

review_title: The worst example of H1B  Culture!  Avoid if you are a non-immigrant.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Tampa, FL
pros: There is nothing redeemable about this company from an IT standpoint.
cons:
Everything bad about an H1B 'culture' company.

Like most H1B companies the workforce is underpaid and exploited and the managers (mostly foreign born Indians) are hostile to non-immigrants and operate as if they were running a Mumbai call center.

They will do everything to underpay, overwork, and exploit the working relationship.  When confronted they will lie and/or ignore your emails, phone calls, etc.  This would work well if you were in Mumbai or New Delhi.  However as an American Company they need to do better.

Just do yourself a favor - say no and look for work elsewhere.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Interesting job, good strong process in place. Nice people. Citi  foster a culture in which the best people want to work, where people are promoted on their merits, where we value and demand respect for others, and where opportunities to develop are widely available to all. Considerable management  Flexible Work is a business strategy that enables employees and managers to consider different ways for how, where, and when work is accomplished.Citi enhances its ability to provide employees with the highest technical and professional development training programs available. Classroom training, self-paced learning, accelerated learning paths, and multimedia delivery options are just a few of the learning channels that await anyone with the desire to learn and advance his or her career.
cons: Bureaucracy could prevail sometimes over the real thinking. Inconsistent management decisions would be implemented as the result.

review_title: Not the best place to be now.
pros: Good company, easy to stay for a long time with the company, decent benefits package (at least up to this year, now it costs much more than in the past), still a good amount of time off
cons: Don't plan on getting any advancement or moving to other departments.  Also, if you do manage to work your way up the food chain, you will be paid much less than the new hire doing the same job that is alwasy asking you for help. The rules keep changing, restrictions are making the job more difficult.  Policies keep changing.  Pay is low, difficult to get a bonus, call quality scoring is a joke and almost impossible to pass.

review_title: I hear that back in the 80's Citigroup was a great place to work
pros:
As an officer, received 4wks vacation.
Was able to obtain my series 7, 63, and life and health licenses while there, and Citib payed for the classes.
cons:
The "C" in Citibank stands for change. Ask anyone who has worked at Citib and they will agree.  Just as there is an understanding of what needs to be accomplished, along comes another Sr manager trying to make his/her mark, instituting an entirely different marketing idea; and not necessarily a better one. 

I worked at Citib for 13 yrs, in numerous postitions, and it was a pressure cooker.

review_title: Don't expect any promotions within the Amherst/Getzville Offile
job_title: BSC Analyst IV in Amherst, NY
pros: Great building, amenities, work-life balance (in some departments), large area for parking, great cafeteria and gym.
cons: For the finance group, everybody ultimately rolls up to senior management in New York City.  They rarely promote people in Buffalo and when they do, it is only in title and not salary in many situations.  There is no way to work on career advancement within this office other than being networked into one higher level executive.  Company has a strong NYC bias.  Management moves people around at will without posting and interviewing for jobs.  Many positions do not have formal job descriptions.

review_title: great place to work, great people, but lots of systemic flaws.
pros: good values, will things to get done, great school, good intentions...this place is so big that you can bet your lastdollar, that someone, somewhere, has already done what you are trying to do.
cons: conflicting objectives sometimes, separation of authority and responsibility, broad spreading of responsibility (causes things to fall through the cracks, and the "I thought you were doing it" situation), too many objectives, inward looking, earnings and revenue driven, technologically very backward, huge inefficiencies, lots of talk and little action, undisciplined business reviews, commitments are made but not followed upon...too much employee rotation at senior mgmt level leads to short-term earnings focus and lack of good long-term business building decisions...lots of flaws...but still a great place to work...inexplicable.

review_title: Very nit-picky... Management is never happy...
pros: Great people. The environment is laid back, mostly younger people working there. The salary isn't to bad for this area. I was making $13.75 when I left. The benefits are pretty good too, you get health, dental, vision, 401k, and much more.
cons: Your boss, will never be happy. I felt like I was walking on egg shells all the time. They listen to 8-10 of your phone calls every month. When you times that by 10 - 15 people on a team, you never get time with your boss for training, or mentoring on what you can do better.

pros:
-401k match? Never saw it in my 401k before I left the company, that's why with the question mark.
-commuter benefit
-health insurance within first 30 days
-easy to move up ONLY if you know people, and people is on your side
cons:
-very very very bad management.
-you don't get reward for what you do, but get reward to be favor by your manager
-you will stay on the same position forever unless you know someone
-HR is not an individual decision making on hiring, meaning not being fair, is all about what the manager demanded of  them 
-constantly changing employees, so don't be surprise if you get fire
-reduce of staff, people work for decades there, company has no concern about how you going to survive, is your problem, not their concern

review_title: "Bad Salaries & No good benefits in Chile"
pros:
Working as a team, not competitive at least in our group.
Working from home.
cons:
Under market pay
No career grow opportunities.
No Bonuses.... train people please, not CIti Courses that have no certifications!!
Have to work hard with excess of Hours are not paid, Fridays late working with no life(almost every release).
Don't retain good talent.
Compensation is not always aligned with performance.
HR, that has to help employees, only helps their interests, horrible team.
They ask you to stay late, but when you need to leave early they dont let you.

pros: Holiday pay, vacation pay, Site closed thanksgiving, Christmas Eve, Christmas, and partial day on New Year's Eve. Very generous with time off for active service.
cons: Was promised a $200-$300 bonus based on collections. But what I came to find out is the bonus is based on averages. So the more you collect per hour the better. But what is preventing me from a bonus is my shift that has 2 hours of low call volume. Which means lower collection rates.  And to top it off if you waive late fees you lose any bonus multiplier. Also Citi 40% of the calls consist of "I never received my statement" which means either Citi did not send them, the USPS screwed up or, the customer threw it away.

review_title: Good Place to work in terms of benefits
pros: Great benefits. The company fosters work/life balance, but............ see the comments below in the Cons* section.
cons: Manangement hires you as part-time and are able to have you as full-time but  you don't get full time benefits, and they use the employees and do not value certain work/life balance situations. Certain employees at the branches  should never be promoted to be a branch manager from a Personal banker position just because they are at the same branch. In my experience, the branch manager was not even qualified to hold such a position.

pros: Citi is large and has robust process. You will learn everything you need to know about oiling the machine. You will get to work with interns to Managing Directors.  You will get to work globally and have lots of work and learn.
cons: The company has such a high workload per person that nice people are rude because they are crushed by the volume of work. It is very corporate still and manual. There are times you need to copy the same information up to 3 times. Because of the size approving anything takes time and many people need to be involved

job_title: Financial Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great Experience in Finance. I learned a great deal about the industry. The company is well respected in the Finance Industry.
cons: Very aggressive Culture.  Associates and managers are rewarded only on financial results, not based on how they achieved the results.  Therefore, ethics and doing the right thing are sometimes secondary actions..along with mutual respect.  It is not a surprise that they took such a hard fall during the financial crisis.  The overall business model of the company is to provide good numbers...no matter how you obtain them.

review_title: A great place to grow and be proud of working for.
pros: Excellent management that cares about doing the right thing for customers and employees.  My experience with management was positive.  I was in a position to coach and influence managers and staff and I found it to be easy in most cases because of the atmosphere that management maintained.  Associated were rewarded not only with pay but with praise and recognition.
cons: Frequent change is often difficult for employees and customers.  Understanding  that the industry has been changing and the reputation of banks in general has been poor, it is still not a great idea to make as many changes as occur at Citibank.   Employees and customers are often anxious and frustrated by the changes that seem to happen on a regular basis.

review_title: Good company but needs to move with the times
pros: Friendly team but flexibility changes from manager to manager. Hours are standard work hours not too many late nights. I generally work 8:30 to 18:00. Career progression can be quite good if you get on well with your management team. Basic salary is above average. Extensive facilities in the building.
cons: Poor bonuses in the operations area. Working from home is an option in only an emergency. Systems in the operations areas are very old and lots of processes are very manual. System upgrades are in progress but the new systems don't seem as good as ones I've used in other companies 7 years ago.

pros: If you are looking for exposure to a Global environment, Citi has a presence in many places.  There are opportunities to work with a diverse group of people.
cons:
Citi is consistently inconsistent in how it operates.  The 'get it done' culture has resulted in a patchwork of processes, systems, etc. and it limits their ability to be truly 'Global'.
Citi has downsized & outsourced its Operations & Technology, so that the few knowledgeable, experienced people left are doing the work of many.  The lack of focus & overwork is a disincentive.

pros: The men and women at this company work very long hours to do a good job at what they do. They have many experienced management and technical staff to help the businesses make money as efficiently and highly performing as possible.
cons: There are so many good people working here its difficult to accomplish a single task that does not impact several other tasks and goals.  If you cannot be patient and navigate the various interests involved it can be frustrating but may not lead to promotion in any case.

review_title: Benefits are good. But you pay for it in kind. Long hours, very bureacratic.
pros: Compensation is good. Both Pay and bonuses are higher than market averages. Benefits are excellent - 3 weeks vacation to start with for non officer level exempt employes. Maternity Leave benefits are very good. 100% paid leave for 12 weeks after 1 year of service for exempt employees.
cons: Long hours. Unofficial expectation of over 9-10 hrs per day for middle office type roles. No room for work life balance. Telecommuting and flex work arrangements are not encouraged. No concessions made for Special circumstances or temporary personal life situations. Also difficult to move up unless you are 'in' with the right decision making crowd.

job_title: Technical Specialist in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Great work-life balance. Lots of career-oriented, smart people to work with. Terrific benefits package.
cons: Compensation was far below industry standards and what my peers were making. Promoted twice with any increase in salary. Career mobility options are more limited than they should be for a company of this size, due in part to frequent purges of talent and downsizing. Moving between business areas is almost impossible due to "good ol boy" mentality. Absurdly slow to embrace new technology.

review_title: A great company to complete a career
pros: Citi Mortgage was a good company to work considering the employee benefits and appreciation.  If employee performance was good, the company would reward the good performance with bonuses.  An employee appreciation activity was held every 6 months. This company always kept employees up to date on training and laws that affected mortgage lending and servicing as well.
cons: The company continually experienced computer issues resulting in excessive amount of down time.  Also, some of the leadership took advantage of their positions and did not assist the employees as needed.

review_title: Minimum wage jobs have better working conditions
pros:
Will  get a fancy title
Good 401 K match
Ok benefits to maintain their fortune 500 status
cons: No training at all and you are always at least 3 years behind in the industry.This place has become sliding doors with lot of people leaving the place and management not filling the positions based on cost savings.Oh the positions are out there all the time showing that this place is always hiring.You will know that you are doing the work of five people once you get hired.No bonuses or raises in the past five years.Performance is not valued.Global Talent management is a farce and black and white icon.Wolves all over the place and nepotism to the roost.No value for hard work when it comes to getting rid of people

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
Good salary
Decent benefits 
Great location
Modern building facilities
Good trainers 
Discounted food on premises
cons: If new don't request for holidays or sicks days as you wont get them unless your friends with the management. Need to be curious about some staff members as they will stick the knife in when your back is turned and just be generally nasty for no reason. All political politics so don't expect promotion soon unless your cleaning the bosses car every weekend. Workload is very high compared to most other companies and you seem to never have enough time to complete everything so guaranteed to stay at least 1.5hrs extra a day.

pros: Large company, many community activities. Depending on the department, very good work life balance.
cons: They tend to not care about the employees they have and focus on the outside customers.  If the employees are not taken care of then how are they supposed to care for the customers.  The constant moving of positions to other countries tends to show how un appreciated the employees is.  Regardless of the good job that is being done, they position is moved and the quality of service and work is quickly deteriorates but at the emd of the day it is a save since itsw cheaper wages.  You get what you pay for.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: They will pay you just enough to not insult you for your efforts.  They are generous with "thank yous" and other forms of non-monetary encouragement/praise.
cons: You will be out-earned by anyone in a comparable role with a comparable title at any other institution.  If you're hired low, you will stay low, and they will deny you promotions to prevent having to pay you at the right level.  Promotions are given purely on political grounds and being great at what you do counts for very little.  Very senior people with very little skill make elaborate amounts of money and compensation pools are hoarded by these people.

pros:
United front - everyone at your level has the same issues and so you bond quickly.
Competitive salary.
Good location in city centre
Parking at science park
cons:
Procedures are vague and hard to apply (perhaps specific to my role)
Location - odyssey / science park
No parking - city centre / odyssey 
No communication until the last minute when everyone already knows and have been gossiping about it for weeks.
Some staff are rude and cliquey and when you’re new to the team it can be hard to make friends. I found it ok but I saw my manager who was bought in being excluded by the other managers on the same department.
If you want to do a good job you’ll have to work mad hours. And you’ll be tied to the good app for work emails.

pros: Seems like a good place for junior level people to advance to mid level (in technology). Good place to work if you are an officer or associate level looking to make VP.
cons: Very competitive at the senior level. Big push to downsize in “high cost” locations like New York and London.  Poor bonuses while I was there. When I was a consultant (before converting to staff) they actually cut my rate 14% after being there a year after as an executive decision placing a max rate on all consultants in my group. That was demoralizing.

job_title: Personal Banker in New York, NY
pros:
Management to a certain extent
Occasional events that are fun but far and few between
cons: Systems are TERRIBLE, career mobility is nonexistent unless you want to be a branch manager which is a terrible job, Citi in general has nothing to offer its clients or its employees, upper management ignores glaring problems, KYC unit cripples business, general attitude is to not help anyone whether it’s an employee or customer, new issues literally every day, pay is below average

job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Compensation, Career Advancement.  They pay very competitively to a college graduate looking for his/her first job and there are numerous networking opportunities. Lunch & Learn seminars help individuals network with senior management. The training you receive is very helpful as well. Team oriented environment helps one to get acquainted with fellow employees as well as learn in an efficient matter. There is a lot of flexibility and many co-workers have switched industries, workgroups, or locations.
cons: Some employees are annoying. For example, they do not do any work, but just joke around the entire time.

review_title: It's who you know, not what you know
pros: According to ex-colleagues who had moved on to other banks, Citi Private Bank is comparatively non-political, and truly tries move forward for the business. Colleagues are pretty collegial and open, except for a few mid-level management who can be nasty, as with any workplace.
cons: Despite the usual talk about meritocracy, it really is about being at the right place at the right time for any movement, lateral or otherwise. Being someone's pet also helps.

pros:
Fairly reasonable work  to private life ratio.
You can work remotely at times and thus avoid always having to be in the office.
cons:
Some employees are doing most if not all of the work while others hardly doing anything at all. They are being paid to just show up thereby by placing an unfair burden on others who are forced to work that much harder and pick up more than one's fair share of the workload.
Management is distance and hardly even acknowledges you. Forget ever getting a hello or goodbye if you're not on the VP level or higher.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Florence, KY
pros:
-if you're lucky enough to sit near a window you might get a nice view of the lake
-i honestly have not met a person there that i dislike. most are very friendly
cons:
-very stressful
-clients are extremely rude
-breaks are very short- 1/2 hour lunch gives you just enough time to grab something in the cafeteria use the restroom and get back in your seat. weekends are worse because the caf is closed. if you dont pack a lunch then you get to sprint to burgerking (the only thing close) and jam the food in your mouth on the drive back because if you're a minute late you'll hear about it
-false promises from management- told we could advance within 6 months. once the six months rolled around we were told we have to wait at least a year to advance
-you're surrounded by people but you never have time to talk to them or get to know them because you're on the phone constantly
-the pay isn't that great

review_title: Profitability Must Return To Increase The Stock Price
pros: The new CEO Michael Corbat has the vision to return to a core set of products and services to allow the Bank to make money in the 21st century and start a growth trajectory, but it will take many, many years at the current rate.
cons: Citigroup has not yet determined fully what it wants to be when it grows up. The new economy has them reaching for profitability by cutting products, services and talent. A new strategy is required to create a balance between cost cutting and growth. Right now, the strategy is very much dependent on cost cutting.

job_title: Senior Vice President in Irving, TX
pros: Variety of work. Company supports the community. Flexible work arrangements-easy to work at home. Lots of training.
cons: I worked there for 10 years. Very bureaucratic and difficult to get things done. Constant reorgs, layoffs, shifting priorities and difficult to get resources. It was a job but thats about all I can say. The longer I worked there, the more numb I got to it. Kind of like a lobster in a pot. The water gets warmer, but you don't realize suddenly it is boiling and you are dying. Many years with no increases. Policy is to never give more than 10% increase even when you get a promotion. Better to leave and then come back, than to take a promotion.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Ok pay and good location
cons: Citi is really not a good place for technologists like me. They have archaic systems and incredibly painful bureaucratic processes. It felt like going back in time when I made the mistake of joining - the project I work on had no build automation, no test automation, no documentation, no product backlog and no plan. It was absolute chaos made all the worse by the sub standard hardware and tools we were forced to use. It took months just to get the access I needed to do my job and interacting with the outsourced technology support teams is always a massive waste of time and energy.

job_title: Senior ISO Analyst in Long Island City, NY
pros: Its  a respected global company. Health insurance is good, they are involved with the community.
cons: No room for growth, not every plays by the same rules, no raises, my boss told me I could not use my sick days. Citi has the option to work remote but if you get a boss like mine that only applies to employees who have been there for many many years not newer ones even tough your entire team is mostly remote 95 - 100% remote.

review_title: Worst Processes with respect to HR
pros:
It's a good company to work with respect to -
 a) Banking domain
 b) technical exposure
 c) Good working culture
cons:
Pathetic HR, facilities and finance processes
They don't want to move even a finger. They hardly even acknowledge  your mail and timely action is a luck

job_title: Investment Banking Associate in New York, NY
pros:
- HR really trying to improve employee experience. Amenities being improved, ongoing free professional development classes, revamped office space.

- Culture of keeping employees within. If we lose someone in CIB, we try to find someone within the bank that can fill the role if it makes sense, good for somebody that wants to use a role at Citi as a stepping point to get somewhere else later.

- Balance sheet allows greater flexibility in winning deals
cons:
- Pays on the lower end of street, though not far from average / median

- Promote-when-ready also means you may not get promoted. Also takes an extra year to make VP versus other banks

- Poor IT systems. Spend a lot of time filling out compliance forms and dealing with IT issues from time to time

- Not willing to take too much risk on balance sheet

review_title: Complete lack of work life balance
job_title: FX Analyst in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
Nice work environment
Central location 
Good to put on CV
cons:
Long working hours beyond your contracted hours. You will be expected to stay late every night with no additional pay. There are some there work 11-12 hour days. If you do leave on time you'll be expected to give a reason and made to feel bad about it by management. 
Lack of communication between teams, management, co workers makes working difficult day to day.
Lack of atmosphere, most workers look like zombies and talk like them too, no craic. Any wonder when they work so many hours they aren't getting paid for.

review_title: CTI was a great place to work
job_title: Senior Vice President in Irving, TX
pros: Flexible work hours.  Before the meltdown, ability to transfer between workgroups to cross-train. Most of the people I work with are great, knowledgeable and willing to share their knowledge and help each other out.  My workgroup did not cut the training budget as most others did.
cons: Morale is very low right now due to layoffs 2-3 weeks ago.  Sr. Mgmt believes 50+ hours every week is acceptable.  Due to regulatory requirements separation of duty has put every workgroup in a silo causing 1) no to very little cross training, 2) decreasing the ability to get things done in a reasonable amount of time.

review_title: Former Sales Assistant in PWM Division
job_title: Sales Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Prestigious name brand and great learning experience.  Vikram Pandit seems to be working hard to turn the company around and if you can survive the cut off, it's a great place to learn about the markets.  The atmosphere in the Private Wealth Management division was not too cutthroat and as with most places, there are sociable people as well as the few bad apples.
cons: The culture has an "every man for himself (or every woman for herself)" mentality so if you want a collaborative atmosphere, this isn't the place to be.  As with all banks right now, they are in an unstable state so that's also something to keep in mind.

review_title: Citi - Potential for greatness, but paralyzed like a wooly mammoth stuck in a tar pit
pros:
I believe that someday Citi will become an efficient and streamlined corporation. When this happens, Citi will truly be a benchmark company to work for. 

Citi has a footprint in every market and every product. 

As Citi restructures, there will be much opportunity to make an impact in the future of the company.
cons:
Citi is a tangled beaurocratic and technological mess. This has created a culture where employees are conditioned for process failure, inefficiency and just general complacency.

Brain Drain - many of the bank's talent has either left the firm or is making every effort to leave. 

Future compensation structure is a mystery.

job_title: Senior Director in New York, NY
pros: There is not really many pros given the dismal last 5 years. Once a respected juggernaut now a beaten and bitter shell of its former self.
cons: Citi has spent the last 5 years reducing its staff count from 375,000 to 250,000 employees.  The culture, never a Citi strong point, is a constant slash and burn.  The bank has moved all of their back office operations out of New York and ensure all the highly competent and highly paid employees were laid off in the process.

pros: Paid holiday, sick leave, 2 weeks mandatory paid vacation. Great training and lots of potential if the branch to grow your client base if it sits in a good location. Great hours.
cons: A lot of responsibilities around the branch and some times its hard to focus on sales. Scorecard and bonus is heavily based on random customer survey. The metric of the survey should be adjusted since the 'passing score' is hard to reach. Survey is rated all or nothing. If customer rates you an 8/10, you pretty much screwed. Your ranking is judged by the score of the whole branch. So even if you did great and your coworker got a bad score, it hurts your branch and thus get part of your bonus taken away (up to 10% of your already heavily taxed bonus).

pros: not that I can think of....except bad memories
cons:
I worked as a Universal Banker:-
1. Retail - back then, we were made to stand all day at corporates and malls, begging for people to buy a credit card or loan, like in Ghaffar Market in Karol Bagh
they want 2 files everyday, and they will put you in PIP if you dont meet target for 3 months.
it was an embarrasing job for me.
2. Suvidha (Noida) - I ran away from retail thinking corporate sales might help, it turned out even worse, i was assigned entire delhi as area, which I had to manage from Noida
i used to run like mad dog entire day. the HR people distribute your number to employees and you get calls 24 hours 7 days a week

WORST POINT - you are supposed to come back to Gurgaon / Noida office in the evening even if you are in Rohini - reason - you can not carry client files at home.

It is highly irritating

review_title: Great company to work for just watch which department you go into
pros: Great opportunities, fast pace and company stability.
cons: Depending on which department you are working for it can be a dream job or an absolute nightmare!  If you are not part of the "in crowd" you will be stone walled, ostracized, and down right abused!  I've never worked for a department within a huge organization like Citigroup where people do not take accountability, back stab, and throw people under the bus as the norm.   People seem to be able to talk to you any way they want and you just have to take it.  Abuse is what I would call this particular department within the Citigroup organization.

pros: Institutional structure; generally friendly people; plenty of support if you know how to find it or can get it; room to network with others in this behemoth of a company.
cons: You're immediately thrown into the fire.  There is no process surrounding training and your supervisors are generally too busy to care about you.  It's sink or swim and sinking is generally quick to occur.  Politics is very much the game and if you don't play, leave.  Email "requests" are essentially ways for a party to delegate their assignment away.  All in all, a very stifling institution.  The only good it did was make me realize I never want to work for a conglomerate.

pros: You can truly build a career at Citi. In fact, you can have a wide spread career across several different operations/functions at just one site. You can learn something new everyday even when staying in one role. Huge opportunity for building a network. If you put the time and effort in , it will pay off. I like being challenged at work, so I would certainly recommend.
cons: unfavorable work life balance for many, lots of negative attitudes. high turnover, difficult to retain SMEs at the entry and intermediate level.

review_title: Tough skin needed to work at Citibank
job_title: Commercial Relationship Manager in Washington, DC
pros: The bank offers tremendous advancement potential if you are willing to move to New York.  There are also other divisions that an individual can transfer to.  The bank's brand is extremely strong.  Compensation both monetary and through other benefits is very very competitive.  this is evidenced through the longevity of many of its employees.
cons: Citibank has a reputation for being a "big business" bank and not caring to service smaller clients.  In my experience this is true.  Also, the bank is huge and support for the individual is almost non existent.  One must be completely self sufficient to survive there.  Lower level managers are not that great in my experience.

review_title: Know what you are getting into before you work at Citi
job_title: Finance Summer Analyst in New York, NY
pros: It was a tough time to look for an internship so I accepted the offer because it was the only one I had.  However, one benefit of working for Citi is that it is a household name and people know it.
cons: The company is too large and too political.  Too many fake people work there; people who talk behind people's back.   Vikram should not have brought in all his buddies from Morgan Stanley to run the company, that is cronyism.  That place is not the safest place to work right now.  In fact that is not a good industry to work in right now.

review_title: The current financial climate is not showing Citi at its best
job_title: Vice President in San Francisco, CA
pros: The company is so big that there are many opportunities to obtain a varied work experience.  They company is also very good about providing training, both ongoing and new skill development.  You are also working for a company with international cachet.
cons: It is easy to get lost in the shuffle.  Here, the size plays to the company's detriment.    One could easily feel like a cog in the machine, dehumanizing one's belief in one's self worth.  There also isn't much corporate sense of loyalty.  This is probably pretty true of most large corporations, but consequently, it leads to less loyalty among the employees as well.

pros: The only Pro, I could figure out is the Medical Benefits package.  For those fo you that gave good Pros, you must be in upper management and or paid very well.
cons:
No inter departmental communication what so ever. No Manager wants to talk about or resolve another departments failures in processing.  Way too many people promoted on favoritism/friendships or in general if you have experience you won't be promoted. Citi tends to prefer  hiring outside for managers who tend to NOT have a clue of the industry or any idea of the department they will be managing. However, Senior managment response to questions on bad processes and guidlines????  "It's the Citi way'   what a joke.

I am with Citi currently because there are not many jobs I can go to at this pay scale. I am still trying.

review_title: Citi Cards Jacksonville FL - Sales Operations Mgrs to Director level are the worst to work with.
job_title: Customer Service Sales in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Nice benefits, nice up to date building, family center, exercise & health care advice on site. A cafeteria is available on site as well.
cons: The turnover rate for sales associates is horrible. Upper management  is always getting rid of  slow performers instead of developing them. They expect new hires to come out of training to be sales, compliance, customer service experts yet make them fly through the calls. They require reps to push products on clients that call in and then wonder why survey results are not higher from customers. The reps have bonus money, raises taken away & get written up for not producing enough. They call them action plans or accountability plans and the director or operation manager use them as scare tactics.

pros: Pretty decent hours, No sundays, great bank.
cons:
Management is terrible, unrealistic sales goals. 

My branch is located in a suburban area, but there is no foot traffic! There is a lack of advertisement, which is sad because I actually think it's a good bank. Management compplains about how Tellers aren't get the minimum 2 referrals a day, but how can we if there is nobody in the bank to refer, Management needs to stop trying to assert athority, we know who the boss is, no need to assert remedial tasks. I have had a enough, it's actually not like this is all branches I have actually worked in a few other branches when they were short staffed, and there was no tension everyone did their share, but not where i work, it's dreadful.

pros: knowing you have a paycheck coming
cons: this place treats you like high school, no talking on the floor, no breaks on floor, use the bathroom at break time, no loud talking on breaks, go outside. this place is horrible. they make unrealistic goals that you cant meet. the company is in debt and want you to fix it. the pay is so poor not able to do anything, they will not work with you if you have school,kids, or a life. they want you to have no life. they tell you that you will have a set schedule but soon as you hit the floor the schedule change. constantly lie to employees so they will not quit. they will fire you for no reason the average life of an employee here is 3 months which is sad. i have seen more people get fired from this one job then i have my whole entire life.

pros: This company values its employees and does its best to make working there a pleasant experience.  All managers i was in contact with were both professional and caring.  You also have many opportunities for transfers and promotions. Great benefits and low employee costs for those benefits. Pay rates are very competitive.
cons: I worked as a customer service rep and received recognition for my ability to handle callers and solve their problems. But all phone jobs have time requirements, and i was never able to meet those time requirements.  I finally left when i was overcome by stress.  The company gave me plenty of time to improve my times but, probably due to my ADD diagnosis, i was never able to meet their requirements.

review_title: Great place to work - but great challenges
pros: Great level of talent and professionalism. You can learn so much from working with so many high caliber professionals. Global footprint can provide many opportunities for growth and movement, but you have to work for it. Compensation is also quite good.
cons: Highly political environment particularly in consumer bank. Shrinking footprint in EMEA consumer - Citi is/has exited several markets since the crisis and continues restructuring and reducing staff. Maniacal focus on short-term profits and metrics vs. long term strategy and investment. Since crisis significant shift to compliance risk averse culture makes it difficult to do much of anything. Innovation is very limited playing on the margins.

pros: Large upside potential if you are willing to put in the work. If you can contribute to the team in a unique way, you can be given the flexibility to adjust your job description and directly report to more senior people which equals more visibility and responsibility. The pay was great, too. Analysts, associates, and directors really work very well together, but this is definitely a case-specific, team dependent assessment.
cons: Great performers are rewarded with the highest bonuses, but they won't promote ahead of schedule. An astute employee knows the latter is much more rewarding because (1) your financial earnings power over the long term will be much greater and (2) titles still matter and should reflect the level of responsibility. The hours are long but you have a good amount of flexibility over your daily schedule.

job_title: Ops Support in Rocky Hill, CT
pros: Great company to work for. Co Workers were great and very welcoming. Learned a lot working for Citi. Loved working here
cons: Came up with a no family policy and since my mother and sister worked there I was terminated because of this new rule. Many got grandfathered in but I was not able to because I was not working there long enough.

pros: When I joined the company it was a great place to work.  We were growing and there was a lot of opportunity to advance.  We had good leadership and a good business plan that was understood at every level of the firm.  Pay was above average and co-workers were great.
cons: Everything changed during and after the mortgage crisis.  Many people were laid off and we had a revolving door of leadership and ever- changing strategies.  Company is now getting smaller, closing branches and focusing only on the affluent and lay offs are a regular occurrence.  I didn't want to wait around for it to be my turn!

review_title: If given an opportuntity to work at Citi again I would be more than happy to do so.
job_title: Associate Security Processing Analyst in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Throughout the years I worked with an amazing group of people. Acquired knowledge and understanding of the commodities clearing process.  It was a daily challenge to learn new processes which were also beneficial in my day to day job functions.
cons: In extreme cases of data processing and heavy trading it could have been long days ensuring the job gets done. However there were always unexpected and unpredicted issues which caused management to seek resolutions to avoid next day problems.

job_title: Mortgage Loan Processor in O'Fallon, MO
pros: Cannot think of a single one.
cons: Literally the most stingiest company I have ever had the displeasure of working for. Billion dollar company yet the low ball you in salary (they pay more than $10k less of competitors), cut overtime when pipelines are out of control just so upper management can show their managers how much they saved per quarter doing this, they don't give two craps about their borrowers and they make up absolutely ridiculous and petty guidelines in order to screw you out of a quarter bonus. Currently trying to get the hell out of here. 90% of the dept either got laid off or quit. Oh and after all these ppl quit-Citi had the audacity to go back and ask the ppl they laid off to come back. Who does that? They have posters all over the building that say "Citi, Power of One". Yeah right. Freaking JOKE.

job_title: Senior Program Manager in London, England
pros: Global brand with offices all over the world
cons: Very hierarchical in parts of the business and many incompetent managers.  Many bankers and traders are holding on to what is left of the industry until they get laid off and collect a severance.  The most talented and inspirational leaders have left and probably started their own firm or just retired.  Some good people still remain, but there are many just greedy people that don't have any other industry to go to.

pros: Boost to CV, learn new things, progression and pay rises, everyone is willing to help (mainly as it's easier to help than sort problems by things being done wrong!) received a payrise after 7 months, bonus wasn't great after tax though
cons: Long hours and no overtime pay, be expected to work through lunch, stressful work and high workload, bad training-no formal training just expected to watch others work and be taught by colleagues who are busy. people are friendly but can also be quite 'cliquey', disorganized in terms of making sure systems ect are ready for new starts, those that are promoted seem to have much more responsibility and extra work

job_title: AVP- Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Working in Tech Finance, they are really big on work-life balance.  It is flexible and you do learn a lot.
cons: Management is condecending and they are not as sharp as you expect upper management to be.  You expect a lot of communication and mentoring from a company of this size but there is NONE.  A lot of politics involved in this organization and you can tell that at Citi a lot of the things that happen are based on favoritsm and who knows who.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: I had a great opportunity to work with really smart people and make an impact in a rapidly changing business environment while at Citi CIB.  Employees are given a lot of responsibility very quickly and recognized for their hard work and dedication.  Management was responsive to the team's needs and always collaborated to work through problems or to reallocate work when people were overwhelmed with client needs.
cons: The company is so large; there were many redundant initiatives going on and the company made organizational changes made too frequently; just as people would get used to new management or a name change or a group re-org, another came our way.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Benefits, pay,  time off.
cons: Citi is far behind both large and small lenders.  Their technology is the worst among the major banks.  Mortgage department on a whole different page than the rest of the organization.  Inconsistent management allows employees at one location to not be held accountable while others were held accountable at another site.  No job security even for top performers.  Layoff decisions appeared to be made for legal standards versus keeping the best employees.  Many employees that stay are on written warnings while those let go are strong performers.  Upper management does not seek feedback from employees.

review_title: Big corporate company, its better if you enter through a training program with others to be up to speed with processes
job_title: Banking Business Strategy Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Nice pay, some personal growth out of conflict with senior boss
cons: Terrible work-life balance, unreasonable expectations in terms of time investment, terrible culture that promotes people to be money driven above all and no value for people or anything else. Worked in new years last minute, even though I got a raise in my salary, I was never thanked for it and instead was told that I had to react faster to checking my blackberry on holiday.

review_title: Citibank was a great place to grow and become  banking ninja! you learn how to survive in any banking situation possible
job_title: Personal Banker in San Diego, CA
pros:
great pay
great benefits
some people are nice
cons:
no adequate training
Never leave on time
Set ridiculous sales goals
They are obsessed with HELOC apps and don't care if they close they just want the app.  Even if you reach your sales goals but don't get two HELOC apps you get in trouble.
