They are obsessed with the CITI APP and if your clients don't use it you get in trouble
Once a new month starts they totally forget about everything you did last month or even yesterday. 
Forget about your two 15 min breaks you will never get them.  And you'll be lucky if you get to take your lunch on time.

pros: Ability to build relationships with clients. Good benefits, and time off. There are some very intelligible people here. If you can get a chance to pick their brains you will find out some very valuable information that will take you far.
cons: Micro-managing at times, lack of training, overload of work from assisting other teams due to high turnover. As well as favoritism. Due to high turnover chances for advancement became a joke. Felt trapped on my team because they knew no one else wanted to fill my slot.

review_title: HR is terrible and treats us like slaves
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Name recognition, decent respect outside of the US.
cons: Low pay. Managers have to get approval to give salary increases fro HR. HR treats us like slaves. Officially Citi is all about fair pay but in reality they love underpaying folks. Very shameful considering Citi is a signatory of UN Global Compact. Double standard! I would not be surprised if managers get compensated for keeping pay low for their workers.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Plenty of room to grow in many directions. The size of the firm allows for many possible career paths.
cons: The culture is so thick, you need a knife to cut through it. Very difficult to get things done. Politics rule the day and everyone is only interested in covering their behind. Red tape everywhere. A normal request that used to take hours 10 years ago now takes six months to complete.

review_title: Smith Barney - A great place to work.
pros: Opportunities to move around within the company because it is so large.  Lots of perks from deals with all sorts of vendors.  Good software in place to get things done easily.  Flip side is sometimes overly complicated compliance procedures due to wariness from 2000-02 downturn.  Guess it wasn't enough considering what is now happening.  There are some type A jerks there but that is the case at any financial firm.  Overall it is a good experience, lots of good people there.  I think they are going to have to change their model going forward just like Merrill, Morgan and the rest because they were clearly some of the biggest losers from the recent downturn.
cons: Sometimes moves too slowly due to size.

pros: It is usually a stable company, but as of late it has not been so much. So, the reasons are going away fast.  There is generally a comfortable work environment, lunch room in the building and mandatory breaks and lunches, which you do not get in a lot of companies. I would say citi is a good place to work for, but I would also look in other areas.
cons: Chances for layoff, poor potential to move up. Often poor management due to the size of the company. A lot of unhappy employees due to reasons I stated above. Salary could be better and more on par with other companies.

pros:
the team was great, very helpful, always ready to answer any questions. Our manager was very approachable with any concern regarding performance and overall feedback; supervisor teams the same way. 
Great atmosphere, great over-time pay. 
Good advancement opportunities.
cons:
Vacations needed planned in almost a year ahead. 
Any last minute emergency was not really appreciated as the call volume would increase and team performance would drop.
Culture was very lazy, people with absolutely no life goals surround you in every department and majority of co-workers felt to me as they were scared of expressing their true opinion about certain management issues and overall new rules. 
Paid maternity leave was horrible, especially if you are already pregnant when you join (had 2 girls in my team, different stages in pregnancy and each pay was worst than the other)

review_title: My career at Citi was frustrating.
job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros: As a large and global company there were endless internal options for positions. Compensation levels are competitive. The office setting was always modern, and technologically advanced.
cons: Too big to manage, very political. So large that few people feel connected to success or failure. Work/balance ratio is awful. The previous pre-Sandy Weill culture was destroyed, and the new culture rewards outside relationships over performance. Employment policies that had existed for over 15 years of my career were eliminated in days, with no grandfathering in place for previous loyalty.Older employees, at the middle management or below levels are stripped of their importance and made uncomfortable in the hope they will leave.

pros: The best thing about working at Citibank are the extras which can be considered alongside a resonable salary. Every branch has a social committe who encourage employees to partake in a variety of social events. During my time there I enjoyed a range of activities which are subsidised by the firm; coctail making classes, bubble soccer, soccer team, summer barbecue, cycle tro work schemes, gym schemes, health schemes etc. The working environment itself is also social, usually focusing around team-based work.
cons: Can be long/stressful working hours. As a software engineer based in Production Support it was required to stay after hours should there be a production issue. With time-in-leiu or pay benefits only being offered in exceptional circumstances (10+ extra working hours per week). Due to large number of low-seniority employees, often found those deserving promotion being overlooked.

pros: Great company goals, great products as well as incentive plan. The training is amazing with great motivating staff.
cons: I had terrible management and i saw a lot of unhappy employees and people who did a lot of unethical selling just to get points and make money. But upper management pushed for more sales so how do you make them if no client really has a need? You force them to get a credit card even though they dont need one. You open more accounts even though they dont need them. Its not ethical banking.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Florence, KY
pros: This company provides flexibility in many ways, allows people to move to different positions and learn new things. Benefits are good. Company does giveaway contests and nomination contests. Remote or work from home positions in upper level positions and some customer service roles.
cons: Manager deliverables are unrealistic leaving no time for people management. Process knowledge does not equal leadership skills when promoting people into management positions. Internal promotions offer little to no salary increases. Reactionary vs proactive throughout departments.

pros: Benefits, Brand, good place to bank in, not so much to work in. If you have a good team or make a good team out of the one you have, you can have a positive workplace
cons:
Lack of life work balance, 
Do most of the work that's not part of the job description that doesn't pay.

pros:
Pay was good, additional earnings if you worked 2nd shift. Commission 
Great support from everyone at the start during the training period.
cons:
The job is very stressful. You are always monitored, you are working with a system that is almost impossible to navigate. After the training period its impossible to find reliable help from others to assist you when you don't know how to do something. 
If you can deal with not being able to help most of the people you talk to while they get mad that you can't help them then this is the place for you.

review_title: Unethical Hiring Practices across the company
pros: Work Life balance, benefits, vacation time, flexible work hours.
cons: Rampant Nepotism while hiring, Unethical hiring practices, HR department is a total joke, recognition and promotions only to certain races, work visas for friends and relatives only.

pros: I love Citibank and everything they have to offer. They treat their employees well with great benefits. I learned a lot in my time there and started as a teller and became a banker after 2 years (I could have moved up before that, but chose not to). Paid vacations and federal holidays, 6% 401K matching, and maternity/paternity leave. Get both monthly commission and quarterly bonus.
cons: Compensation changed yearly and sometimes quarterly, for the worse never seems like for the better. Commissions and bonuses seem harder to get as time passes. Hard to move up after Banker, not many other avenues to go because the corporate offices are hard to get into if you have little experience.

review_title: Citi is a frustrating place to work!
pros: Citi is a large company with great brand recognition.  Until the recent financial melt down, I was proud to work for Citi and having Citi on my resume was a huge bonus.
cons: Citi is so large that the left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing.  There are a lot of good things but too many bad.  Because Citi is so big, it costs a lot of money and time to fix an issue or implement a new technology.  Citi no longer has the money and we never have the time.

pros: Large stable company with hefty compensation packages.  The idea of working on very large scale systems supporting mission critical financial services can be a nice challenge.
cons: Executive team had little care of real issues and focused strictly on cost per head count regardless of any other factor.  The technical teams in Dallas and St Louis had resigned to a life of not caring anymore.  The company lacked any kind of energy, with most employees readily telling you they are there to collect a check.  We saw critical system fixes delayed 9 months because no one wanted to actually do the deployment.

job_title: Vice President Decision Management in Long Island City, NY

pros: Package, if you want it - go for it
cons:
1. They will tell you it's a development role while interviewing, while once you are inside they will give you production support
2. They will make you work in shift, while avoiding calling it shift job
3. They call it a captive and CoE, while the senior management thinks of it as a support center
4. Main work in US, only support functions are coming to India
5. Work - Life balance - Non-Existent
6. Indian HR is under the US manager. They have no voice
7. Very confused about if they are a product organization or a service organization
8. Employee satisfaction - NIL
9. Employee support - NIL
10. Employee care - NIL

review_title: Conforms to traditional ways and fails to promote or reward innovation.
job_title: Technical Analyst in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: The only thing I enjoyed about working at Citi was getting paid - that part they are good at. Most of my colleagues were excellent folk too.
cons: Non technical career bureaucrats that rode on the backs of excellent engineers to further their own agenda whilst falsely promoting a team environment. Little room for innovation and they hired more of the same types as those getting themselves somewhere. Heavy politics and low staff morale for those teams who suffered. I never saw so much ass kissing by adults in my 20 years in IT.

review_title: Declining quality of leadership/management and excessive politics
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good online and class offerings. Big company, many opportunities. High diversity
cons: Constant layoffs, high frequency of changes, no information sharing/transparency, very long work hours with no support and/or appreciation from senior management. E.g. Took a week vacation after over 8 months and every day on my vacation i had calls and texts from my colleagues/manager. Even after being on call/responding texts back at work on my vacation, I came back to work to find out all my work were messed up. I had to catch up and fix everything on my first day back to work working till midnight. Very incompetent management and senior mangers does not care anyone below VP/SVP. Good work is not communicated to senior mangers by immediate manager. Excessive politics and self interest. Full time employees are replaced by contractors.

review_title: A great firm to learn the business, but the culture needs work
pros: There are opportunities galore for learning and growth, but you must find the right people to sponsor that growth.  Overall, I had a great experience working there, but ultimately my career reached a plateau.
cons: If you are not from an ivy league school, your upward momentum will be stunted.  The firm is so large and highly bureaucratic, so its often difficult to get things done in a reasonable amount of time.  The culture has a mix of highly volatile people with some really great people, upper management consists of many former Lehman guys mixed with people from other firms and, as a result, there's a lot of fiefdoms and the culture has suffered as a result.

job_title: Branch Manager/Vice President in Arlington Heights, IL
pros: Competitive pay and benefits. Generous vacation time of 4 weeks.
cons:
Terrible internal systems, company is stuck in the 80's, not allowing to help customers and have to jump through hoops to accomplish the simplest task. Unethical sales practices are visible everywhere, even though company claims to frown upon it, they structure compensation to push bankers and managers in the unethical direction, which is unacceptable. 
Company is solely number focused and do not care how you obtain them, raising the bar every year, and asking you to beat last years figures, by any means possible. Training is absolutely horrible, unorganized and completely useless. Even if you are an experienced manager, you are on your own figuring out the systems, policies etc.

review_title: Pay not competitive but environment is nice
job_title: Risk Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Not as stressful as people perceived.
Working hours are highly dependent on your role. 
Mobility is really good, especially for those who wants global transition.
cons:
Pay is not the same to JP Morgan or many other banks. 
Sometime it feels like your future/pay/raise/job is dependent on how the senior view the business that year. 
When time is good, they cut cost less, and time is bad, they REALLY cut cost. 
Don't expect ridiculous bonus either.
Certain function you will see kids fresh out of college with 2 years of experience getting automatic promotion to Vice President. and at others function you see people with 7 years of work experience, from great colleges, work on much serious role, only then promote to VP. It's a big big organization, these things happen really often

pros: I would like to say that there are good times working for this company! But I can’t! You’ll walk in healthy and walk back out sick.... Citibank is nothing but a sham, a shinny star looking good from the outside but darkness on the inside... I’ve made one or two good friends at the company, but that’s about it
cons: I would never encourage anyone to work for Citigroup unless you want to stay in the same position..... the management is nasty and all about themselves, it doesn’t matter how good you are they always reward the ones like, plus! If you work at a bank where there is a Spanish manager! He or she would always hire Spanish speaking people and speak they language around you even though they know it’s against company policy to do so

review_title: Citigroup - too big but also a place of opportunity
job_title: Senior Vice President  in New York, NY
pros: A large place with many different things to do, for those interested.  It's what you make of it.  There is no shortage of opportunities, but you need to be on the lookout for them -  take the initiative, talk to people and proactively seek new positions.
cons: Can be very bureaucratic.   Layers upon layers of people in some cases.   It often seems there are many people whose sole job is tracking abnd reporting on the few who actually do anything.   Very over-staffed, and managers defending their turf.

review_title: People always get work done but run into down-turns on re-organization of the company
job_title: Senior Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
The team you work with is excellent and people really work as a team. There are very senior team members at Citigroup that are helpful and provide good mentoring of junior team members whenever required. Management also came up with a plan to talk to individual employees as part of their 'lunch meetings' which was a great idea to talk directly to management. 

Overall, a great place to start your career but make sure if this is your first job, you at least look around to understand the importance of the people you work with and respect the company. I was happy at Citigroup from work/life balance, but pay scale was below average.
cons: Current market turn-around and lot of re-orgs.

job_title: Call Service Representative in Columbus, OH
pros: Management does a good job of communicating with employees and asking for feedback.  Opportunities for advancement were clearly communicated and fostered.  Annual reviews were completed on-time and the overall atmosphere was positive.  Emphasis was placed on customer service and many initiatives were designed to improve client retention.  Many formal internal training programs were available for employees.
cons: Salary is not up to industry standards.  Top management was not well qualified and industry savvy.  So much emphasis was put on shareholder value and quarterly earnings reports that the long-term vision was ignored.  Not enough was invested in the future since the future was the next quarterly report.

pros:
Global bulge bracket IB
Good to get experience at a junior level
Global network able to be leveraged on both a regional and a local basis
cons:
Negativity sentiment towards the brand as a result of GFC
Poor management performance at all levels
Overly rigid process of reporting through NYC - lack of regional autonomy
Promotions based on ability to "brown-nose" rather than any inherent capabilities - in fact often it was the reverse
Lots ot pitching, not enough live deals
Excessive in-fighting when it came to revenue allocation as it drove end of year comp reviews

review_title: Citigroup & Wall Street - Is it all the same?
pros: Flex hours, work from home when needed.
cons: Benefits get worse every year, it's a race to zero.  No growth, no bonus regardless of performance.  Bell curve evaluation process, somebody must get a poor review even if everyone performs well.  New hires are over compensated with lofty titles and bonus guarantees, while existing loyal performers get no growth and no bonus.  Toxic work environment, when the going gets rough, the fingers start pointing.  Lot's of in-fighting and empire building.

review_title: AML is a tough place to make it.
pros:
- Interesting groups of people
- Trainers are nice
- Potential for growth
cons:
- Was brought in as temp so no benefits
- If falling behind in casework, no additional training just let go
- Quantity is valued over quality.  If someone is faster but has a lower accuracy rate, they're still on as opposed to someone with a higher accuracy rating but few cases done.  It's a case by case basis so it's not a real fair standard.

review_title: Tough environment, but the challenge made me a better employee!
pros: Benefits package comprehensive and pricing to employee(s) fair.  Proactive with FMLA and disability issues.  Working environment well spaced, well lit, and generally quiet for this type of business.  Centrally located in the DFW metroplex, outstanding cafeteria, clean breakrooms, close to external food services.  Generally speaking, treatment of employees was fair and very respectful.
cons: Long hours at month-end, month-end close.  Long hours at mid-month.  Occasionally these long hours interefered with attending college courses at night.

pros: Work life balance is equalized. The vacation and holiday benefits are on the higher end in relation to other companies in the area.  Low stress job, with a steady amount of work.
cons: No clear career path for a web designer.  All web designers these days are developers.  Yet, we are treated like salespeople.  Projects involving the non web designers never start with web designers involved, we are constantly asked last minute to perform miracles.  There is no one in our company hierarchy that can be viewed as a mentor, or someone to help you improve your skills.

review_title: Large company that puts profits over people. Company culture that DOES NOT promote empowerment.
pros: Good benefits, salary was above average
cons: Worked in the HR department - there was poor communication and the directors were not current on state employment law which lead to poor decisions.  Managers/Directors had favorites, if they didn't like you then you never received recognition or special projects.  Favorites were always kept during layoffs even when they performed poorly.  Favorites were also promoted over other qualified candidates

review_title: Good Experience but Left A Lot To Be Desired
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
Friendly colleagues - collegial and collaborative culture; there is a discernible Citi community where people come together across common goals and values.  
Flexible work arrangements i.e., work from home possibility, etc. 
Good communication from senior mgmt
cons:
Compensation is static.  Raises were hard to come by even for top performers.  Bonuses were up and down.
Morale was low due to comp issue.
Technology is a bit outdated as is the case at other firms.  A bit of a disconnect between Tech / IT and the business.
Organization is just too massive which makes it difficult to wade through the many layers to get things done.

review_title: Not for College Graduates; Extremely high turnover
pros:
Work-Life balance
Training
Friendly People
No at-home work
Part time employment
cons:
Politically based.
Hard work is looked over.
Part Time employees are better off as the incentive check will equal what a full time employee does.
High Turnover with no replacements.
New hires are stuck with weekend work with no adjustments.

job_title: Mortgage Loss Mitigation Specialist in Alexandria, KY
pros: Good and clean work environment
cons: Expectations for talk time were unattainable with all the verifying and updating required on each call.  Then there were constant changes that were not always relayed or relayed effectively causing reps to fail calls.  The work load was too high for the pay. Then they take away one of our main tools for making bonus by giving it to Customer Service as well and then start laying us off. Terrible planning.

pros: The benefits are good, great relationships with some customers, office is clean and spacious.
cons:
This place is a joke. They overwork, underpay employees. Managers are uneducated for the most part, and are only promoted based on their numbers. The problem with that is that now you have managers (who make around $70-80k) stealing loans from their employees (who make $30,000) and bullying them into staying quiet, probably because they're used to selling and selling by all means necessary. There's no work-life balance to speak of (it's just work) and good luck getting promoted regardless of how well you do. My personal advice is you're better off somewhere else. 

Another "con" would be interest rates and insurance. You're definitely a predatory lender when you lend someone $7,500 and expect them to pay you back $22,500 over 5 years.

review_title: Great company with good benefits, beware layoffs and new departments.
job_title: AML Compliance Analyst in Irving, TX
pros: Great benefits and an HR department that looks out for the employee. You'll never feel more secure knowing that you will be taken care of by HR. Great people work here, leading to a fairly relaxed atmosphere.
cons: Unfortunately layoffs come around every so often, be prepared. New departments that come in lack direction and struggle to find pacing and footing. Although these are expected challenges, it sets a bad precedent from the start in a new department.

pros: Generous pension, free health & doctor on site, gym, good canteen food, intelligent global team, flexible work hours, good view.
cons: Long hours, USA focus, worked on a global team & there was not always consideration that I wasn't in New York, grey cubicles are so 1990's.

review_title: surprised we are still in business
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Hagerstown, MD
pros: Benefit time is amazing! I get tons of time off each year due to my tenure
cons: Unrealistic sales goals, quick to take earned commission if you are .001% shy of meeting a goal, off shore agents monitor our calls and interpret things differently therefore causing us to get hit on call monitoring which results in negative scorecards and potential commission impact.  No growth potential at Hagerstown location. Continuously closing depts and transferring to other locations. Closing buildings and minimizing the work area.

pros: Very few pros. The only thing I can say it is good to have it in your CV to get a better job.
cons:
The bank is for people who wants to be a slave to his manager. Never question anything. Never raise their opinion. The bank has no REAL diversity at all. It is more as Group 1 are against Group 2 which Group 3 is helping Group 1. I don't advice anyone to work in this unethical Bank. 

The bank claims they have a great ethical standard but the truth they don't. If you raise an ethical issue against anyone as soon as the other person has stronger connection you will not be able to do anything about it. If you raise an ethical issue it just gets forwarded to HR or they call it ER and they support the managers to frame it in a way that you are not correct.

review_title: A great company that lost its way, and trying desperately to find its roots.
pros: In this market climate, size matters.  It is as difficult a market climate as I have seen in 18 years of doing this.  Citi has screwed up so much in the past 8 years, it should get better from here, right?  Past management blew it, current management is trying hard to put us back together again.
cons: Always in the news and usually with negative headlines.  My clients realize that it is a huge company with a big footprint, and with a shoe size that big, the company is bound to step in it from time to time.

review_title: HR department is one big dominatrix warehouse.
pros: Large company with many different types of positions. Depending on your job, it’s relatively easy to transfer to other cities and maintain salary/employer history.
cons:
> The HR department is run by women who have made it their mission to keep men out of management positions. 
> Too many businesses trying to distribute their services/products through the financial centers. 
> Very complicated variable compensation plans, that change yearly.
> Sales goals are NOT sustainable year over year. A great year must be followed by a bad year to reset your sales goals to an attainable level.
> To many bonuses are tied to group effort which penalizes a top performer in a poorly producing financial center.

review_title: Citi life has it's ups and downs.
job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The benefits and salary were well above industry standards. Having this company on your resume will open doors for you. It is nice to work with some of the smartest people in the industry. The work environment is nice. There is a lot os potential for growth.
cons: A lot of colleagues and managers had superiority complexes. A lot of management was not a approachable and managed through fear. It sometimes felt like high school with all of the cliques. They did not really try to make new hires feel welcome. Long hours, but worth the benefits.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Best reasons include: much learning is done on the job. A person will grow with much Business corporate experience, senior management is generally available to provide advice and nuture growth. There is a good dept culture within teams. Peers work hard to help one another in order to get the job done. Management takes into consideration family & outside responsibilities and community involvement is welcomed.
cons: Downsides included limited room for growth currently. Many layoffs and low pay compared to other financial industries. Employee turn over would minimize if salaries were at least within the range of other industries. Currently 401k matching is down, tuition reimbursement is down & salary increase are very low. Citi is losing many good people - while upper management continues to get larger salary increases.

review_title: Decent pay, but company overall cuts corners
pros: Pay is good, benefits are decent and bonus structure is fair. You can work in your position forever unless they have lay offs which usually only happens in the back office. Most of the employees I know have been there forever.
cons: The company cuts corners and does not spend to advance technology. The systems are horrible and everything is outsourced, so communication between different departments is horrible. This leads to poor customer service. They are slow to hire new employees when needed, so the work load is huge on the existing employees and the customers receive poor/slow service.

review_title: Citibank is a great place to work, if you are one of the top performers.
pros:
Performance based promotion criteria.
High flyers get rewarded.
Not stingy with recognizing when work is well done.
Great training and a lot of personal development opportunities.
cons:
Since is multinational, poor performance in other countries can affect the increases/bonuses that you get, even if your country's performance is better than the rest.
You sometimes have to know the right people to get things done.
There is a tendency for one to get pigeonholed as an operations person, or marketing person, making it harder for people to transition to different job functions.

pros:
Good starting salary (few raises after, though)
Opportunity to travel
Great co-workers
Loyal workers
Great reward program (for employees/customers) in Thankyou points
cons:
Too much middle-management that creates unnecessary work so they can justify their jobs. 
Too much middle/upper management that is clueless as to the reality of their retail branch system- doesn't ask for input from those on the front lines
A lot of "feedback" surveys that are a waste of time. Again, people job-justifying, but not caring about what they're told.
Very goal/money driven, to the point where employees do things that may be unethical in order to meet goals. (usually given the behind-the-scenes nod of approval by whomever they report to...until caught)

Quietly slinking out of Philadelphia market due to horrible locations, and no support system for the market by way of advertising etc. Disgraceful.

review_title: Good company but it seems that at the end of day, you're just another number.
pros: Citi provides you with great benefits as well as wonderful co-workers to help you in need.
cons:
Tellers do most of the work and are paid the least.  You're expected to answer the phone even if you have a line of customers.

Management expects you to walk in the first day and know everything and when you ask a question, you get looked at like you're incompetent.  That's where good co-workers come in.  Managers don't want to bother babying you.

They care more about KDS than anything else.

review_title: The last company I would recommend working for.
job_title: Associate Operations Support Analyst in New Castle, DE
pros: Good soup in the cafeteria.
cons: Highest turnover of any company I have ever worked for. No employee moral. Work is thrown on you in abundance and expected to be completed in very narrow deadlines. Client interface is very chaotic. Minimal training provided. Only one or two people out of a whole team, including team leads, are the least bit knowledgable and worth going to for questions. Otherwise, its practically a guessing game. Pay is also very low compared to other banks. Management is very impersonal. Waited a full 3 full months to even speak with my manager for the first time and even then they still appeared miserable on a daily basis. In addition, after leaving the company, they continued to pay me by mistake and I have to repay the gross amount back, not the net which I received. I recommend to avoid this company at all costs.

review_title: CITI never sleep and never let its emloyee to :)
pros:
- No Swipe in & out 
- Good Pay during Joining
cons:
- Pathetic Work Culture
- Promise lot of thing during joining but will give only baba ji ka thullu.
- No time tracking because u always have to complete 12 hr as lot of garbage is der to clean
- Job Mismatch
- No Car parking they are reserved for higher people only
- Worst transport facility
- No bonus, only promised during joining
- Interview are really  easy to crack so you will smart enough which type of team member you will have.
- Pathetic hike as compared to other IB

review_title: Great company if you are in the right team
pros:
-  Global reach - opportunity to work with diverse teams and clients
-  Great people and talent if you are in the right team
-  Good entry level programs with decent mobility options
cons:
- Tends to be highly bureaucratic - decision making could be slow
- High turnover with lack of consistent leadership;  like most financial services, can fall into the trap of  being very short term focused
- While the large size and global reach create opportunities, the company starts lacking consistent culture
-  The company could better manage talent by promoting an apprenticeship culture and give more opportunities for developing skills

job_title: Senior Quantitative Analyst in London, England
pros: Relaxed working environment for a bank, without the work culture of excessive hours which sometimes exist in investment banking.
cons: Terribly outdated technology stack.  Many parts of the code base have code written over 20 years ago.  The general monolithic nature of the software libraries have unfortunately created an environment in which it is very hard to be productive.  This is unfortunately accepted as the status quo with little desire from senior management to change this.

review_title: Working for Citi is as good as you can stand it.
job_title: IT Analyst in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: The benefits package has been very very good throughout the years, although it has also gotten more and more expensive.  It pays well but expects 150% for that payment.  Do not start there thinking it will be a breeze, it is not.  No one has been treated well, and they are all more than willing to share the misery.  But like I said it pays better than most places in this town.
cons: Long hours, expectations from management that are unclear, senior management seems unclear on anything.  Rewards are few, and are given to the people who promote themselves the most, or the people whos management takes the time to recognize them.

review_title: Pros & Cons, but needs some help
job_title: VP, Marketing Manager in New York, NY
pros: They offer great benefits and time off.  Five to six weeks for most everyone was great!
cons: Well, you must be a favorite to get promoted.  And these days you seem to need to be the right color to be a favorite.  Not to say other weren't promoted, but most of the folks who move up after I left were all part of the same group.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: There is an excellent opportunity for advancement. Their training is very thorough, although some people tend to get left behind. In my opinion, most of those who do get left behind were not good fits for the job in the first place. Those that do make it through training, and the first 90 days of employment tend to be very successful. If you can tough it out in an entry level position you can work your way through the ranks.
cons: As stated previously it can be a grind to get a chance at promotion. But like most jobs that's just the way it goes. Senior management makes attempts to give employee recognition, but a lot of the time it as seen as cheesy.

review_title: Used to be good, now its a dump...
job_title: Personal Banker in New York, NY
pros: Citi offers good benefits and if you are a new hire you will get paid much more than an existing employee
cons: You will need your benefits to handle all of the stress that comes along with the job. They expect you to be at work at 8Am and stay 3 hours after your workday is done (8pm) in order to make phone calls. New management does not care or value their employees. Loyal employees that understand the business and culture of the bank are paid way less than the new hires whom you are then asked to train. Turnover is excessive, in the past year 70 percent of the staff at my branch has either resigned or tranferred elsewhere only to deal with the same issues. In all honesty Citibank has turned into a big dump..... Retail without folding clothes

review_title: Very disappointed, that after years of dedicated service I was cast aside for a few dollars in savings.
pros: Good Pay, Excellent benefits, Many hard working dedicated employees.
cons: Very Long hours put in will go unappreciated. Upper management will give you lip service, but as I found out, it really means nothing. They Claim to care about their employees, especially long term ones, but at the end of the day all they really care about is the bottom line.

pros: Pros are the benefits such as being able to wear jeans to work, their contribution to dependent care expenses/day care, contributions to health savings plan account, and matching 401k up to 6%.
cons: My job responsibilities have been constantly changing on a weekly basis regarding what is required of me.  They keep giving us more busy work to do that doesn't have any point (repetitive tasks) and tie it to our quarterly compensation.  They've made it harder and harder to bonus out with unrealistic expectations.  It's a moving target that has become a major source of dissatisfaction.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lima, Lima Region
pros:
Compensation is superior to the market average (related to the amount of work done)
In retail banking no one gets killed if you dont reach the business goals, so less stressful than other banks i have worked for
If you complain about a superior to HHRR, you will always be right
It is possible to have a life in this company
You may complain to HHHR if you dont like your goals.
cons:
In Peru,the retail business has not been doing good for years which has resulted in the cutting off of relevant managers and left the business to unexperienced executives. 
Long time citibankers cannot accept comparing themselves to local competition. Lots of arrogance gives awful results.

job_title: Personal Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits, awesome culture for a bank and supportive management. Ethical sales is taught everyday and management will not pressure staff to sell just to meet goals. The entire organization, worldwide, is on headed in the same direction and executives have been very clear and communicative about their plans for the future.
cons: Citi is moving away from mass market banking and developing a niche as the world's affluent bank. That brings a lot of pains and changes that are difficult but everyone stays positive. Some of the people in the retail banking, particularly one's who've been at Citi for 10+ years, are happy with their positions and just want to keep doing what they're doing. Then there's some who just won't work for what they want. Weird, but upper management is supportive.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Citibank was a relatively low stress work environment. After coming from Wells Fargo which was a truly horrific experience, Citibank offered less stress, higher base salary , better hours, and much more control over how much commission is earned. The commission structure has changed for the worse since I started, but still features monthly commission instead of that quarterly crap.
cons: There are many things going on at the upper management level that cause concern and unrest. I was laid off as a result. As far as working for citi, the biggest flaw Is that there is little room for growth within the branch. The company prefers to hire externally when positions arise. This caused many branch members to become complacent and unmotivated.

job_title: Bank Teller in New York, NY
pros: Horrible there are no pros . By far the worst job .
cons: Horrible hours for part -time employees high hourly pay rate but if you don't have any hours you make the same salary as a minimum wage employee no offense .They don't care about employees and will drop you at the drop of a dime . Stay away from this company. I worked at this company for a year and half the worst they accidently over paid me and made me pay them back which wasn't my fault. The managers don't follow policy and if they give you permission to do something and it goes bad you will take the fall . Co-workers gossip about one another all day . management treats you like a slave .

review_title: My Time as a Mutual Fund Analyst
job_title: Mutual Funds Analyst in New York, NY
pros: I was in several different departments in regards to Mutual Funds, and overall upper management was very good, the pay was excellent and I worked well with everyone and made quite a few friends along the way. The hours were great and the work was challenging,which I really liked.
cons: In my final mutual fund department, it didn't start out that way but lower management was not so, consistent. They were all hired as a group from another company and we were doing the work of forty or more people as a much smaller group. It became much harder and even more unpleasant.

pros: benefits were decent, but our costs went up.
cons: bonuses cut, this was at least 2/3 of my salary.  Jobs cut and assets sent to outsourcers to manage, depart closed down for the most part.    Difficult manager, merit increases were nonexistent due to being in the higher salary range, although those salaries were never published, so its just their word, very demanding workload due to high volume of employees having left.  over 10 years working there and seen several employees with over 25 years let go.   I worked hard to save Citi money,  just one week I saved them over 50,000 in HOA fees, no good job or thank you, no bonus, no merit increase.   After 10 years,  I was making less and working harder than when I started,

pros: The branch employees really tried to give their best. There was absolutely nothing good about working for this branch in Rego Park.
cons: If a manage states in what they call a “hurtle” that “you can flip burgers at McDonald’s” just to coerce his/her authority. What else can it be expected of the overall work environment? Managers would do the impossible to please customers who are racists, just for the sick of a key driving scores which affects the managers’ bonus. This may be perceived as a private wrong as one might say well, it might had happened in one occasion. However, in this particular branch,  it happened all the time, and the managers pretended like nothing was happening, or corrected the employee. Managers should be there to increase potential and not just to fire people because they can. The branches main focus is customer retention and not employee growth or motivation.

review_title: Lots of opportunity but easy to get complacent
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: You can be given opportunities quickly if you're in the right place at the right time, and if your reputation is strong.  Great ability to move around across the organization once you prove yourself.  Great thing is that although roles are very narrow you do have the change to try new things and move around over time.  However, be careful of getting stuck - people need to know who you are, and relationships (like everywhere) are critical. People ,ake up their mind quickly about you, and word travels fast.
cons: Absolutely need a champion - if you or your group get caught up in the politics you're toast.

review_title: Enter with caution and low expectations
pros: hone your customer service skills, learn what you don't want in your next job.  The work life balance is pretty good with this company.  It is a great job for university students but there is a quick burnout factor for those employees looking to make this a career.
cons: lack of support, countiuous layoffs, shut downs every few years, low pay, poor management, disgruntled employees, lack of consistency, low employee morale.  All of the good managers seem to move on faily quickly and the ones that you would like to see move on seem to stay around forever.  They do not seem to have much of a development plan in place for growing their mangers skills.

review_title: They could have been a contender...
pros:
There was a good work/life balance in the division I was in.  Not all areas of Citigroup have this balance, although they do try to accomodate people where they can.

Working at Citigroup teaches you to deal with bureaucracy and find your way through a maze of disconnected information to get an answer.  While this is also a downside of Citi, it can help turn a negative (bureacracy) into a positive.
cons: Bureaucracy.  Lack of consistent, knowledgeable leadership.  Very political.

review_title: Too big, lousy career advancement, great opportunity to progress if you are an excellent networker
pros:
- If you network all the time and are excellent at making contacts, you can build a great network and can easily move between jobs
- Despite recent economic downturn, Citi is still respected and everyone knows the name
- opportunity to work abroad in all sorts of locations
cons:
- difficult to navigate, silos, lack of understanding of business lines other than your own
- plenty of employees who are not bright nor professional
- hard to come by the truly great managers, other managers have really only got to their current position because of their tenure / have been with the bank since 1975.
- outsourcing of functions means job security is always a question

review_title: Citi is a company full of bureaucracy, inefficiencies and top-heavy with incompentant, overpaid management.
job_title: Hedge Fund Accounting Supervisor in Columbus, OH
pros: Citi has a great work/ life balance with a flexible work schedule.  There is a young and fun corporate culture.
cons: Compensation is very poor.  Promotions are given without salary increases.  Decisions made are from so many levels above that they don't make practical sense when applied.  The company is full of overpaid managers that do very little to contribute to the bottom line while the first three levels of positions are considered expendable.

review_title: People usually do their time and get out!
pros: Great to have on a resume because Citigroup has a respectable reputation among the banking industry. Able to get promoted if you have specific banking experience, but little to no education.
cons: Continuing education is not valued. Promotions are rarely given on merit and / or production. The size of Citigroup makes it difficult to be recognized. You may get a pat on the back for a job well done, but do not expect monetary compensation. There are far too many 'channels' to go through to get anything of importance accomplished.

pros: Good Benefits. They offer multiple schedules. Not a bad choice but not something you'd want to stay at for as long as I did, hind site 20/20 I wish I would have went back to school and learned something more valuable, they make it so easy to stay on the hampster wheel with all the vacation they offer and you do have job security or at least I did.
cons: Pay to retain employess is horrible to say the least and Management is some what to be desired. If your just looking for a "job" this might work for you. Its one of those kinda jobs where you need to drink lots of koolaid, you are the hampster on the wheel.

review_title: Good Exposure in a very diverse organization
job_title: Risk Analyst in Long Is City, NY
pros: As Citi is a Global organization there is lot of exposure. You get to interact with lot of people at various levels in the organization. After 1 year, you can move to a different position internally. My immediate managers were pretty nice, learned a lot from them.
cons: As Citi's Consumer Banking is not growing in US, career growth in Consumer Banking is limited. The culture is less analytical as compared to its peers. Also, there are lot of inefficiencies, you do the same work again and again. Lot of Bureaucracy and Hierarchy is there, its tough to get approval of strategies from the management. Also, Promotions are very tough

review_title: Great people and plenty of opportunities to gain exposure across a number of areas within the bank.
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in London, England
pros:
I spent most of my tin within operations and I came across some great people who have continued to be close friends. 

The bank generally encourages internal mobility if you want to gain exposure to different areas.
cons:
As it is such a large institution, you can quickly become pigeon holed and it can sometimes become difficult to break out of. 

If you choose to move around the organisation it can be tough getting promotions as there are no "credits in the bank" you take with you, so you find yourself starting afresh each time.

review_title: Good company, but doesn't pay well
pros: The good thing about Citi is that it's not Goldman, i.e., it is possible to have a life outside work
cons: Citi pays billion-dollar fines, but cannot afford to compensate good talent.  Current cost-cutting strategy is nothing but a race to the bottom.

job_title: Vice President Engineering in Warren, NJ
pros: There are a lot of training opportunities
cons:
Citi says it supports a work-life balance and lets employees work remotely.  Then it uses the fact that work can be done successfully while remote to justify moving the job to cheaper locations.
The matrix relationships between managers is crazy -- its pretty hard to figure out who works for who & what the real priorities are when you report to three different people at a time.
It's just too big -- it shouldn't be as hard as it is to get things done, but the organization is so complex that even the little things take forever to accomplish.
Its still very much an old boys network and doesn't take the time to really groom managers.  Some of the behaviors they reward are really beyond belief.

job_title: Product Control Analyst in Getzville, NY
pros: Brand recognition. Since the building is relatively new, it has many amenities, such as a large cafeteria and a gym. Good place to start if you are a college grad.
cons: Lots of people came here because either they had no choice, or want a transfer to New York. People tend to leave after only a few years, which causes significant knowledge loss (not to mention that procedures are rarely written down). This and combined with low pay, contribute to the negative vibe you will may feel. Also, due to the site reaching capacity, parking can be terrible if you come in late, or need to run an errand during the day.

review_title: Not the greatest place but also not the worst
job_title: Mortgage Processor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great benefits. Flexible work time due to open minded management. Most people were great but it is a very strange gossipy environment.
cons: Very tedious work with constant arguments between sales and underwriting. No matter how well you tried to organize your work it was out of your hands because your work depended on too many other people doing their work also. Upper management had no idea what was going on at the ground level and kept making changes. The company overstaffed without thinking of future and then fired people. It was a horrible cycle.

job_title: Java Cloud Engineer in Irving, TX
pros: Excellent 401K plan (6% match), good medical and life plans, very flexible schedule (WFH), supportive management teams, tons of training and volunteer opportunities
cons: Lack of a bonus since the economic downturn in 2009 crash, somewhat inefficient promotion opportunities, bad team culture due to hiring many under-qualified contractors and employees than the best talented employees, only partially competitive pay salary

job_title: Solution Analyst Lead in Hidden River, FL
pros: Great company, always with employee engagement and great environment, big organization to do career development across multiple functions and areas, diversity is amazing, people with different backgrounds make the company rich in knowledge
cons: In my 6 years with the company so far haven't find much cons, maybe parking space, since there are 2 campus in different areas, one of the campus has small cafeteria but the building is temporarily and they are extending the land so in the future shouldn't be a problem

review_title: Showcase yourself and you will get opportunities.
pros:
1. Several lines of business which gives opportunities to work in technologies of choice through internal mobility
2. Flexible timings.
3. work from home facility.
4. Yearly Bonas
5. Public holidays (More that what you got in school :-))
cons:
1. Politics in all aspects, only completing your work is not the case, you have to handle and convince all the related teams about what you are doing as everybody gives their own opinion and you have to make sure that you get the credit otherwise chances are your lead or other related team will take away the credit for your work.
2. Formal dress code
3. No insurance coverage for family
4. Repetitive work if you are on the same team.
5. Too much vendor intervention and at times you may feel like vendors overpower you.

pros:
Love this company when I started wotking for them. They then merged our dept with another one whose staff was loding their jobs. The agreement was they had a contract to complete the work until a set date then they'd get laid off. 
 The managers agenda was to have his team learn my teams jobs them lay us off. Their team was rifed from posting into other posoptions in the co. When my staff attempted to post they never got the job so we asked was was going on were they rifed?  Lies. So I left and attempted to come back have proper notice. I believe I'm blacklisted.
cons: Some managemt they don't understand managing.

job_title: KYC Senior Analyst in New York, NY
pros: We have good benefits, 401K Match, and good training within to take advantage while in company.  Flexible work arrangements and good old fashioned managers.
cons: Sometimes too big of a corporation to get procedures changed but can suggest changes anytime.

review_title: Lack of a consistent growth strategy frustrates employees.
pros: Combined compensation and benefits packages are very good.  Excellent 401K benefits package and tools to learn to manage the account are very good.
cons: No job security.  Inflexible approach to banking.  No clear vision for the future.  Focus is on cutting people and expense, not growing the business.

review_title: good for short term and commission and bad for long term career development
pros: it's pay better than other competitior (banks) in the same position as personal banker.  such as bank of america, wahington mutual, wells fargo bank.  The base salary is almost the same, starting out 40k dollars. but then the commission is monthly.  which give an opportunity for personal banker to get pay every month.
cons: The managers and co-workers at some location are very up-tight, not very helpful for new employees.  The training provide by the company isn't that great, but able to survivie.  On the job support from management is ZERO.  The managers will yell at you if you make a mistake, don't let you go to lunch, break.

review_title: Try it - it has its good points.
pros: There seems to be some places in company that still have a good working environment but these are now rare.  The pressure that has hit the banking industry will probably make this even less of an occurance.  I worked at the Weehawken location my first year and totally loved it.  I think that they will be a good company again but it will be a tough couple of years.
cons: Sometimes the pressure to work "extra hours"  got a little out of hand.

review_title: Lack of integration makes Citi a difficult place to find success.
job_title: Project Manager in Las Vegas, NV
pros: As a large organization with a tremendous amount of locations and resources, opportunities to work in other states in various departments are available.  The organization also values work/life balance and encourages time off along with providing flexible working conditions.
cons: Due to frequent restructuring at the senior management level, the strategy is continuously changing.  Coupled with the various silos created from all the M&A, the lack of cross-communication can make it extremely difficult to share best practices and network with internal talent.

job_title: HR Manager in New York, NY
pros: State of the art, global organization with boatloads of career opportunities throughout the corporate world and the operating units. Hard work is rewarded but given the size of the organization things can get very complicated. Top management is very clique-like and decisions get made without everyone getting an opportunity to contribute to the possibilities.
cons: Firedrills on a regular basis, especially when things aren't going well. Bonuses somewhat arbitrary and at the discretion of your manager. Long hours are expected if you want to do well and although they talk work life balance it is mostly talk. Health benefits are costly and getting more costly every year.

review_title: Not all that it is made to be
pros:
Being in the Summer Analyst program was considered prestigious.

Working for Merrill, Goldman, Citigroup or Lazard is a great accomplishment.
cons: The whole summer analyst program is simply over hyped. Interns don't really make that much and are forced into cold-calling, answering phones and essentially doing b--tch work. You learn very little in terms of finance and struggle to even grasp concepts of what the financial world is really about. Financial Advisers are selling bs advice from above and invest your money without much of a guarantee or foresight. It has given me a very negative opinion on finance

pros:
My salary was excellent, especially considering the economic environment.
There are a number of opportunities to advance, if you keep your eyes open for them.
Management is surprisingly accommodating when it comes to taking time off.
cons:
Extremely high turnover - people can't stand the place, and quit often.
Erratic management - mistakes that should elicit a panicked response don't, and minor mistakes bring about a world-class freakout.  This is a cultural thing, apparently.
Management changes strategy often.  Be prepared to throw away months of work based on someone's whim.

review_title: Much depends on your manager. Compensation not commensurate with job duties.
pros: Benefits include medical, dental, vision, 401K and more. Generous time off: sick days, Holidays and Vacation days that start at day one.
cons: Communication is almost non-existent. More often than not promotions and raises are dependent on the "social" climate, or your relationships within the company. A manager can make or break you, literally. Compensation is not even close to appropriate for all the work you are expected to take on, and barely meets basic needs without working overtime or a second job.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great Global Brand, you interact with a lot of different people and the company definitely has the resources to compensate you and accommodate you.
cons: My time at Citibank was a roller coaster of a ride, I work for a lot different parts of the business Customer Service (call center), CitiPrivate bank, traveled nationwide as a quality analyst and capped it off by working for a branch support department. All in all a lot of hard work that didn't ever payoff,  its all about politics, who you know, not what you know or do.

review_title: Great place to learn. Lack of direction and multiple redundant positions.
pros:
- Every possible job under the sun.
- Can easily horizontally move across different departments.
- Remote work available
cons:
- Management is constantly changing direction.
- Too many layers/senior managers and not enough individual contributors.  More time is spent planning and creating power  point decks rather than actual execution.
- Every department has redundant roles and are typically going after the same goal. Creates confusion for the team on the ground level and wasted effort.

review_title: Good culture, challenging work but cost cutting creating pain across
pros: Ability to move across departments and geographies (after spending some time), good bosses (at least for me), intelligent people around you in general, good opportunities for learning and development
cons: Cost cutting to become lean and mean is creating too much pressure now, so much that you do not get time for learning and development and work life balance is getting spoiled. Merit is not given due respect and functions earn money as per budget allotted to them. Operations are bureaucratic and systems are not up to the mark for a global organisation.

review_title: Great company with strong leadership but cost savings measures hurting talent.
job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
Senior leadership is upfront and invested in organization and people.
Dedicated talented staff members with flexible work arrangements.
Opportunity to take charge and contribute.
cons:
Cost savings measures are driving great talent and intellectual knowledge out of the company.  
Focus on saving each team, division and department taking priority.. 
While a globally diverse workforce,  promotions are driven by location over talent.

review_title: Good people generally except many senior mgmt dont care about people
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Work/life balance, smart people, pay can be good. Some realy nice people below?senior?levels.
cons:
Benefits contributions are crazy high if your title is even moderately senior ($1000+ / month),  you never feel much job security... seniors think nothing of slow rolling layoffs or transformations for years while everyone fears for their jobs. Reviews are bizarre because managers have to submit ratings long before any conversation with directs... so no possibility of convincing boss to improve rating.
Bonuses seem barely related to performance. So you can do a great job and not be recognized much more than someone who barely contributes.

review_title: Stay away unless you like abuse.
job_title: Product Manager in New York, NY
pros: Pay was pretty good that's about it. If you like redundant work (like i  do) this can be a interesting opportunity.
cons:
Toxic. Toxic. Toxic. Citibank has a culture of narcissistic rage. People yell and scream for very little reason in meetings just to flex their authority. Directors will work to devalue you and attempt to force you out if you don't enable the narcissism. Just like any bad behavior without consequences this culture will never stop. It's horribly stressful because most people are overworked. In the end it takes a toll on your health. I feel 5x better after leaving. 

I should have known i was in for a wild ride when one of the leaders of my department told us during our 1st week orientation that Citibank wasn't a big happy family and people will withhold information from you.

pros: Good benefits package.  Other than that, not a thing.  Unless you happen to luck out and get a half way decent manager that is willing to back you and support you ( of course only if deserve it) you will not and I repeat will not make any type of progress in your career.  And unless you step in a pile of you know what, you are stuck at the spot in which you first applied to.
cons: Management has no idea what they are doing if they actually do do anything at all. Nothing but politics and who a popularity contest.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: CItigroup does offer a fair work/life balance - with management approval employees can generally work one a week from home, I never have a problem taking off a little early when there is an event at my child's school, etc.   Benefits and vacation time are better than many other companies.
cons: Communication from management is poor to dishonest, employees get better scoop from the WSJ.  Tenured employees are paid less than new hires at the same level.  Corporate culture is very harsh, political, and siloed

job_title: Marketing Analyst in Long Island City, NY
pros: Citi offers a competitive salaries, great work/life balance (with the opportunity to work remotely), employee discounts to museums, shows and other great places, a comprehensive health benefit plan and most importantly, tuition reimbursement.
cons: Unfortunately management does not provide appropriate feedback, the end-of-year rating system is not structured, career development is difficult and there is not enough emphasis on working to elimate redundant practices.

review_title: Great opportunities, but beware the good ol' boys
job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
* Fun culture where people form good relationships both at and beyond the workplace
* Lots of resources, including gym, cafeteria, decent benefits
* Large company offers opportunities to move around, but there is at times very little interaction between divisions
cons:
* Can some times be a good ol' boys environment. Networks are incredibly important for promotions and opportunities.
* Work life balance really depends on your division and your group. Large variation in hours. Some 9-5 while other work until midnight every night.

pros: The pay was good and they had company parties and events that I was invited to participate in even though I was a contractor
cons: There weren't enough employees to do the job that I was assigned to do, so the other mailroom clerks and I often "scrambled" to get the work done in a timely manner.  Also, if the day shift staff wanted to work overtime, they would sit at their work stations, and the 2nd shift staff (of which I was one) had to find places to sit which wasn't easy.

pros: Citi is a huge corporation with a footprint almost in every geography and finance business. Citi is a very nice place to work. Diversity matters a lot. Because it is very big we cannot generalise anything across the corporation. It is all down to the organization within the organization you are working. The best thing about Citi is the flexibility (WFH, compensatory offs etc). Citi is not a pay master, having said that Basic pay is ok, but the bonus is bad. Overall it is a very good balanced life in Citi, if you want a cool Job with enough but not too much work, Citi is a good place.
cons:
Bonus is not great. It is very slow moving.
Lot of constraints and over head even for the smallest job.
Bureaucracy

review_title: Strong people, but can be so much more
pros:
People: The people I worked with were great - looking back I ended up missing the people far more than I expected. Bright, competent, helpful.

Variety: As a large banking institution, there is vast opportunity for exposure to many products, services, and business units.
cons:
Bureaucracy: Hard to get things done. The institution is simply incapable of nimbleness.

Resource allocation: There is a strong disconnect between Senior Management and rank/file employees. Hence, rank/file do not feel engaged, and Senior Management does not understand the challenges/barriers rank/file face.

job_title: Senior Teller in Long Beach, CA
pros: There was a lot of autonomy in this role, the company provided some benefits, and I got to know my clients well because we had a small branch.
cons:
The managers were lacking in training, did not encourage growth and development throughout the branch, and had obvious favorites. The pay did not justify putting up with this aspect of the job.

The trickle-down of the area director's decisions didn't always translate for our small branch, so some of the goals ended up being unrealistic.

pros: Because they are very flexible with your schedule, if you need time off ((in our department, because this is very dependent on who your manager is), I have never seen it not granted.
cons: Its...."who you know"....when it comes to promotions, senior management does not really qualify in our department to be "Senior Management".  Persons are always on the defensive because upper management does not communicate with the employees and everyone is afraid that their job is going to be outsourced...there have been a few titles already outsourced, but management waits until the last minute to tell the employees that it will affect, and will not tell the truth to the other departments.

job_title: Assistant Vice President  in Warren, NJ
pros: One of the biggest and prestigious global firm. Great internal mobility (both global and countrywide) to advance your career and opportunity to try out different areas/groups without having to switch firms. Relatively a much better work life balance compared to other financial firms. Good people, encouragement to volunteer, diversity etc. Benefits especially healthcare may not be as good as the jersey pharma firms but they are comparable to financial firms in the NY metro area.
cons: Due to the diversified portfolio of business you don't get the upside in a bull market as you would working for a pure IB. At the same time it is better to be diversified in the current environment.

review_title: You will be challenged, and hopefully rewarded.
pros: You will be challenged and given opportunities to show your leadership. Professional advancement opportunities are available, but you have to seek them. If you're lucky enough to have a seasoned manager, he/she will show guide you through the Citigroup jungle, and help empower your career. Flexible work-life balance, if you schedule and communicate well with your management is possible.
cons: Excessive regulatory and audit scrutiny drain resources from more productive projects. You have to take charge of your schedule early on, else you will be a blackberry (aka crackberry) slave. Some evidence of old school, micromanagers still exist, although senior management is working hard to change that culture.

review_title: Citi is a company for now, not forever
pros: Mangement is compotent in my department, and allow you to take time off usually when you want, as long as your back up is not off.  Vacation time is pretty good and you can earn an extra few days for giving to charity
cons: No advancement, no raises, no bonuses.. health care plan was just modifed and costs increased so it was like receiving a pay cut... Bonuses are non-existent.. upper management does not allow numbers to be released, so they tell you that you are doing a good job and are ahead of last year, but you never know by how much... advancement is tough, and raises are not there

review_title: Lack of leadership and interest in creating a unified culture that motivates the workers.
job_title: SVP, Enterprise Architecture in Dallas, TX
pros: I can say with openness that the only good thing about Citi or Citigroup right now would be the fact that you get a pay check, as small as it is; oh yea insurance.  Other then that you will have a J-O-B with minimal pay
cons:
The board of directors have lost vision and direction, and are unwilling to make the "real" decision required to "right the ship".  The executive group "click" are not truly interested in fixing any of the real issues, instead they are only interested in ensuring they get their bonus, which they have NOT earned.

If I were in charge I would remove the cancer from the executive team, clear the deck all the CxO's at corporate and sector levels as well as their 1st, 2nd and 3rd Lieutenants.

review_title: Not the best place for junior people interested in wealth management.
job_title: Summer Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Citigroup has a large network and there are many opportunities for advancemenet across divisions within the company.
cons: LOTS of bureaucracy. Also, the feedback wasn't always great. People who weren't doing so well were never told explicitly. More transparency would have helped. I feel like many times my boss gave me things to do soley for the purposes of keeping me busy. Many of the projects had little to no added value. Furthermore, as a junior person within the company I was asked to do some extremely tedious, non-business related tasks. One time a more senior employee gave me a bunch of receipts for his personal expenses and asked me to create a spreadsheet.

review_title: The steping stone in a banking career.
job_title: Senior Teller, Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: The best of working for Citibank, is the experience one can gain from such an aggresive sales environment.  If banking and sales is something you want to do as a career, then working as a senior teller can give you both the choice between going into operations management or move on as a personal banker.
cons: If you are someone that has a hard time adjusting to change, then the current changes going on Citibank might stress you out a bit.

pros: Worldwide locations, you can move up a bit and then go to another bank. They also have the google wallet and new ATMs and  they are in 7-11
cons:
The systems don't talk to each other in the retail bank
They will tell you that you can grow in the company, but then employ people from outside of the bank
When you get promoted, they only bump your salary max 5% and then bring people in that make way more than you do.
They say that they care about service, but they fired all of the service officers and cut the number of tellers at every branch.

job_title: Mortgage Back End Collector III in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I loved everyone that worked there. My Managers, Co-Workers, etc., & eventually work at home.
cons: The Company left Phoenix & I was unable to relocate.

pros: Great staff and customers were top tier and amazing to work with.   Very family sensitive and benefits are available the first day of hire.
cons: Sales goals were not in tune with local economy.  They reduced the sales force when I was let go and the one person left is still struggling with goals.   It was not due to lack of drive or effort.

pros: The leadership of the organization in which I belong are visionary.  They want to move the organization in a positive direction.  Working remotely if your organization permits it,  but you must be accountable for your actions and time.  If abused it will be taken away.  Great benefits, health, 401K, and time off!
cons: As with any large company it can be a machine from time to time.  Coming from smaller companies it took time for me to adjust to large corporate timeframes.  Since team is geographically dispersed it would be good to have face to faces on some occasions with other team members

pros: I love the idea to make a global name that is recognized across the world and to make sure the service one receives in one place is the same as is in other please.
cons: Citibank is very fast to cut peoples' jobs with out any word.  They are mostly about their money and status no matter what will do what ever it takes to maintain the a global image.

review_title: I enjoy my co-workers and my boss. Feel like I am a member of the team. Benefits are great.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Florence, KY
pros: Great benefits, chance to move up.  Management wants employees to do better.  Upper management can be approached as long as all are on the same page. Dress code is fair and reasonable. Vacation and unplanned time are good.
cons: One, the salary is low for what they ask.  You are micromanaged to the max. High turnover due to demands of call times and being customer service. They get on you about using unplanned time. Reviewing of calls does not take place in a timely manner nor do reviews. No merit raises but once a year.

review_title: Large Corp.  (Only worked for 4 months now)
pros:
Easy to go with the flow and keep on getting pushed up without actually contributing or adding much value (as is the case in most large corp)

Good development for new analysts in programs, though HR sucks and you really have to ask for it.  Good job to start career.
cons:
The pros can also be seen as cons depending on what you're looking for. It isn't very challenging here. Sr. mgmt only care about their own metrics

I hear compensation sucks and am not expecting any large bonuses. I also hear climbing the ladder can also be tough after the analyst program / for non-program hires

job_title: Vice President, Specialized Analytics in Allen, TX
pros: Benefits package is certainly appealing.  401(k) match at 6% plus 2% flat contribution annually.  Medical / dental have broad coverage, and vacation time is generous (6 weeks including holiday time).
cons: Management in private label credit card division is against remote work and more strict than corporate policy on number of remote days allowed before requiring executive VP approval.  In addition, high priority / high risk projects are often understaffed requiring clean-up weeks or months later.

pros: Citi is obviously a massive organization. I felt fully supported and felt that I had access to multiple avenues where I could grow professionally.
cons: To be honest I have nothing to compare it to so I cannot say for sure that something is negative but I did feel at my time there that the openness between middle management and upper management was not as much as it should have been. There was quite of operational quirks that middle management knew that upper management had no clue about.

pros: If you work hard , if you are willing to work overhours  you can get promoted. I got to know helpful, talented people in the team and I met there my best teamleader. Required support from the management and training is provided to fulfill the daily tasks. Trainings are well-organized. Relative high salaries. Huge variety of social events.
cons: There are loads of social events, meetings, team huddles. Of course these can be pros as well but sometimes it is really frustrating that you don't know when to complete your daily tasks because of your tight meeting schedule. Poor, steril, 10 years old style work environment. Constantly changing team structure, processes and systems.

review_title: Either you like it or you don't.
pros:
A.) Awesome benefits, hard to come by a company that provides benefits from day one. 
B.) Several site clubs to promote inclusiveness. 
C.) Gym on site for low price.
D.) Lots of good people to work with.
cons:
A.) Room for advancement isn't great, unless you have yourself in the right pockets. 
B.) There is a lot of office politics, to the point where some of the rules are nonsensical. 
C.) Sometimes you're forced to help other departments without any say in the matter, which can affect whether or not you work on holidays. 
D.) Unforgiving sick time policies.
