E.) Management, more so upper management, can be quite dishonest.

pros: Salary, remote work, central office location
cons: Expensive healthcare  premiums with little coverage, coworkers who survive by doing the minimal amount of work, open office system that’s noisy and impersonal, too many H1B workers, over 75% of programmers and testers are off shore. So cheap. They cutoff the hot water in the restrooms at my location to save money.

pros: There is excellent in-house training resources...as long as one takes the initiative to look for them.  Management pays more than lip service to the option of telecommuting and flexible work options, which is nice.
cons:
Let's be honest, it's a little embarrassing to have to admit that I work at this train wreck of a company!  In addition, the company is such a behemoth, that everything is so stratified and separated, which makes for an abundance of red tape.  There is a lengthy conference call for even the most innocuous of matters.  
The benefits and pay scales are paltry in comparison to similar financial services firms.

review_title: Good for IT people who don't enjoy working close to technology.
pros: With a bit of luck you can participate in large-scale IT projects. Working with globally distributed teams can be satisfying. The carrier path can be good if you are interested in management.
cons: A lot of bureaucracy and red tape. People are too often treated as resources. The management elitysm can also sometimes get irritating. There is definitely not enough communication between teams - people tend to hide behind processes and often focus on finding an excuse not to get involved with given initiative.

review_title: Good people, hard work and no work/life balance
job_title: IT Project Manager in Warren, NJ
pros: Because of the size of the firm, there is always room for advancement and growth.  There are a lot of very sharp people and almost all of your peers and teammates are pulling together for a common goal.
cons: They pay you as little as they can get away with.  Work/life balance is non existent.  Be prepared to work long days, frequently into the night and on weekends with no additional comp.

pros: Good people.  Good work.  Good company.
cons: Middle management may have poor leadership skills.  Despite "Voice of the Employee" attempt to get upper management feedback on their middle managers.

review_title: irritations of a teller at citibank
pros: pay is good-$15 with no banking experience. hours.
cons: too much emphasis on the customer surveys. rude clients are called up by survey company and if youre in the red management will observe you daily and will critique every little thing. i used to enjoy going to work but now its just one big anxiety attack. at the end of the day I'm not going to connect with every client. some people are just plain cynics. also unrealistic sales goals even for my slow branch. and the the stupid vcic check imaging machine is a mess. let back office do all of that. :/

pros: Hard to get fired and you don't have to produce.
cons: Unethical practices perpetrated against the client and employee, even if a borrower can bring their account current within the month citi's management requires you to place them on a deferment so they can get the $1000.00 from the tax payers, the Irving Texas location had 250 work outs in January 2013 which netted them $250,000.00 for the month , just from federal handouts, and their stated goal is to double that amount over the next two months.  I came to this department promised many thing and out and out lied to. I just purchased a home a few months ago, I got my loan from Wells Fargo.

pros: Company offers good benefits to employees, has a flexible work program, and employee networks. Globality offers much opportunity for motivated employees.
cons: Because the company is so large, it's hard to get some things done - cohesiveness isn't as strong as it should be.  Company morale is slipping to an all time because the focus is on the stock prices and not raises.  Expense management is the focus, but money continually is wasted on needless process and superferlous processes.

review_title: Love the place. A pity about the politics.
pros: The smart people (and lifetime friendships), the business buzz, the blue chip client franchise, the well-resourced infrastructure (esp from the outside looking in), the opportunities to experience and grow as a professional.
cons: The size, and the dysfunctional that is a consequence.  You can be rated high-potential one year, and be made redundant the next if you happen to be at the wrong place at the wrong time.

review_title: Great place to work, but depends on the project
job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: I work in IT where almost everyone was friendly and brilliant. Many interesting projects and advanced technologies is use, and lots to learn. Great work life balance.
cons:
Internal processes are inefficient. Even a 4 year old PC upgrade required months of waiting.
Thousands of e-mails exchanged every day, it was overwhelmingly bad.

review_title: Division or people you work with defining your experience at Citi
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Citi has a global presence and may be able to provide better global transfer opportunities and experiences.
Depending on whom you work with, right experiences may be obtainable.  Work-life balance may be possible for certain divisions only when working with right people/management who care.
cons: For certain divisions, work-life balance is hard to come by; there are almost non-existing bonuses for AVP and positions below; and it is hard to get time off especially when working for more than one manager. Promotion is not based on performance evaluation alone.  It is only possible if there is an opening for the next-level up and candidates have to be aware of the opening and apply online in time, etc.

job_title: Credit Risk Analyst in Buffalo, NY
pros: Citi has good benefits and competitive salaries. I did not think that the work was that demanding or challenging, which may be a pro or con, depending on what you are looking for. There is definitely room for career growth and plenty of opportunities globally.
cons: Citi's management is mostly incompetent. They make poor decisions and fail to listen to their employees. Also there were a lot of lay offs/restructurings while I was there. Mostly people in NY were being laid off and jobs were moving to low cost areas. Training/onboarding new employees was another weakness of Citi's. Also the bureaucracy inhibits efficient work from being accomplished and prevents innovative changes from being implemented.

review_title: Currently working as a Corporate Service Manager with CITIBANK NA, GURGAON possesses 6.5 years rich experience
pros: An innovative and unique thinker which help to the best of my ability for maintaining effective customer service for all internal and external customers by utilizing excellent, in-depth knowledge of company processes and programs
cons: As compared to the market and other new joiners at work, it feels extremely demotivating comparing the annual package after providing the loyalty of approx. 7 yrs to the organization.

job_title: Senior IT Manager in London, England
pros: A huge company with many lateral opportunities in low cost locations. A global brand. Canary wharf offices are quite nice.
cons: Too much concentrating on promoting people who look good on paper. Constant problems with stability in risk area. Unbelievable beurocracy. Almost impossible to get promoted above VP. It's not what you know it's who you know. Major under investment in QA and non production support. Not enough environment stability. Minimal automation. People are praised based on how they look. Not what they do. Vengeful managers who are worried about their jobs more than the company. Pointless townhalls

review_title: Long hours. Very political work environment.
job_title: Senior Vice President in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Access to the latest in technology.  Great cutting edge  projects to work on .  Theoretically   career mobility within organisation is encouraged.
cons:
Long hours seem to be the rule ather than the exception in this organization .  Especially at senior levels.  Sending and responding to emails at 6:00 AM is a common practice. Weekend work is also expected from time to time.  

This can a very political environment to work in.  Career advancement benefits etc can be dependent on who you know rather than what you know.

job_title: Bankruptcy Specialist III in Florence, KY
pros: Lots of job opportunities for which  to submit resumes, within company.  NOTE: I cannot appropriately and accurate rate Senior Management as I have not personally met any of them.
cons: It's rare you will get anything other than a lateral move or downgrade.  Out of 300 submissions for jobs, I had (wait for it) THREE interviews, and only one was with this particular site.  Others were for other company sites.

review_title: Depends on what supervisor you get
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Gray, TN
pros:
Insurance benefits. 
The schedule could be a pro if you can get one you want.
cons:
Managers. Your experience at Citi will depend on your manager when you get hired in or if you can get switched teams in a hurry if you get a bad one! I had a bad one which only had new hires on her team because as soon as they can they get away from her. 
Also getting time off approved is difficult. My mom was having health problems and had to have several procedures and I requested off atleast 5-7 days before and they refused to give me time off even talking to my supervisor didn't help. So I had to use my time instead of pto.

job_title: Securities Processing Representative in Warsaw, Masovia
pros: More or less flexible schedule. Managers are great. Atmosphere is really friendly. At some positions you have a lot of opportunities for overtimes. The possibility to grow and to learn. A lot of trainings.
cons: I cann't find any serious really. Sometimes work environment is really intense and you feel that you should be paid more than you really get, but in the end of the day that is not the main factor. Also there are a lot of people just pushing buttons and don't understanding the sense of the process, but I feel at every company the situation is more or less the same.

review_title: Good Global Firm with Name Recognition - but bureaucracy reigns
job_title: S&T Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great resume item no matter your role, access to much information internally and a great learning experience for a young employee. For the most part, good people and the middle/upper ranks and filled with many career veterans that have spent most of their time at the firm.
cons: Bureaucracy can feel insurmountable at times, and it takes a lot of politicking to be appropriately noticed. There was a time when exceptional performance seemed like it would outweigh this type of nonsense but now that flat is the new up it's difficult to see it in that same light.

job_title: Applications Development Technical Specialist in Irving, TX
pros: Good Benefits, Stability and Flexibity of locations
cons: Slow pace and limited career advancement. Pay hike is based on a formula, which leaves little incentive for employees to step up, this is in IT

pros:

+ Helped get me started utilizing advanced levels of Excel VBA

Personal Example: 1-manager, 1-supervisor, 1-analyst (this was changing since I've left)
- I had 13 different people I reported to in 4 years; equals 1 (supervisor, manager or AVP) approximately every 112 days.  I believe this left me without any promotions or significant raises because I had to prove myself (not a problem initially) to what seemed like a never ending cycle of management.

review_title: Good career progression but old fashioned
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Good people, strong work ethic within teams, management are approachable, good benefits (heath etc). The people really make Dublin Citi site a pleasure to work in.
cons: Large salary discrepancies between colleagues doing the same job, with the same title and same experience, performance (15k+ differences in my experience). Citi don't care about this even when they tried to remedy  the situation and admitting it was a problem it was never transparent exercise and people know the person sitting next to them is still on % higher.

pros:
Lots of diversity programs
HR programs/resources were good

pros: Well known company, great pay, benefits, bonus program, hours, able to work from home when needed. Enjoy working with some talented people.
cons: Employees are treated like a number, lie directly to their employees, change benefits in the employee handbook 2 weeks before we are told Citi is selling mortgage servicing, if offered job with new company and don't accept then no severance pay, I could go on and on.

pros: My coworkers are very helpful, kind, intelligent, and competent.  The training program is quite thorough.  The work is rigorous and challenging but fair.   A variety of resources are provided.  The work environment is comfortable, flexible, and versatile.
cons: The pay is low, low, low.  It really could be a tad higher for the type of work we are asked to do.  The yearly work schedule is a bit up in the air.  Nothing is stated in stone, so balancing one's work and personal life is difficult. The branch is small.  Team-work is not promoted at this branch.  Autonomy is thought of as a very, very important quality.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Saint Louis, MO

review_title: Citi still has to improve on motivating its employees
pros: Job security and large company benefits.  They have 401k, dental, medical, and vision benefits.  I'm not complaining about my salary either, considering the amount of effort and time i'm putting in my position.  I haven't been laid off yet, which is a plus to being in back office.
cons: Poor leadership, communication, and career advancement.  There's this wall that exists between me and my manager, and I absolutely hate it.  He's not personal at all, and I wish he could be more supportive and caring towards me.  I feel like another ant in this huge company, and sometimes I wish it can be a little smaller with all the benefits still there.

pros: Citi has good health care and many choices of coverage.  Work/Life balance is fair because it affords you the time to attend to family needs when necessary.
cons: The lack of communication.  Citi lacks defined career paths and opportunities to expand a person's career.  For example, if you have a speciality and a unique skill set your opportunities are limited. In addition, obtaining information on how your new job titled (during the recent reorg) was determined and what KSA are required for that position.

pros: Prestigious large money center bank.  Opportunities for exposure to other areas not available in smaller institutions.
cons: Dysfunctional management with minimal insight into actual banking operations.  The institution was literally too large due to ill throughout and/or mistimed acquisitions.  As a result, Numerous systems existed that did not "talk" one another.  Moreover, there was minimal inter-departmental cooperation.  This often led to mid-level management being unable to deliver acceptable level of customer support.  Compounding this issue was that certain areas were ofter moved from the Consumer Bank to the Investment Bank with little thought to the actual impact on the business unit itself and ultimately its clients.

pros: Citigroup hires really bright people with big ideas and drive.  The compensation package is excellent.
cons: There is no work life balance at Citi.  My colleague had to cancel a trip to Italy for a project and he had already paid for the tickets.  The other issue at Citi is politics.  Turf wars are  common practice and institutional knowledge is something that is guarded and shared only when absolutely necessary.

review_title: Talk about meritocracy is just talk
pros: Flexible Work benefits, generous time off package, company daycare, global mobility options, and plenty of work from home positions in IT.
cons: 2011 will be the third year without significant raises or bonuses, even for high performing VPs. If you do decide to work for Citi you will hear a lot of talk about meritocracy, unfortunately it is just talk. Merit increases will not be given in 2011 once again, regardless of performance rating.

pros: Great benefits, some real talent in middle management.
cons: uppper management completely misses the concept of noblesse oblige, and since they seem to think of themselves as nobility, this is a problem. They make arbitrary changes mid stream, leak the info to every company under the sun, but fail to inform their employees what is going on. Employees are shuffled around into positions they never applied for and would never have accepted if given any input into their own lives. Upper management feels that the people who do the bulk ofhte in the trenches work areirrelevant,  expendable, and replaceable in that order.

review_title: Nice Company to work with on an overall basis.
pros:
Citi is internationaly recognised comapny with Nice culture, work life balance, good training for employees and also provides a good background to work with experienced and talented people. They also offer good pay pakage depending upon the profile and candidates cirriculam vita.

It provides you a great exposure and ability to find your inner talent during the work process.
cons: If you are less than a year then possibilty for  a transfer to other team or dept. is null....which leaves you in a mess....by spoiling your career graph.

review_title: See your physician before accepting the job
job_title: Customer Service Specialist IV in Florence, KY
pros: They give you a little money, health, dental, and vision benefits.
cons: Toxic environment caused by lack of accountability from  management and senior  management. Employees are rewarded for avoiding doing their actual jobs, due to the political environment. Opportunities for advancement are constantly thwarted, and external talent will always be recognized before internal. Managers and especially operations managers do not ensure equal treatment of employees or take concerns seriously. No real focus on quality of service or training. Changes to products and service are not based on client or employee experience or feedback. Many agents have to take antianxiety or antidepressant medication to function in their roles day to day. Bed bugs are a constant threat and the bathrooms are never clean. Pay is not at all competitive.

pros: The only good thing about working at Citibank is that other companies look at your resume in a positive way for having worked there.
cons: Micromanagement in the retail environment. Conference calls ever 2 hours in Washington DC market.  Ridiculous sales goals and service expectations with horrible metrics.  They measure the surveys with answers 1-10, where anything below 9 is automatically a 0.  If you get a low score, they embarrass you in front of all the staff.  Also, staffing issues. AKA, they don't care if you are understaffed, they still expect you to perform at a high level.  When people call out, they don't give support in the branches.  When someone quits, they don't act quickly to get someone else.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
Great structure, and internal social structure for finding people / teams / stuff using the internal equivalent to 'Facebook' and 'Amazon' considering the global nature of the company this is impressive.
Projects are ambitious and you can garner a relative about of autonomy once you understand the ropes with is quite empowering.
cons: The sheer size of the company means that you may find yourself waiting weeks for something that might only take hours in a smaller company. Projects can seem unclear with lack of direction at first, as your project my form only a small part of a much larger jigsaw. So you will need to be very patient and not get overwhelmed for at least the first 12 months of being in the company.

pros: If you like fast paced work, this is the place to be.  The *vastness* of the network (infrastructure) allows you to experience things that you will not  experience elsewhere.  Also, the work life balance is EXCELLENT.
cons: The sheer amount of emails you get everyday can, and is, very daunting.  You really have to be disciplined to stay on top of it.  Also, sometimes, people use the "process" to slow down projects.  As they say:  "You can't fire someone for following the process"  But it can be tough to get initiatives through.

pros: The pay was great and the people there were great overall. Opportunity to move up if you are liked and if you are not liked then you are talked about in "secrecy." However, like any job if you come in and work hard and leave then your day isn't so bad.
cons: The products are somewhat crappy so be prepared for a lot of customer complaints. The websites barely work and the employees' systems often crash. There is always sometimes of gimmick or catch with the credit cards and it upsets the customers off. Be prepared for an ear full everyday.

pros: Good incentives (quarterly bonus and sometimes a gift card), most of my co-workers were very nice
cons: Was treated very badly by my supervisor for no reason other than she was a miserable person, which ultimately led to me resigning. Health insurance is awful for anyone with a medical condition who goes to the doctor regularly; I ended up with a bill that took me over 6 years to pay off. Constant pressure on the tellers to make sales referrals, in person and on the phone. If we didn't meet our goals, we were lambasted for it, many times in front of our co-workers.  WE ARE TELLERS, NOT SALESPEOPLE.

job_title: One Stop Sales in Florence, KY
pros: Benefits if you stay long enough, upward mobility in a year, bonuses on sales
cons: I had serious ethics concerns so I left. They tell you a 6 month learning curve to do your job perfectly but put you on the phone working with client accounts in a matter of a few weeks , telling you you are doing great while you are managing them incorrectly. The training computers do not work the same way as the real world computers so "training" is often times wasted time and ineffective.

pros: Its a brand name, which means you can leverage it for finding another employer like GS, JP; however, this is less likely now given the internal degradation.
cons:
1. VERY VERY LONG hours: Citi never sleeps is the company motto and how  we lived in research. There was no weekend, no time for family  (mine forgot that i exist)
,  and the worst, YOUR WILL NOT GET time to study for CFA or other professional designation. 

2. My boss changed 3 times. Something is going wrong upstairs, but the people at upstairs talking of company loyalty while leaving the company. 

3. Salary growth is really really low. 

4. Don't get sick! 

5. Management Associate program is THE MAIN pipeline to boardroom, so you are not part of this program but equally or more qualified you still would be past for promotion.

job_title: Senior KYC Analyst in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Good facilities, management are supportive, transferable skills, excellent salary, clear career progress
cons: The training program is poor. 1 week of classroom based theory and then weeks of waiting around for actual work to start as you wait on systems access and other groups to finish.

review_title: Slowly becoming more progressive, but the culture is still rigid
job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
Real glimmers of hope on pay equity, equal representation
Generally strong ethics
Smart and committed people trying to do their best for clients and each other
Good, strong messages about culture and values
Good career mobility
cons:
Still a fundamentally hierarchical organization
Territorial executives building empires within the empire
Despite the FinTech threats, still conservative and slow in technology innovation
Terrible meeting and email cultures
The culture & values promoted by execs & HR don't feel entirely authentic and don't quite trickle down

review_title: Not a bad place to work if you are in the right area.
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
Lots of room for advancement as they change the chairs around every couple years to keep it interesting for Senior Management.  Interesting ideas do get listened to but you have to deal with dinos and idiots getting in the way of progress.
Good vacation after 5 yrs/VP and they are doing a decent job promoting life-work balance -- though of course it saves us money to have folks working from home.
cons: Have seen large projects disappear into thin air without recognition of why they were a waste of time to begin with. Different business lines definitely still have issues working together.

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Miami, FL
pros: Higher salaries compared to other banks.  But this seems to be true during 2007-2008.  But starting in the latter part of 2009, the commissions have disappeared and bonuses have decreased by half.  This is a direct result of increased goals.
cons: After the mid 2009, Citibank began focusing  on quantity rather than quality.  Today, every PB is required to open 40-50 accounts per month.  This is very frustrating when you're an honest individual who tries to do the best for clients and find yourself without any available time.  No payouts for any loan products.

review_title: A challenging work environment in which personal loyalties are often rewarded over job performance.
pros: Opportunities to learn and work with some talented individuals. When times were good, pay raises and bonuses were awarded annually.  A decent 401k plan.
cons: Department managers did not always reward performance.  There was no such thing as a "safe" environment to express your disagreements or concerns with their management style or any issues you had with how the department was run.  Managers used company layoffs as a means of weeding out anyone who didn't share their views.

pros: flex time (when you can get it approved...) benefits, paid time off, coworkers. they are always hiring.
cons: DO NOT TAKE A SALES POSITION! management changes their mind every other day on what they want you to do, things that you sell mysteriously just disappears and good luck on trying to get your commission. once they have made enough people mad and they quit your locked into your position for over a year why they rebuild the department back (out of a class of 25, 2 will last (i am one of the 2) for a couple years).

review_title: The culture has changed for the worst
pros: -Great team (may vary), Vacation, Benefits
cons:
Where do I begin?
-Unrealistic goals trickling down from upper management to branch staff
-Compensation is a joke in relation to the stresses that tellers deal with
-"Quarterly bonuses" (if you're lucky to get them) 
-Rewarding Employees with ThankYou Points (Don't think that I can pay bills with Thankyou points)
-Customer satisfaction scores tying in with branches' overall compensation (anything less than an 80% avg is considered even if cust. wrote down that the service was extraordinary)
-Low Morale 
-Absolutely no overtime!!!
-Major disconnect with upper management

review_title: Citi is very silo'd.  If you work in one part of the bank, it is difficult to change to another part of the bank.
pros: Excellent benefits; ability to transfer to different parts of the world; from a policy perspective they encourage mobility
cons: Management is Silo'd and people are very territorial.  They want to keep talent for themselves.  It is less stressful to leave the company and comeback to another part of the company than to try and move internally.  Ironically, philosophically the organization encourages mobility.  The culture is very darwinistic.  You will grow fast if you amaze the right people but you can also be stuck with some one who doesn't want you to grow because they need your talent where you are.

review_title: Great place for recent college graduates to get feet wet but vicious corporate culture....
job_title: Senior AML Analyst in Tampa, FL
pros: Able to work from home; salary is decent for Tampa; great title and company for your initial resume start.
cons: People are overworked regularly due to lack of capacity planning; co-workers gossip non-stop about trivial things and are all on edge due to the aforementioned; technology is old and disorganized; and professional decorum and civility are at an all time low with regular emotional break downs at meetings and cursing. AML also does not have a standard business process so the quality of your work varies with whose eyes its before and how your manager is feeling.

review_title: Good place to work for those who thrive in an ever changing environment
job_title: Program Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: There are some wonderful, dedicated people at Citi to work with. If you appreciate working in an environment where there is a LOT of change, this could be the place for you.  There isn't time for complacency, which I found highly appealing. This also gives you an opportunity for a great deal of learning.
cons: Sometimes you feel as though you are spinning your wheels due to the constant change.  Some folks are not cut out to work in this environment; if not...this isn't the place for you.

review_title: If you can make it here, you probably can make it anywhere.
pros: Global footprint is its unique differentiator. No other bank has its reach-- from people to products to platforms. Very fast-paced and bottomline-driven. Very unique to feel the world at your literal fingertips.
cons: The bank caters to the triple A -- the large multinational, the large government client, the high net worth individual. If the client isn't in this category, the client isn't valued. So big and complicated, it is prone to many broken pieces that need constant fixing. In many cases, the pressure to deliver on revenues is so high, products are not built properly. Hence, the amount of re-work, fire-fighting and managing client escalations is very high.

review_title: Lot of work pressure, unreasonable deadlines, No work life balance
job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Jacksonville, FL
pros:
You get to see every sort of technology.
You work with lot of smart, energetic, dedicated but aggressive people
Work from home option only for certain teams. 
Good vacation package, good benefits.
cons:
You should spend lots of overtime at work. Management would not help in any way. Work is expected to be done all by yourself as an individual. No team work. Management is involved(sort of directly provokes) directly in conflicts within colleagues. 
Lots and lots of politics. You cannot survive with out developing very thick skin to tolerate. 
No salary raises. If there are, they are very low compared to the long hours you spend. 
Very bad work culture.

pros: Working in a great group with exposure to diverse projects and senior management.  Get good support from my senior leadership team.  They are great role models.
cons: Have been told I am doing the work of the next level (i.e. Director) for over a year although I have been top rated for the last 3 years, they won't promote me because there are no Director requisitions open in our area.   In general, it looks like I may need to leave my department or the company if I want to move ahead.  The irony is that there are many Directors that have no staff(I have 7 directs) and much less responsibilities yet they appear to grandfathered in.

review_title: Very bad culture. No work ethics. No professionalism. No work life balance.
job_title: Senior Fp&A Analyst in Goregaon East
pros: Decent brand. In order to attract talent, they pay well but no hikes and bonus after that.
cons: Extremely high attrition. Not a good organization. No work life balance. No professionalism. No hikes and bonus. Hire and Fire policy. No work ethics. Extremely high politics. People even go for paycuts after citi, it is that bad. Experienced people with 10+ yrs of work experience too leave within a year. In first 5 months with citi, i was the oldest member of my team. Freshers, please do not start your career with Citi. You will never get the confidence in your career and they will ruin it.

review_title: Depending on the Department and Boss
job_title: Executive Assistant in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Like all jobs, it all depends on the Department and the boss. If you have a good one there is possibility to work from home. Some call centers have their agents work from home too. Because it is an international company there is definitely a lot of options to move to. Tuition reimbursement offering is a definite plus. Not many utilizes this and they should.
cons: If you work in a Call Center, depending on your boss, you may be micromanaged which is typical at a Call Center. But if you do your work and do your time you can move up relatively quick if you keep looking.

review_title: Citi is a great place to work in a diversified atmosphere
pros: The diversity of the people and their dedication. Opportunities to move globally are good if you're willing to not only change location but also take on varied roles. Pay is good with a benefits package that pretty much matches elsewhere
cons: The management are always playing games and more interested in their own career progression rather than building successful businesses. Stay out of Consumer if your in EMEA, enough said. Too many decisions taken in NYC or Singapore without accepting some places are different.

job_title: Senior Mobile Test Analyst in Coppell, TX
pros: Can work from home, dress very casual, no micromanagement.
cons: Little growth opportunity and managers detached from their teams day to day. People hired because a friend of a friend even if grossly unqualified, creating more work for current team mates to pick up the slack. Farthest from a meritocracy I've come across, unfortunately. At Citi, its pick the best friend for the job, not best person for the job.

pros: Excellent quality of work.  Collaborative environment.  Well paid (although only mid range compared to other US investment banks).  Growing acceptance of flexible working arrangements including working form home.
cons: Ability to implement flexible working depends on immediate line manager.  Significant re-organisations are common.  Constant assessment of whether to offshore or near-shore roles.  Poor career progression - goal posts move often on objectives and targets.  Existing staff are over-looked in favour of lateral hires.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Training, scope of the job, team leader and teammates are wonderful. You learn a lot and get paid well. And, it's dayshift. You get a lot of support from supervisors.
cons: I just wish they were a bit closer. I live in Bacoor, and they are now in Taguig.  they used to be in Makati.

review_title: Citigroup: An organization in transition handling it well.
job_title: Research Analyst in Saint Charles, MO
pros: The size of the organization offers wide opportunities, so if you could potentially spend an entire career with this company in many different functional roles. The benefits are best in the industry. Communication from senior leadership about important issues is always made available to employees via the company website. There are many learning and professional development courses available to employees.
cons: The culture is not always a meritocracy and can be highly political. Senior management does communicate but it is not always timely. Workloads can be high due to restructuring in the last couple years. Compensation for certain positions isn't the highest in the industry.

review_title: Remember to recognize existing employees and promote from within.
job_title: Vice President in Long Island City, NY
pros: There are many talented people there, and lots of opportunities to do some interesting work.
cons: Unfortunately, the work is hampered by lots of bureaucracy. Often times, corporate politics, rather than results, determine who gets ahead. The infrastructure is antiquated.  Too little attention is paid to strenthening the long term health of the company.  Every project is reviewed for quick pay back without thought to investing in long term growth.  Recent layoffs contributed to severe morale issues; just waiting for the other shoe to drop in 2009.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Long Island City, NY
pros: Large company. Many opportunities to move around. Flexible work schedule- could be bad for you depends.. see cons below. A well known brand- good to have on your resume.
cons: Currently not in a good place financially, so this will reflect on your pay, bonuses, and overall job satisfaction. hardly any work and life balance, esp. if you are in IT area. Flexible work schedule also means that you are expected to work from home if you can't get things done in the 9-10 hrs you spent in the office. Forget about asking for more resources in this economy.

review_title: "Good learning opportunities, very consontrated on client service reviews".
job_title: Personal Banker in New York, NY
pros:
The incentives as far as 401k match is the highlight. 
Otherwise, medical insurance is expensive.
Vacation is usually 2 weeks to start.
cons:
Basically, the name of the game is customer service and anonymous client reviews".
Anonymous ratings on your performance can literally damage your career.
These "anonymous client rveviews" or "KDS" are incorporated in your compensation.
Goals need to be met and exceeded, KDS has to be great or else your lifespan in this company 
will be very short lived.

review_title: It's a huge company, experiences vary greatly.  Mostly dependent on 1 and 2 level managers for analyst positions.
pros:
Huge company.
Can work many locations and remotely.
If working on international can potentially travel internationally.
Internal jobs database that is searchable and can apply for all kinds of jobs.
Great place for any point in career.  Many people start and return later.  Enough opportunity to be a lifer but will typically have to move between businesses for significant promotions/raises.
cons:
Pretty stable overall but subject to market swings.
Work/Life balance can be real hit/miss to both extremes.  Some teams 40 hr week, others 60 hr week.  At least it is not a consistent culture of no work/life balance like other places.
Few good employees and mostly only terrible resumes coming across.

pros:
Very flexible working schedule.
Great benefits.
cons:
Top heavy with regards to management. We had 1 manager per 3 employees, at times giving contradictory requirements.
Poor cross-integration between sectors, with a mentality of some sectors being treated as second rate citizens.
Notion that reducing head count will directly have an effect on the stock price - as such head cut reduction has been going on at an extremely high rate, without regard to consequence while stock price has remained almost identical as what it was years ago.

pros: Some decent people to work with.  Depends on your supervisor you can have great motivation or it can be a nightmare and just a reason for some benefits or a pay check.
cons: The structure changes regularly. There is usually poor leadership among the chain of command which affects anyone below them.  By poor leadership I mean there is usually clichés, and if your not in it, well then you will get a rude awakening.  And while most of us don't always agree with our manager at some point, managers have to be able to listen....which I've never seen in any of my surrounding areas.

pros: You can gain insights into why capital adequacy, large exposures and liquidity are crucial and learn about the Basel 3 framework which governs the way these reports must be finalised.  A lot of knowledgeable people surrounded me who always lent me a hand when I needed help.
cons: Tight deadlines to get reports done, a technical hitch in another system can hold you up for hours as you can't access information you need. Reporting systems are sometimes exremely difficult to handle. As you download information from a reporting system, you have to process by performing many, repetitive actions in Excel. The formatted report must be uploaded in another reporting system. You can lose a few hours if you have not formatted the report carefully.

pros: Fast-paced environment, flexible schedule for students, excellent pay with bonuses added, people were great to work with, has great customer loyalty, teller system NBS was easy to use
cons: Some managers were micromanaging, one of which found out that many people don't like like that when she resigned after less than a year managing a retail location. Very into saying a welcome and goodbye script to customer, you weren't allowed to put your personal spin on it, you had to say what Citi wanted verbatim. Everyone sounded like a robot, BUT other than that, fun place to work.

pros: A truly Global Bank, with an amazing culture that helps each employee grow individually. This place is very inspiring with  intellectually stimulating environment that teaches you a lot.
cons: Might be intimidating at times. Difficult to find the right person for the work you need to do. It is a very adaptable environment but still because it is such a big organisation some processes could take a lot of time.

review_title: Great company to work for with room for advancement
pros: There are many pros to working for Citi. They care about their employees and customers. The vacation time offered, benefits from day 1, maternity and paternity leave policy. The benefits are great! You have a chance for advancement as long as you are open to feedback and find a mentor. This has been the key for me last 17 years. Depending on your location, you also get to work from home. Great company, hands down!
cons: If you work in a large call center as an hourly employee, if there are open desks the option for work from home is non existent.

review_title: Great Managers Make ALL the Difference
job_title: Financial Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Very good managers at my office in San Francisco, has a "tech" kind of feel when it comes to colleague activities, get togethers, always have good boost in morale.   Not just the traditional boring quiet banks where managers hang over your head like a slave driver.  Coworkers are great as well, very supportive, age ranged varied  which is a good mix.  Ppl know their "stuff" for the most part and is supportive when it came to learning new things, taking on new tasks. I'm very fortunate to have worked here at this office.
cons: Very tough to  promoted unless someone gets laid off or quit,  introducing new tech  is slower than a turtle

job_title: Senior Operations Manager in Irving, TX
pros: Time off is excellent. Benefits are good.  Paid time off for new mothers AND fathers is excellent.
cons: Lots of offshoring going on all around the business. If it can be moved to Manila or Mexico City or India it will be. This is not new, been with Citi 19 years and its been happening the whole time but now its really fast tracked. That and the hiring of contractors vs. Full time, benefit eligible employees has picked up BIG TIME. Used to be out of the 6500ish folks at this site, 6400 were FTEs. Now more than half are contract workers.

review_title: wealth management  at Citi does not bode well for internal transfers.
job_title: Registered Associate in New York, NY
pros: Although the reputation is awful, and it is very beauracratic, there is some great human capital at the firm.  You will have access to innovative products and extensive research, both funamental and technical.
cons: seemingly impossible for most people to advance to "front office" roles.  specifically in Smith Barney, most financial advisors do not add value for their clients.  in a tough market environment, this has become very evident.  management and advisors focus solely on sales, and not enough on knowledge and market savvy.  to call many of them "used car salesman" would be a fair assesment.  also will not pay for graduate level education or certifications like the CFA.
